Allison Joyce/Getty\n\nUnder Armour CEO Kevin Plank announced on Monday that he is stepping down from President Donald Trump's American Manufacturing Council, saying the company \"engages in innovation and sports, not politics.\"\n\nThe move comes after Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier, the only black business leader in the council, resigned from the group after Trump initially failed to explicitly denounce white nationalists following the events in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nA number of other CEOs have said they will remain on the council in order to impact policy going forward.\n\nPlank previously stepped into the political arena by calling Trump \"a real asset to this country.\" Plank later clarified his comments saying it was \"unfortunate that my words got characterized in a way that were meant to be divisive in some way, shape, or form.\"\n\nTrump almost immediately attacked Frazier on Twitter after his resignation, Trump has so far not done the same to Plank.\n\n\"I joined the American Manufacturing Council because I believed it was important for Under Armour to have an active seat at the table and represent our industry. We remain resolute in our potential and ability to improve American manufacturing. However, Under Armour engages in innovation and sports, not politics.\n\nI am appreciative of the opportunity to have served, but have decided to step down from the council. I love our country and our company and will continue to focus my efforts on inspiring every person that they can do anything through the power of sport which promotes unity, diversity and {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "storyUri": "eng-3361963", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-15T01:00:00Z", "url": "http://fortune.com/2017/08/14/under-armour-kevin-plank-leaves-trump-manufacturing-council/", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Under Armour CEO Kevin Plank announced on Monday that he is leaving President Donald Trump's manufacturing council.\n\nThe decision comes amid the blowback against Trump for his response to the events in Charlottesville, Va over the weekend. Ken Frazier, the CEO of pharma giant Merck, announced Monday morning that he was leaving the council over the response to Trump's response to Charlottesville, prompting angry tweets from the President.\n\n\"I am appreciative of the opportunity to have served, but have decided to step down from the council,\" Plank said in a statement posted on Under Armour's official Twitter account Monday evening. \"I love our country and our company and will continue to focus my efforts on inspiring every person that they can do anything through the power of sport which promotes unity, diversity and inclusion.\"\n\nPlank came under fire earlier this year when he seemed to praise Trump, saying: \"to have such a pro-business President is something that is a real asset for the country.\"\n\nThe company quickly sought to clarify Plank's comments and emphasized that it valued \"optimism, teamwork and unity.\" Plank then defended his comments in June and said it was \"unfortunate\" that his words were seen as \"divisive.\"\n\nThe Under Armour CEO was one of more than two dozen high profile executives on Trump's manufacturing council when the president announced the group in January. The president formed a similar group for tech CEOs, and that group also saw several members depart after controversies earlier this year.\n\nAfter white nationalists clashed with protesters in Charlottesville this weekend, Trump did not initially condemn white supremacists or racists by name, prompting sharp criticism from all sides. After intense pressure, the president on Monday issued a new statement saying \"racism is evil\" and condemning \"the KKK, neo-Nazi, white supremacists and other hate groups.\"\n\nStill, Under Armour decided it had had enough of the controversial administration.\n\n\"I joined the American Manufacturing Council because I believed it was important for Under Armour to have an active seat at the table and represent our industry. Kenneth Frazier, the CEO of pharmaceutical giant Merck, was the first to step down from the council, which focuses on the economy and job creation, as Trump came under intense criticism for initially failing to condemn white supremacists and neo Nazi groups following the Charlottesville attack.\n\n\"Under Armour engages in sports, not politics,\" Plank said in a statement posted to the sportswear company's official Twitter account. \"I am appreciative for the opportunity to have served, but have decided to step down from the council.\"\n\n\"I love our country and our company and will continue to focus my efforts on inspiring every person that they can do anything through the power of sport which promotes unity, diversity and inclusion.\"\n\nPlank and other members of the council have come under pressure in the aftermath of the attack in Charlottesville, when a white supremacist rally erupted into violence. One of the rally participants has been accused of intentionally driving his car into counter-protesters, killing 32-year-old Heather Heyer.\n\nPlank had earlier tweeted: \"We are saddened by #Charlottesville. We choose love & unity.\"\n\nThat response was found to be insufficient by Twitter users, who urged Plank to step down from Trump's council. was taking a stand against intolerance and extremism.\n\nKenneth Frazier announced the move on twitter.\n\nIt follows criticism of Mr Trump for not specifically denouncing the far right in his first comments on violence at a white national rally in Charlottesville, Virginia, at the weekend.\n\nMr Trump denounced what he called \"this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides\", repeating \"many sides\" in his address.\n\nA 32-year-old woman was killed and 19 people were injured, five critically, on Saturday when a man ploughed a car into a crowd of people protesting the rally.\n\nMr Frazier said in his tweet that US leaders must honour \"our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal\".\n\nMr Trump responded in a tweet, \"now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nSeveral executives from top US companies have stepped down from a number of presidential advisory councils in protest at some of Mr Trump's policies.\n\nTesla Inc CEO Elon Musk and Walt Disney Co CEO Robert Iger left the president's Strategic and Policy Forum,a business advisory group, in June, after Mr Trump said he would withdraw from the Paris climate accord.\n\nMr Musk also left the manufacturing council.\n\nFormer Uber Technologies Inc CEO Travis Kalanick quit the business advisory council in February amid pressure from activists and employees Musk also left the manufacturing council.\n\nFormer Uber Technologies Inc CEO Travis Kalanick quit the business advisory council in February amid pressure from activists and employees who opposed the administration's immigration policies.\n\nThe White House said Sunday that Trump's remarks condemning violence at a white nationalist rally were meant to include the Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazi groups.\n\nDemocrats and Republicans criticised Trump for waiting too long to address the violence - his first major domestic crisis as president - and for failing when he did speak out to explicitly condemn white-supremacist marchers who ignited the melee.\n\nTrump on Saturday initially denounced what he called \"this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides.\"\n\nOn Sunday, however, the White House added: \"The president said very strongly in his statement yesterday that he condemns all forms of violence, bigotry, and hatred, and of course that includes white supremacists, KKK, neo-Nazi, and all extremist groups. 0.8313725590705872, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "The chief executive of pharmaceutical giant Merck & Co. publicly resigned from a White House manufacturing council on Monday, declaring he felt \"a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nThe move by Kenneth Frazier, one of corporate America's leading African American executives, came after President Trump was criticized for not explicitly condemning white supremacists after violent clashes with counter-protestors turned deadly in Charlottesville, Va., on Saturday.\n\nTrump quickly lashed out at Frazier on Twitter.\n\n\"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\" Trump wrote less than an hour after Merck posted Frazier's statement on Twitter.\n\nFrazier was among more than two dozen corporate executives and union officials advising the Trump administration on boosting American manufacturing.\n\nBut after Trump's comments in the wake of the deadly Charlottesville protest, blaming the violence \"on many sides\" without specifically denouncing the white nationalists who were at the center of the clashes, Merck posted a statement on Twitter from Frazier announcing his resignation from the council.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier said.\n\n\"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism,\" he said.\n\nMany on Twitter noted that Trump responded more quickly and specifically to Frazier's {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T15:27:00Z", "url": "https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/merck-ceo-resigns-from-trump-council-after-charlottesville/", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Chief executive Kenneth Frazier stepped down from the president's American Manufacturing Council, citing intolerance and extremism\n\nMerck & Co Inc Chief Executive Kenneth Frazier resigned from U.S. President Donald Trump's American Manufacturing Council on Monday, saying he was taking a stand against intolerance and extremism.\n\nA gathering of hundreds of white nationalists in Virginia took a deadly turn on Saturday when a car plowed into a group of counter-protesters and killed at least one person.\n\nTrump had said \"many sides\" were involved, drawing fire from across the political spectrum for not specifically denouncing the far right.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier, who is African-American, said in a statement announcing his resignation. (bit.ly/2fFnITM)\n\n\"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism,\" he said.\n\nTrump responded in a tweet, now that \"Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nSeveral executives from top U.S. companies have stepped down from a number of presidential advisory councils in protest to Trump policies.\n\nTesla Inc CEO Elon Musk and Walt Disney Co CEO Robert Iger left the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, a business advisory group, in June, after Trump said he would withdraw from the Paris climate accord. Musk also left the manufacturing council.\n\nFormer Uber Technologies Inc [UBER.UL] CEO Travis Kalanick quit the business advisory council in February amid pressure from activists and employees who opposed the administration's immigration policies.\n\nThe White House said Sunday that Trump's remarks condemning violence at a white nationalist rally were meant to include the Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazi groups.\n\nDemocrats and Republicans criticized Trump for waiting too long to address the violence - his first major domestic crisis as president - and for failing when he did speak out to explicitly condemn white-supremacist marchers who ignited the melee.\n\nTrump on Saturday initially denounced what he called \"this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides.\"\n\nOn Sunday, however, the White House added: \"The president said very strongly in his statement yesterday that he condemns all forms of violence, bigotry, and hatred, and of course that includes white supremacists, KKK, neo-Nazi, and all extremist groups. He called for national unity and bringing all Americans together.\"", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "time": "15:27:00", "originalArticle": null, "details": {}, "timeCrawl": "15:27:00", {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T14:16:00Z", "url": "https://www.rollcall.com/politics/trump-fires-back-at-ceo-for-resigning-from-advisory-council", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Hours after Kenneth Frazier, CEO of Merck Pharma, announced he was stepping down from the President's Manufacturing Council, President Donald J. Trump hit back on Twitter.\n\nFrazier's resignation came two days after violence broke out at a white nationalist \"Unite the Right\" rally in Charlottesville, Virginia. In a statement Monday morning, Frazier said he felt \"a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nCritics from all sides have criticized the president Trump for not taking a stronger stance against white supremacists after violence broke out at the rally, which left three people dead and nearly 20 injured.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier said in the statement.\n\nTrump didn't mince words in his reaction to Frazier's resignation, saying the pharmaceutical company CEO would now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nNow that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council,he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES! -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nFrazier was one of 28 company executives who joined Trump's American Manufacturing Jobs Initiative in January.\n\nOther CEOs have also left Trump's advisory councils, including former Uber CEO Travis Kalanick, who left in February. Tesla CEO Elon Musk and Walt Disney CEO Bob Iger left the Strategic and Policy Forum in June following Trump's announcement that the U.S. would withdraw from the Paris climate agreement.\n\nAs a trustee for Penn State, Frazier served as the chair of the special investigative committee in 2011 on the child-sex abuse case involving former assistant football coach Jerry Sandusky.\n\nFrazier has served as chairman of the board and CEO of Merck since 2011. In his statement, he said the U.S finds strength \"from its diversity and the contributions made by men and women of different faiths, races, sexual orientations and political beliefs.\"\n\nFollowing the violent clash this weekend, Trump didn't address white nationalists directly in his comments.\n\n\"We condemn in the strongest possible terms this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T15:18:00Z", "url": "http://www.lifezette.com/polizette/trump-say-merck-ceo-quit-business-council/", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "President slams pharmaceutical exec, 'He will have more time to lower ripoff drug prices'\n\nPresident Donald Trump ripped into Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier Monday for resigning from the American Manufacturing Council.\n\nThe CEO of the pharmaceutical firm announced his resignation Monday in a statement citing the president's decision not to use the specific words \"white supremacy\" and \"Neo-Nazi\" in condemning the hate groups who participated in the Charlottesville protest Saturday. This protest resulted in the death of one woman, with dozens of others wounded. Although Trump condemned \"in the strongest possible terms\" the \"egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence\" that took place \"on many sides\" in Charlottesville, he received widespread criticism for failing to identify specific groups.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier said in his statement. \"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nHe added: \"Our country's strength stems from its diversity and the contributions made by men and women of different faiths, races, sexual orientations, and political beliefs.\"\n\nIn response, Trump took to Twitter Monday morning to needle Frazier over his resignation, saying, \"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nThe American Manufacturing Council, led by Dow Chemical CEO Andrew Liveris, originally sported 28 members when it was formed in January to aid Trump in revitalizing U.S. manufacturing and creating jobs. But Frazier became the latest White House council member to step down in a protest against Trump and his policies.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk and Disney CEO Robert Iger resigned in June after Trump announced that the U.S. would be withdrawing from the Paris climate accord. Uber co-founder Travis Kalanick withdrew from Trump's business advisory council in February after the president issued his travel-ban executive order.\n\nAlthough Frazier took issue with Trump's all-encompassing Charlottesville statement on Saturday, the White House issued a statement Sunday clarifying that Trump \"said very strongly in his statement yesterday that he condemns all forms of violence, bigotry, and hatred. Of course that includes white supremacists, KKK Neo-Nazi and all extremist groups. He called for national unity and bringing all Americans together.\"\n\nBut that didn't stop Frazier from making a personal statement and removing his voice and expertise from Trump's manufacturing council.\n\nTrump responded to Frazier's departure less than an hour after the Merck CEO made his announcement -- a fact that mainstream media members noticed and exploited as they continued to push their narrative.\n\n\"It took Trump 54 minutes to condemn Merck CEO Ken Frazier, but after several days he still has not condemned murdering white supremacists,\" CNN commentator Keith Boykin tweeted.\n\n\"Merck CEO Ken Frazier has officially earned more vigorous denunciation from Donald Trump than neo-Nazis. Happy 2017,\" MSNBC's Joy Reid tweeted.\n\n\"It took Trump 54 minutes to harass Ken Frazier but we're still waiting for him to denounce white nationalists,\" Huffington Post global social media editor {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T13:46:00Z", "url": "https://in.reuters.com/article/virginia-protests-merck-idINKCN1AU1GU", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "REUTERS - Merck & Co Inc Chief Executive Kenneth Frazier resigned from U.S. President Donald Trump's American Manufacturing Council on Monday, saying he was taking a stand against intolerance and extremism.\n\nA gathering of hundreds of white nationalists in Virginia took a deadly turn on Saturday when a car plowed into a group of counter-protesters and killed at least one person.\n\nTrump had said \"many sides\" were involved, drawing fire from across the political spectrum for not specifically denouncing the far right.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier, who is African-American, said in a statement announcing his resignation. (bit.ly/2fFnITM)\n\n\"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism,\" he said.\n\nTrump responded in a tweet, now that \"Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nSeveral executives from top U.S. companies have stepped down from a number of presidential advisory councils in protest to Trump policies.\n\nTesla Inc CEO Elon Musk and Walt Disney Co CEO Robert Iger left the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, a business advisory group, in June, after Trump said he would withdraw from the Paris climate accord. Musk also left the manufacturing council.\n\nFormer Uber Technologies Inc CEO Travis Kalanick quit the business advisory council in February amid pressure from activists and employees who opposed the administration's immigration policies.\n\nThe White House said Sunday that Trump's remarks condemning violence at a white nationalist rally were meant to include the Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazi groups.\n\nDemocrats and Republicans criticized Trump for waiting too long to address the violence - his first major domestic crisis as president - and for failing when he did speak out to explicitly condemn white-supremacist marchers who ignited the melee.\n\nTrump on Saturday initially denounced what he called \"this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides.\"\n\nOn Sunday, however, the White House added: \"The president said very strongly in his statement yesterday that he condemns all forms of violence, bigotry, and hatred, and of course that includes white supremacists, KKK, neo-Nazi, and all extremist groups. He called for national unity and bringing all Americans together.\"", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "time": "13:46:00", "originalArticle": null, "details": {}, "timeCrawl": "13:46:00", {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T17:18:00Z", "url": "http://www.sfexaminer.com/merck-ceo-resigns-white-house-council-take-stand-intolerance-extremism-trump-slams/", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "WASHINGTON -- The chief executive of pharmaceutical giant Merck & Co. publicly resigned from a White House manufacturing council on Monday, declaring he felt \"a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nThe move by Kenneth Frazier, one of corporate America's leading African American executives, came after President Donald Trump was criticized for not explicitly condemning white supremacists after violent clashes with counter-protestors turned deadly in Charlottesville, Va., on Saturday.\n\nTrump quickly lashed out at Frazier on Twitter.\n\n\"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\" Trump wrote less than an hour after Merck posted Frazier's statement on Twitter.\n\nFrazier was among more than two dozen corporate executives and union officials advising the Trump administration on boosting American manufacturing.\n\nBut after Trump's comments in the wake of the deadly Charlottesville protest, blaming the violence \"on many sides\" without specifically denouncing the white nationalists who were at the center of the clashes, Merck posted a statement on Twitter from Frazier announcing his resignation from the council.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier said.\n\n\"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism,\" he said.\n\nMany on Twitter noted that Trump responded more quickly and specifically to Frazier's resignation than he did to the violence in {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T15:22:00Z", "url": "http://nypost.com/2017/08/14/trump-blasts-drug-ceo-who-quit-council-over-charlottesville-rally/", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "The head of US drugmaker Merck resigned Monday from a manufacturing advisory council to the Trump administration citing \"a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism\" - and was promptly lambasted by the president on Twitter.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier tweeted Monday.\n\n\"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism,\" he said in the statement.\n\nPresident Trump lashed back almost immediately about the African-American head of the nation's third-largest pharmaceutical company.\n\n\"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\" he railed.\n\nFrazier's resignation comes shortly after a violent confrontation between white supremacists and protesters in Charlottesville, Va., that left one woman dead and 19 other people injured.\n\nTrump has been assailed for his tepid response and not explicitly condemning the white nationalists who marched in Charlottesville.\n\nIn an appearance Saturday at his golf resort in Bedminster, NJ, Trump faulted \"many sides\" for the violence.\n\nBut he made no mention of the far-right groups involved in the violence, some of whom were wearing Trump hats or T-shirts.\n\nFaced with the backlash, White House officials have since made explicit they oppose bigotry and white supremacy.\n\nSeveral top officials, including Vice President Mike Pence and White House adviser Ivanka Trump, have spoken strongly against hate groups.\n\nFrazier was one of 28 business and union leaders Trump named in January to the council, which was aimed at helping him boost US manufacturing jobs.\n\nTrump told Frazier and other pharmaceutical CEOs during a White House meeting that drug prices were too high\n\nFrazier is the second CEO to quit advising Team Trump in protest. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T11:29:00Z", "url": "http://heavy.com/news/2017/08/merck-ceo-ken-frazier-trump-council-charlottesville-statement-twitter/", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Merck CEO Ken Frazier (right) with President Donald Trump on July 20.\n\nKen Frazier, the CEO of pharmaceutical giant Merck, resigned from President Donald Trump's American Manufacturing Council over the president's failure to immediately condemn white supremacists after the violence in Charlottesville, Virginia on Saturday. \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier wrote.\n\nHere's the full statement Merck posted on Twitter:\n\nI am resigning from the President's American Manufacturing Council. Our country's strength comes from its diversity and the contributions made by men and women of different faiths, races, sexual orientations and political beliefs. America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal. As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscious, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\n\nTrump responded to Frazier's decision on Twitter, but didn't reference Frazier's reasons. \"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council,he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES,\" the president tweeted.\n\nFrazier's decision followed Trump's remarks after the violence in Charlottesville, which broke out at a white supremacist rally. After a car plowed into a crowd, killing a counter-protester, Trump said there was violence \"on many sides\" without specifically denouncing white supremacists. It wasn't until Sunday that members of the Administration finally said that Trump denounces white supremacists.\n\nFrazier, an African-American who became CEO of Merck in 2011, was among the chief executives to join the President's American Manufacturing Council on January 27. The other CEOs to join included Whirpool's Jeff Fettig, Ford's Mark Fields, General Electric's Jeff Immelt, Kevin Plank of Under Armour and Dennis Muilenburg of Beoing.\n\nTesla's Elon Musk and Disney's Robert Iger also left another Trump advisory council in June. They were members of the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, but left in June after Trump pulled the U.S. out of the UN Paris climate accord.\n\nFrazier and Trump were on good terms until today. In July, Frazier traveled to the White House during \"Made in America Week\" to announce a partnership with Pfizer and Corning on \"valor glass.\" The project is set to add 1,000 jobs to the Corning plant in Vineland, New Jersey.\n\n\"This initiative will bring a key industry to our shores that for too long has been dominated by foreign countries,\" Trump said in July. \"This announcement reflects a central theme of my administration that when we invest in America, it's a win for our companies, our workers, and our nation as a whole.\"", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"imp": {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T15:50:00Z", "url": "http://www.wbal.com/article/258147/3/exec-resigns-from-presidents-council-and-trump-lashes-out", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- The CEO of the nation's third largest pharmaceutical company resigned from a manufacturing council that advises President Donald Trump days after racially tinged clashes in Charlottesville, Virginia, citing \"a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nTrump, who is under increasing pressure to explicitly condemn the white supremacist and hate groups involved, lashed out almost immediately Monday at Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier on Twitter, saying that because of the resignation, the pharmaceutical executive \"will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nNow that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council,he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES! -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nDrugmakers have come under closer scrutiny because of rising drug prices, though Merck has not been one of the companies targeted by lawmakers or watchdog groups.\n\nFrazier, who is African American, said in a tweet on Monday that the country's leaders must \"honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy.\"\n\nOne person was killed in the protests after a car slammed into a crowd and multiple people were injured in that incident and in running clashes between white supremacists and those opposing them.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned from a White House advisory council for the same reason.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier this year as executives retire, are replaced, or, as with Frazier, Musk and Iger, resign.", "location": {"label": {"eng": "New York City"}, "country": {"label": {"eng": "United States"}, "type": Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nFrazier, chairman and CEO of Merck, announced Monday he would resign from the council \"as a matter of personal conscience\" following the protests this weekend in Charlottesville, Va.\n\n\"Our country's strength stems from its diversity and the contributions made by men and women of different faiths, races, sexual orientations and political beliefs,\" he said.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal. As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nFrazier's resignation comes as Trump faces criticism for not condemning white supremacists this weekend in Charlottesville.\n\nIn responding to the violence in Charlottesville involving Nazi and white supremacist groups, Trump condemned bigotry and hatred \"on {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T18:42:00Z", "url": "https://www.stabroeknews.com/2017/news/world/08/14/merck-ceo-resigns-from-trump-council-over-charlottesville/", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "(Reuters) - Merck & Co Inc Chief Executive Kenneth Frazier resigned from U.S. President Donald Trump's American Manufacturing Council on Monday, saying he was taking a stand against intolerance and extremism.\n\nFrazier, who is African-American, is the only CEO so far to leave one of Trump's advisory councils because of his reaction to the violence in Virginia. Prominent Democrats and Republicans criticized Trump's response to the violence over the weekend.\n\nA gathering of hundreds of white nationalists in Virginia took a deadly turn on Saturday when a car plowed into a group of counter-protesters and killed at least one person.\n\nTrump had said \"many sides\" were involved, drawing fire from across the political spectrum for not specifically denouncing the far right.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier said in a statement announcing his resignation. (http://bit.ly/2fFnITM)\n\n\"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism,\" he said.\n\nTrump responded in a tweet, saying now that \"Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nThe Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, which represents the pharmaceutical industry and lobbies on its behalf in Congress, declined to offer a statement of support for Frazier or to comment on Trump's reaction.\n\nThe industry's silence comes as Trump is finalizing an executive order on drug prices that would relax industry regulation and contains measures that, some say, would protect existing drug prices or even increase them.\n\nIndividually, at least one CEO, John Maraganore of Alnylam Pharmaceuticals, tweeted his support, saying he was \"proud to stand with leaders like Ken Frazier.\"\n\nMerck shares rose 0.6 percent in midday trading on the New York Stock Exchange, roughly in line with the wider market.\n\nFrazier has been at Merck for around 25 years, starting as general counsel of one of the drugmaker's subsidiaries in 1992. He became CEO of the company in 2011.\n\nFrazier frequently made political contributions during the 2016 election, donating to both Republican and Democratic members of Congress but no donations to a presidential candidate during the year.\n\nThe political PAC maintained by Merck and funded through donations from Merck employees made over $1.1 million in candidate contributions during the 2016 campaign - but did not contribute to Trump or his Democratic rival Hillary Clinton, according to documents filed with the Federal Elections Commission.\n\n\"Thanks @Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is,\" Paul Polman, the CEO of Anglo-Dutch consumer giant Unilever Plc said in a tweet.\n\nOther top business leaders also spoke out in reaction to the violence in Charlottesville.\n\n\"Lincoln: 'A house divided against itself cannot stand.' Isolate those who try to separate us. No equivalence w/ those who bring us together,\" Goldman Sachs CEO Lloyd Blankfein tweeted on Monday morning.\n\nA Dell spokeswoman said, \"While we would not comment on any member's personal decision, there's no change in Dell engaging with the Trump administration and governments around the world.\"\n\nSeveral executives from top U.S. companies have stepped down from a number of presidential advisory councils in protest to Trump policies.\n\nTesla Inc CEO Elon Musk and Walt Disney Co CEO Robert Iger left the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, a business advisory group, in June, after Trump said he would withdraw from the Paris climate accord. Musk also left the manufacturing council.\n\nFormer Uber Technologies Inc CEO Travis Kalanick quit the business advisory council in February amid pressure from activists and employees who opposed the administration's immigration policies.\n\nThe White House said Sunday that Trump's remarks condemning violence at a white nationalist rally were meant to include the Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazi groups.\n\nDemocrats and Republicans criticized Trump for waiting too long to address the violence - his first major domestic crisis as president - and for failing when he did speak out to explicitly condemn white-supremacist marchers who ignited the melee.\n\nTrump on Saturday initially denounced what he called \"this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides.\"\n\nOn Sunday, however, the White House added: \"The president said very strongly in his statement yesterday that he condemns all forms of violence, bigotry, and hatred, and of course that includes white supremacists, KKK, neo-Nazi, and all extremist groups. He called for national unity and bringing all Americans together.\"", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "time": "18:42:00", "originalArticle": null, "details": {}, "timeCrawl": "18:42:00", Frazier departed following Trump's apparent unwillingness over the weekend to single out white supremacists.\n\n\"I love our country and our company and will continue to focus my efforts on inspiring every person that they can do anything through the power of sport which promotes unity, diversity and inclusion,\" Plank said in a statement.\n\nUA tweet\n\nIn February, Plank called Trump an asset for the country. Here's that interview:\n\nThis story is developing. Frazier, who is African American, announced his decision Monday morning, writing in a statement that he felt \"a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nThe decision came after critics questioned Trump's decision not to call out white supremacists in a statement condemning the violence that erupted Saturday. Police said Heather Heyer, 32, died after she was struck by a vehicle when a man, identified by police as 20-year-old James Alex Fields Jr., slammed a car into protesters and two other vehicles.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier wrote.\n\npic.twitter.com/a1PNQZism5 -- Merck (@Merck)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nTrump responded to the news on Twitter, writing that Frazier \"will have more time to lower ripoff drug prices.\"\n\nNow that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council,he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES! -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nDrugmakers have come under closer scrutiny because of rising drug prices, though Merck has not been one of the companies targeted by lawmakers or watchdog groups.\n\nTrump told reporters in Bedminster, New Jersey, on Saturday that he condemned \"in the strongest possible terms this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides.\n\nFields faces charges including second-degree murder.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. The president did not explicitly condemn white supremacists.\n\nTrump almost immediately fired back at Frazier, turning the conversation toward drug pricing.\n\nNow that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council,he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES! -- Donald J. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T18:24:00Z", "url": "http://www.dnaindia.com/world/report-virginia-clashes-merck-ceo-resigns-from-trump-council-faces-us-president-s-ire-2529948", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Kenneth Frazier is the first CEO to resign from Trump's council after the Virginia incident.\n\nMerck & Co Inc Chief Executive Kenneth Frazier resigned from US President Donald Trump's American Manufacturing Council on Monday, saying he was taking a stand against intolerance and extremism.\n\nTrump denounced white supremacists including neo-Nazis and the Ku Klux Klan on Monday, and said racism, hatred and bigotry had no place in America following a violent white-nationalist rally in Virginia. Frazier, who is African-American, is the only CEO so far to leave one of Trump's advisory councils because of his reaction to the violence in Virginia. Prominent Democrats and Republicans criticized Trump's response to the violence over the weekend.\n\nThe gathering of hundreds of white nationalists took a deadly turn on Saturday when a car plowed into a group of counter-protesters and killed at least one person. Trump had said \"many sides\" were involved, drawing fire from across the political spectrum for not specifically denouncing the far right. \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier said in a statement announcing his resignation. (http://bit.ly/2fFnITM) \"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism,\" he said. Trump responded in a tweet, saying now that \"Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nThe son of a janitor, Frazier joined Merck as general counsel of one of the drugmaker's subsidiaries in 1992, working his way up to CEO of the company in 2011. He made his name as the company's top lawyer, steering it through daunting litigation over Vioxx, its widely used painkiller that was withdrawn in 2004 after being linked to heart attacks. Many observers thought Merck would eventually have to shell out $10 billion or more to thousands of plaintiffs over the drug's withdrawal. But Frazier's legal strategy led to a $4.85-billion settlement in 2007, allowing Merck to refocus on its pipeline of experimental medicines. Merck shares rose 0.6 percent in midday trading on the New York Stock Exchange, roughly in line with the wider market.\n\nFrazier frequently made political contributions during the 2016 election, donating to both Republican and Democratic members of Congress but no donations to a presidential candidate during the year. The political PAC maintained by Merck and funded through donations from Merck employees made over $1.1 million in candidate contributions during the 2016 campaign - but did not contribute to Trump or his Democratic rival Hillary Clinton, according to documents filed with the Federal Elections Commission. The Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, which represents the pharmaceutical industry and lobbies on its behalf in Congress, declined to offer a statement of support for Frazier or to comment on Trump's reaction.\n\nThe industry's silence comes as Trump is finalizing an executive order on drug prices that would relax industry regulation and contains measures that, some say, would protect existing drug prices or even increase them.\n\nIndividually, at least one CEO, John Maraganore of Alnylam Pharmaceuticals, tweeted his support, saying he was \"proud to stand with leaders like Ken Frazier.\" Other top business leaders also spoke out in response to the violence in Charlottesville. \"I support Ken Frazier's decision. I'm thankful we have business leaders such as Ken to remind America of its better angels,\" said Hewlett Packard Enterprises CEO Meg Whitman, who ran for governor of California as a Republican in 2010.\n\nGoldman Sachs CEO Lloyd Blankfein tweeted: \"Lincoln: 'A house divided against itself cannot stand.' Isolate those who try to separate us. No equivalence w/ those who bring us together.\" Several executives from top U.S. companies have previously stepped down from a number of presidential advisory councils in protest to Trump policies. Tesla Inc CEO Elon Musk and Walt Disney Co CEO Robert Iger left the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, a business advisory group, in June, after Trump said he would withdraw from the Paris climate accord. Musk also left the manufacturing council.\n\nFormer Uber Technologies Inc CEO Travis Kalanick quit the business advisory council in February amid pressure from activists and employees who opposed the administration's immigration policies. The White House said Sunday that Trump's remarks condemning violence at a white nationalist rally were meant to include the Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazi groups. Democrats and Republicans criticized Trump for waiting too long to address the violence - his first major domestic crisis as president - and for failing when he did speak out to explicitly condemn white-supremacist marchers who ignited the melee.\n\nTrump on Saturday initially denounced what he called \"this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides.\" On Sunday, however, the White House added: \"The president said very strongly in his statement yesterday that he condemns all forms of violence, bigotry, and hatred, and of course that includes white supremacists, KKK, neo-Nazi, and all extremist groups. He called for national unity and bringing all Americans together.\"", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "time": "18:24:00", "originalArticle": null, "details": {}, "timeCrawl": "18:24:00", Frazier said he was leaving Trump's American Manufacturing Council, arguing U.S. leaders must \"clearly reject expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy.\"\n\n\"Our country's strength stems from its diversity and the contributions made by men and women of different faiths, races, sexual orientations and political beliefs,\" Frazier said in a statement.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" he continued.\n\n\"As CEO of Merck, and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\npic.twitter.com/a1PNQZism5 -- Merck (@Merck)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nTrump quickly fired back at the CEO, saying Merck would \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES.\"\n\nNow that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council,he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES! -- Donald J. denouncing the violence in Virginia but not directly putting blame on any particular group.\n\n\"We condemn in the strongest possible terms this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T15:21:00Z", "url": "http://www.dnaindia.com/world/report-merck-ceo-resigns-from-trump-council-over-charlottesville-2529894", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Merck & Co Inc Chief Executive Kenneth Frazier resigned from U.S. President Donald Trump's American Manufacturing Council on Monday, saying he was taking a stand against intolerance and extremism.\n\nFrazier, who is African-American, is the only CEO so far to leave one of Trump's advisory councils because of his reaction to the violence in Virginia. Prominent Democrats and Republicans criticized Trump's response to the violence over the weekend.\n\nA gathering of hundreds of white nationalists in Virginia took a deadly turn on Saturday when a car plowed into a group of counter-protesters and killed at least one person.\n\nTrump had said \"many sides\" were involved, drawing fire from across the political spectrum for not specifically denouncing the far right.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier said in a statement announcing his resignation. (http://bit.ly/2fFnITM)\n\n\"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism,\" he said.\n\nTrump responded in a tweet, saying now that \"Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nMerck shares rose 0.8 percent in morning trading on the New York Stock Exchange, in line with the wider market.\n\nOther top business leaders also spoke out in reaction to the violence in Charlottesville.\n\n\"Lincoln: 'A house divided against itself cannot stand.' Isolate those who try to separate us. No equivalence w/ those who bring us together,\" Goldman Sachs CEO Lloyd Blankfein tweeted on Monday morning.\n\nSeveral executives from top U.S. companies have stepped down from a number of presidential advisory councils in protest to Trump policies.\n\nTesla Inc CEO Elon Musk and Walt Disney Co CEO Robert Iger left the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, a business advisory group, in June, after Trump said he would withdraw from the Paris climate accord. Musk also left the manufacturing council.\n\nFormer Uber Technologies Inc CEO Travis Kalanick quit the business advisory council in February amid pressure from activists and employees who opposed the administration's immigration policies.\n\nThe White House said Sunday that Trump's remarks condemning violence at a white nationalist rally were meant to include the Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazi groups.\n\nDemocrats and Republicans criticized Trump for waiting too long to address the violence - his first major domestic crisis as president - and for failing when he did speak out to explicitly condemn white-supremacist marchers who ignited the melee.\n\nTrump on Saturday initially denounced what he called \"this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides.\"\n\nOn Sunday, however, the White House added: \"The president said very strongly in his statement yesterday that he condemns all forms of violence, bigotry, and hatred, and of course that includes white supremacists, KKK, neo-Nazi, and all extremist groups. He called for national unity and bringing all Americans together.\"\n\n(This article has not been edited by DNA's editorial team and is auto-generated from an agency feed.)", "location": null, {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T17:19:00Z", "url": "https://finance.yahoo.com/news/merck-ceo-resigns-trump-council-130843246.html", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "By Michael Erman\n\n(Reuters) - Merck & Co Inc Chief Executive Kenneth Frazier resigned from U.S. President Donald Trump's American Manufacturing Council on Monday, saying he was taking a stand against intolerance and extremism.\n\nFrazier, who is African-American, is the only CEO so far to leave one of Trump's advisory councils because of his reaction to the violence in Virginia. Prominent Democrats and Republicans criticized Trump's response to the violence over the weekend.\n\nA gathering of hundreds of white nationalists in Virginia took a deadly turn on Saturday when a car plowed into a group of counter-protesters and killed at least one person.\n\nTrump had said \"many sides\" were involved, drawing fire from across the political spectrum for not specifically denouncing the far right.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier said in a statement announcing his resignation. (http://bit.ly/2fFnITM)\n\n\"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism,\" he said.\n\nTrump responded in a tweet, saying now that \"Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nThe Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, which represents the pharmaceutical industry and lobbies on its behalf in Congress, declined to offer a statement of support for Frazier or to comment on Trump's reaction.\n\nThe industry's silence comes as Trump is finalizing an executive order on drug prices that would relax industry regulation and contains measures that, some say, would protect existing drug prices or even increase them.\n\nIndividually, at least one CEO, John Maraganore of Alnylam Pharmaceuticals, tweeted his support, saying he was \"proud to stand with leaders like Ken Frazier.\"\n\nMerck shares rose 0.6 percent in midday trading on the New York Stock Exchange, roughly in line with the wider market.\n\nFrazier has been at Merck for around 25 years, starting as general counsel of one of the drugmaker's subsidiaries in 1992. He became CEO of the company in 2011.\n\nFrazier frequently made political contributions during the 2016 election, donating to both Republican and Democratic members of Congress but no donations to a presidential candidate during the year.\n\nThe political PAC maintained by Merck and funded through donations from Merck employees made over $1.1 million in candidate contributions during the 2016 campaign - but did not contribute to Trump or his Democratic rival Hillary Clinton, according to documents filed with the Federal Elections Commission.\n\n\"Thanks @Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is,\" Paul Polman, the CEO of Anglo-Dutch consumer giant Unilever Plc said in a tweet.\n\nOther top business leaders also spoke out in reaction to the violence in Charlottesville.\n\n\"Lincoln: 'A house divided against itself cannot stand.' Isolate those who try to separate us. No equivalence w/ those who bring us together,\" Goldman Sachs CEO Lloyd Blankfein tweeted on Monday morning.\n\nA Dell spokeswoman said, \"While we would not comment on any member's personal decision, there's no change in Dell engaging with the Trump administration and governments around the world.\"\n\nSeveral executives from top U.S. companies have stepped down from a number of presidential advisory councils in protest to Trump policies.\n\nTesla Inc CEO Elon Musk and Walt Disney Co CEO Robert Iger left the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, a business advisory group, in June, after Trump said he would withdraw from the Paris climate accord. Musk also left the manufacturing council.\n\nFormer Uber Technologies Inc CEO Travis Kalanick quit the business advisory council in February amid pressure from activists and employees who opposed the administration's immigration policies.\n\nThe White House said Sunday that Trump's remarks condemning violence at a white nationalist rally were meant to include the Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazi groups.\n\nDemocrats and Republicans criticized Trump for waiting too long to address the violence - his first major domestic crisis as president - and for failing when he did speak out to explicitly condemn white-supremacist marchers who ignited the melee.\n\nTrump on Saturday initially denounced what he called \"this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides.\"\n\nOn Sunday, however, the White House added: \"The president said very strongly in his statement yesterday that he condemns all forms of violence, bigotry, and hatred, and of course that includes white supremacists, KKK, neo-Nazi, and all extremist groups. He called for national unity and bringing all Americans together.\"\n\n(Reporting by Michael Erman; Editing by Nick Zieminski)", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "time": "17:19:00", Frazier's resignation from the group -- the latest CEO to quit one of Trump's high-profile executive advisory groups -- comes after a weekend of violent clashes in Charlottesville, Virginia, following Mr Musk also left the manufacturing council.\n\nFormer Uber Technologies CEO Travis Kalanick quit the business advisory council in February amid pressure from activists and employees who opposed the administration's immigration policies.\n\nThe White House said yesterday that Mr Trump's remarks condemning violence at a white nationalist rally were meant to include the Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazi groups.\n\nDemocrats and Republicans criticised Mr Trump for waiting too long to address the violence - his first major domestic crisis as president - and for failing when he did speak out to explicitly condemn white-supremacist marchers who ignited the melee.\n\nMr Trump on Saturday initially denounced what he called \"this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides.\"\n\nYesterday, however, the White House added: \"The president said very strongly in his statement yesterday that he condemns all forms of violence, bigotry, and hatred, and of course that includes white supremacists, KKK, neo-Nazi, and all extremist groups. violence over the weekend at a white nationalist rally in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\n\"I am appreciative of the opportunity to have served, but have decided to step down from the council,\" Plank diversity and inclusion.\"\n\nHis move comes hours after Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier, one of the country's most prominent black corporate executives, quit the council over Trump's initial failure to condemn white supremacists.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy,\" Frazier said. \"As CEO of Merck and as a {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T13:46:00Z", "url": "http://news.trust.org/item/20170814134142-jg6d5/", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Aug 14 (Reuters) - Merck & Co Inc Chief Executive Kenneth Frazier resigned from U.S. President Donald Trump's American Manufacturing Council on Monday, saying he was taking a stand against intolerance and extremism.\n\nA gathering of hundreds of white nationalists in Virginia took a deadly turn on Saturday when a car plowed into a group of counter-protesters and killed at least one person.\n\nTrump had said \"many sides\" were involved, drawing fire from across the political spectrum for not specifically denouncing the far right.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier, who is African-American, said in a statement announcing his resignation. (http://bit.ly/2fFnITM)\n\n\"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism,\" he said.\n\nTrump responded in a tweet, now that \"Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nSeveral executives from top U.S. companies have stepped down from a number of presidential advisory councils in protest to Trump policies.\n\nTesla Inc CEO Elon Musk and Walt Disney Co CEO Robert Iger left the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, a business advisory group, in June, after Trump said he would withdraw from the Paris climate accord. Musk also left the manufacturing council.\n\nFormer Uber Technologies Inc CEO Travis Kalanick quit the business advisory council in February amid pressure from activists and employees who opposed the administration's immigration policies.\n\nThe White House said Sunday that Trump's remarks condemning violence at a white nationalist rally were meant to include the Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazi groups.\n\nDemocrats and Republicans criticized Trump for waiting too long to address the violence - his first major domestic crisis as president - and for failing when he did speak out to explicitly condemn white-supremacist marchers who ignited the melee.\n\nTrump on Saturday initially denounced what he called \"this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides.\"\n\nOn Sunday, however, the White House added: \"The president said very strongly in his statement yesterday that he condemns all forms of violence, bigotry, and hatred, and of course that includes white supremacists, KKK, neo-Nazi, and all extremist groups. He called for national unity and bringing all Americans together.\"\n\n(Reporting by Michael Erman in New York and Natalie Grover in Bengaluru; Editing by Maju Samuel and Nick Zieminski)", "location": Mr Musk also left the manufacturing council.\n\nFormer Uber Technologies Inc CEO Travis Kalanick quit the business advisory council in February amid pressure from activists and employees who opposed Frazier resigned from the President's American Manufacturing Council citing \"a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nNEW YORK >> The CEO of the nation's third largest pharmaceutical company resigned from a manufacturing council that advises President Donald Trump days after racially tinged clashes in Charlottesville, Virginia, citing \"a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nTrump, who is under increasing pressure to explicitly condemn the white supremacist and hate groups involved, lashed out almost immediately today at Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier on Twitter, saying that because of the resignation, the pharmaceutical executive \"will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nDrugmakers have come under closer scrutiny because of rising drug prices, though Merck has not been one of the companies targeted by lawmakers or watchdog groups.\n\nFrazier, who is African American, said in a tweet today that the country's leaders must \"honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy.\"\n\nOne person was killed in the protests after a car slammed into a crowd and multiple people were injured in that incident and in running clashes between white supremacists and those opposing them.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned from a White House advisory council for the same reason.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T16:54:00Z", "url": "http://www.msn.com/en-us/money/companies/merck-ceo-resigns-from-trump-council-after-charlottesville/ar-AAq3K0y?srcref=rss", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Merck & Co Inc Chief Executive Kenneth Frazier resigned from U.S. President Donald Trump's American Manufacturing Council on Monday, saying he was taking a stand against intolerance and extremism.\n\nA gathering of hundreds of white nationalists in Virginia took a deadly turn on Saturday when a car plowed into a group of counter-protesters and killed at least one person.\n\nTrump had said \"many sides\" were involved, drawing fire from across the political spectrum for not specifically denouncing the far right.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier, who is African-American, said in a statement announcing his resignation.\n\n\"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism,\" he said.\n\nTrump responded in a tweet, now that \"Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nSeveral executives from top U.S. companies have stepped down from a number of presidential advisory councils in protest to Trump policies.\n\nTesla Inc CEO Elon Musk and Walt Disney Co CEO Robert Iger left the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, a business advisory group, in June, after Trump said he would withdraw from the Paris climate accord. Musk also left the manufacturing council.\n\nFormer Uber Technologies Inc CEO Travis Kalanick quit the business advisory council in February amid pressure from activists and employees who opposed the administration's immigration policies.\n\nThe White House said Sunday that Trump's remarks condemning violence at a white nationalist rally were meant to include the Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazi groups.\n\nDemocrats and Republicans criticized Trump for waiting too long to address the violence - his first major domestic crisis as president - and for failing when he did speak out to explicitly condemn white-supremacist marchers who ignited the melee.\n\nTrump on Saturday initially denounced what he called \"this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides.\"\n\nOn Sunday, however, the White House added: \"The president said very strongly in his statement yesterday that he condemns all forms of violence, bigotry, and hatred, and of course that includes white supremacists, KKK, neo-Nazi, and all extremist groups. He called for national unity and bringing all Americans together.\"\n\nReporting by Michael Erman in New York and Natalie Grover in Bengaluru; Editing by Maju Samuel and Nick Zieminski", "location": Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 14, 2017\n\nThe White House came under fire after Trump refused to explicitly condemn white supremacists for their role in a violent protest Saturday in the southern state of Virginia.\n\nLater Monday Trump issued an explicit condemnation.\n\nA woman died and 19 people were injured in the city of Charlottesville when a car plowed into a crowd of people after a rally by Ku Klux Klan members and other white nationalists turned violent. Two state police officers died in a helicopter crash near the area.\n\nWhite nationalists, neo-Nazis and members of the \"alt-right\" are confronted by protesters as they march down East Market Street toward Lee Park during the \"Unite the Right\" rally August 12, 2017 in Charlottesville, Virginia. Several top officials, including Vice President Mike Pence and White House adviser Ivanka Trump, have spoken forcefully against hate groups.\n\nBut Trump, whose presidential campaign was championed by {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T11:17:00Z", "url": "http://www.bnn.ca/merck-ceo-resigns-from-trump-s-manufacturing-council-1.829565", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Merck & Co Inc (MRK.N) Chief Executive Kenneth Frazier resigned from U.S. President Donald Trump's American Manufacturing Council on Monday, saying he was taking a stand against intolerance and extremism.\n\nFrazier, who is African-American, is the only CEO so far to leave one of Trump's advisory councils because of his reaction to the violence in Virginia. Prominent Democrats and Republicans criticized Trump's response to the violence over the weekend.\n\nA gathering of hundreds of white nationalists in Virginia took a deadly turn on Saturday when a car plowed into a group of counter-protesters and killed at least one person.\n\nTrump had said \"many sides\" were involved, drawing fire from across the political spectrum for not specifically denouncing the far right.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier said in a statement announcing his resignation.\n\n\"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism,\" he said.\n\nTrump responded in a tweet, saying now that \"Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nMerck shares rose 0.8 per cent in morning trading on the New York Stock Exchange, in line with the wider market.\n\nOther top business leaders also spoke out in reaction to the violence in Charlottesville.\n\n\"Lincoln: 'A house divided against itself cannot stand.' Isolate those who try to separate us. No equivalence w/ those who bring us together,\" Goldman Sachs CEO Lloyd Blankfein tweeted on Monday morning.\n\nSeveral executives from top U.S. companies have stepped down from a number of presidential advisory councils in protest to Trump policies.\n\nTesla Inc CEO Elon Musk and Walt Disney Co CEO Robert Iger left the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, a business advisory group, in June, after Trump said he would withdraw from the Paris climate accord. Musk also left the manufacturing council.\n\nFormer Uber Technologies Inc CEO Travis Kalanick quit the business advisory council in February amid pressure from activists and employees who opposed the administration's immigration policies.\n\nThe White House said Sunday that Trump's remarks condemning violence at a white nationalist rally were meant to include the Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazi groups.\n\nDemocrats and Republicans criticized Trump for waiting too long to address the violence - his first major domestic crisis as president - and for failing when he did speak out to explicitly condemn white-supremacist marchers who ignited the melee.\n\nTrump on Saturday initially denounced what he called \"this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides.\"\n\nOn Sunday, however, the White House added: \"The president said very strongly in his statement yesterday that he condemns all forms of violence, bigotry, and hatred, and of course that includes white supremacists, KKK, neo-Nazi, and all extremist groups. He called for national unity and bringing all Americans together.\"", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "time": "11:17:00", "originalArticle": null, "details": {}, "timeCrawl": "19:45:00", {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T14:44:00Z", "url": "http://www.khou.com/news/nation-world/mercks-ceo-quits-trumps-council-over-charlottesville/464226294", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN GOOGLE+ PINTEREST\n\nMerck CEO Ken Frazier quit President Trump's manufacturing business council on Monday, citing disatisfaction with Trump's lackluster response to violence that erupted after a neo-Nazi rally in Charlottesville over the weekend.\n\nThe resignation prompted an angry response from Trump on Twitter. \"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council,he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!,\" Trump tweeted.\n\npic.twitter.com/a1PNQZism5 -- Merck (@Merck)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nNow that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council,he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES! -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\n\"Our country's strength stems from its diversity and the contributions made by men and women of different faiths, races, sexual orientations and political beliefs,\" Frazier tweeted.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier said. \"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nThis isn't the first time Trump has clashed this year with high-profile CEOs over his handling of policy matters. In June, Disney CEO Robert Iger and Tesla CEO Elon Musk quit another White House business advisory council over Trump's decision to withdraw the U.S. from a global climate-change treaty, called the Paris Agreement.\n\nIn February, former UBER CEO Travis Kalanick also quit advising Trump on business matters over the president's proposal to ban travel from seven Muslim countries. Trump has come under fire over the weekend for his refusal to specifically denounce neo-Nazis, KKK and other racists groups after their rally in Charlottesville resulted in at least three people killed and dozens more hurt.\n\nHis initial response, issued on Twitter, called for \"all\" to be united and \"condemn all that hate stands for.\"\n\nMany lawmakers -- including some Republicans -- considered his response to be inadequate given the tragedy and national outrage. Some of Trump's political opponents called it a \"dog whistle\" to his far-right voter bloc supporters.\n\nWe ALL must be united & condemn all that hate stands for. There is no place for this kind of violence in America. Lets come together as one! -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 12, 2017\n\nFrazier, who in the past has donated to both Republicans and Democrats, sat beside Trump in February when the president had a roundtable discussion with pharmaceutical company executives.\n\nTrump urged the companies to lower their prices, but he also promised they would benefit from relaxed federal regulations, better trade deals and tax reform. He stopped short of repeating a campaign promise to have Medicare negotiate for drug discounts with manufacturers.\n\nFrazier also represented Merck at a White House event in July where his company and Pfizer announced an agreement with Corning to develop a new generation of stronger glass vials and an investment in manufacturing jobs.\n\nFrazier declined to comment further.\n\n\u00a9 2017
