{"dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "storyUri": "eng-3361963", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-15T01:28:00Z", "url": "https://www.sbnation.com/2017/8/14/16147302/kevin-plank-trump-white-house-council-manufacturing", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "The president has been a problem for Under Armour and its CEO, Kevin Plank, since February.\n\nUnder Armour CEO Kevin Plank is leaving President Donald Trump's American Manufacturing Council, his company announced Monday. The decision comes hours after the CEO of pharmaceutical giant Merck announced he'd do the same.\n\nWhen Merck's boss, Kenneth C. Frazier, announced he'd leave the White House's council, he said it was a \"matter of personal conscience\" to \"take a stance against intolerance and extremism.\" Plank didn't explicitly reference the white supremacist-driven violence in Charlottesville, Va., last weekend, or President Trump's decision not to immediately single out those racists for blame.\n\nShortly after the president took office, Plank joined his White House Manufacturing Jobs Initiative in an advisory role. Plank appeared on CNBC and said Trump would be a \"real asset\" to the United States and hailed him for being friendly to business:\n\n\"He wants to build things. He wants to make bold decisions and be really decisive,\" Plank said, alluding to Trump's desire to bolster American manufacturing and his plans to build a wall along the US-Mexico border and pass a large infrastructure improvement bill.\n\n\"I'm a big fan of people that operate in the world of 'publish and iterate' versus 'think, think, think, think, think,'\" Plank said. \"So there's a lot that I respect there.\"\n\nPlank's praise of Trump didn't play well at home.\n\nPlank is a former football player at the University of Maryland. He started his business there and still runs it in Maryland today. Under Armour is headquartered in Baltimore, a deeply Democratic city in a solidly Democratic state. Hillary Clinton won 60 percent of the vote statewide, and she trounced Trump in Baltimore County and City. The president isn't popular there or in any of the big cities in that part of the country.\n\nUnder Armour is a national business, and how the CEO's political views gel with his home state's aren't everything on their own. But Under Armour has a big business presence in the state and works closely with state and local government.\n\nSome of Under Armour's biggest stars publicly broke with the guy who writes their endorsement checks. Stephen Curry agreed Trump was an asset -- if you removed the last two letters from the word \"asset.\" Dwayne Johnson said Plank lacked perspective. Misty Copeland said she \"strongly disagreed.\" Much of the apparel-buying public did, too, which is part of the risk when an executive speaks up about a polarizing politician.\n\nPlank took out a full-page open letter in the Baltimore Sun, where he backed off some of his Trump praise, which he said \"did not accurately reflect my intent.\" He expressed opposition to Trump's proposed (and since partially enacted) travel ban on visitors from some Muslim-majority countries, because it might affect his workforce.\n\n\"We stand firmly for equal rights,\" Plank's letter read. \"Through our investment, hiring and in everything we do, we expect to be leaders in the advancement of all forms of diversity and gender.\"\n\nAfter protesting in Charlottesville turned violent, Trump initially blamed \"many sides\" for the outbreak, declining to specifically condemn white supremacists. He read a speech on Monday, two days after the fighting, that singled them out.\n\nBut both times, Plank's comments have been measured.\n\nJust as looking too close to Trump isn't good, Plank and his communications team likely don't want to look too opposed, either. You don't need to look beyond Trump's Twitter account on Monday to see why.\n\nUnder Armour doesn't want to look too cozy with an unpopular president who's widely reviled in the state where the company is headquartered. But if Trump were to start tweeting about Nike's superiority to his brand, Plank might not like that, either. Not appearing offensive to customers who support or oppose him is a hard balance.\n\nDespite Trump's Twitter tirade against Merck, the company's stock finished Monday slightly more valuable than it started it. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T14:21:00Z", "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4789308/index.html", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "NEW YORK (AP) - The CEO of the nation's third largest pharmaceutical company resigned from a manufacturing council that advises President Donald Trump days after racially tinged clashes in Charlottesville, Virginia, citing \"a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nTrump, who is under increasing pressure to explicitly condemn the white supremacist and hate groups involved, lashed out almost immediately Monday at Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier on Twitter, saying that because of the resignation, the pharmaceutical executive \"will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nDrugmakers have come under closer scrutiny because of rising drug prices, though Merck has not been one of the companies targeted by lawmakers or watchdog groups.\n\nFILE - In this Thursday, Feb. 23, 2017, file photo, President Donald Trump, left, speaks during a meeting with manufacturing executives at the White House in Washington, including Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier, center, and Ford CEO Mark Fields. Frazier is resigning from the President's American Manufacturing Council citing \"a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\" Frazier's resignation comes shortly after a violent confrontation between white supremacists and protesters in Charlottesville, Va. Trump is being criticized for not explicitly condemning the white nationalists who marched in Charlottesville. (AP Photo/Evan Vucci, File)\n\nFrazier, who is African American, said in a tweet on Monday that the country's leaders must \"honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy.\"\n\nOne person was killed in the protests after a car slammed into a crowd and multiple people were injured in that incident and in in running clashes between white supremacists those opposing them.\n\nOther executives who agreed to serve on councils advising the president have already resigned, citing separate stances taken by the Trump administration.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned from a White House advisory council for the same reason.\n\nFILE - In this Sunday, Sept. 27, 2015, file photo, Merck Chairman and CEO Kenneth Frazier participates in a session \"The Future of Impact,\" at the Clinton Global Initiative in New York. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T19:34:00Z", "url": "http://www.the-star.co.ke/news/2017/08/14/merck-ceo-resigns-from-trump-council-over-charlottesville_c1616719", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Merck & Co Inc Chief Executive Kenneth Frazier resigned from US President Donald Trump's American Manufacturing Council on Monday.\n\nHe said he was taking a stand against intolerance and extremism.\n\nTrump denounced neo-Nazis and the Ku Klux Klan as criminals and thugs on Monday, bowing to mounting political pressure after initially saying many sides were to blame after a white-nationalist rally turned deadly in Virginia.\n\nFrazier, who is African-American, is the only CEO so far to leave one of Trump's advisory councils because of his reaction to the violence in Virginia. Prominent Democrats and Republicans criticized Trump's response to the violence over the weekend.\n\nThe gathering of hundreds of white nationalists took a deadly turn on Saturday when a car plowed into a group of counter-protesters and killed at least one person.\n\nTrump had said \"many sides\" were involved, drawing fire from across the political spectrum for not specifically denouncing the far right.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier said in a statement announcing his resignation.\n\n\"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism,\" he said.\n\nTrump responded in a tweet, saying now that \"Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nThe son of a janitor, Frazier joined Merck as general counsel of one of the drugmaker's subsidiaries in 1992, working his way up to CEO of the company in 2011.\n\nHe made his name as the company's top lawyer, steering it through daunting litigation over Vioxx, its widely used painkiller that was withdrawn in 2004 after being linked to heart attacks.\n\nMany observers thought Merck would eventually have to shell out $10 billion or more to thousands of plaintiffs over the drug's withdrawal.\n\nBut Frazier's legal strategy led to a $4.85-billion settlement in 2007, allowing Merck to refocus on its pipeline of experimental medicines.\n\nMerck shares rose 0.5 percent in afternoon trading on the New York Stock Exchange, roughly in line with the wider market.\n\nFrazier frequently made political contributions during the 2016 election, donating to both Republican and Democratic members of Congress but no donations to a presidential candidate during the year.\n\nThe political PAC maintained by Merck and funded through donations from Merck employees made over $1.1 million in candidate contributions during the 2016 campaign - but did not contribute to Trump or his Democratic rival Hillary Clinton, according to documents filed with the Federal Elections Commission.\n\nThe Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, which represents the pharmaceutical industry and lobbies on its behalf in Congress, declined to offer a statement of support for Frazier or to comment on Trump's reaction.\n\nThe industry's silence comes as Trump is finalizing an executive order on drug prices that would relax industry regulation and contains measures that, some say, would protect existing drug prices or even increase them.\n\nIndividually, at least one CEO, John Maraganore of Alnylam Pharmaceuticals, tweeted his support, saying he was \"proud to stand with leaders like Ken Frazier.\"\n\nOther top business leaders also spoke out in response to the violence in Charlottesville.\n\n\"I support Ken Frazier's decision. I'm thankful we have business leaders such as Ken to remind America of its better angels,\" said Hewlett Packard Enterprises CEO Meg Whitman, who ran for governor of California as a Republican in 2010.\n\nGoldman Sachs CEO Lloyd Blankfein tweeted: \"Lincoln: 'A house divided against itself cannot stand.' Isolate those who try to separate us. No equivalence w/ those who bring us together.\"\n\nSeveral executives from top U.S. companies have previously stepped down from a number of presidential advisory councils in protest to Trump policies.\n\nTesla Inc CEO Elon Musk and Walt Disney Co CEO Robert Iger left the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, a business advisory group, in June, after Trump said he would withdraw from the Paris climate accord. Musk also left the manufacturing council.\n\nFormer Uber Technologies Inc CEO Travis Kalanick quit the business advisory council in February amid pressure from activists and employees who opposed the administration's immigration policies.\n\nThe White House said Sunday that Trump's remarks condemning violence at a white nationalist rally were meant to include the Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazi groups.\n\nDemocrats and Republicans criticized Trump for waiting too long to address the violence - his first major domestic crisis as president - and for failing when he did speak out to explicitly condemn white-supremacist marchers who ignited the melee.\n\nTrump on Saturday initially denounced what he called \"this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides.\"\n\nOn Sunday, however, the White House added: \"The president said very strongly in his statement yesterday that he condemns all forms of violence, bigotry, and hatred, and of course that includes white supremacists, KKK, neo-Nazi, and all extremist groups. He called for national unity and bringing all Americans together.\"", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "time": "19:34:00", "originalArticle": null, "details": {}, "timeCrawl": "19:34:00", Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nTrump, who is under increasing pressure to explicitly condemn the white supremacist and hate groups involved, lashed out almost immediately Monday at Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier on Twitter, saying that because of the resignation, the pharmaceutical executive \"will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nDrugmakers have come under closer scrutiny because of rising drug prices, though Merck has not been one of the companies targeted by lawmakers or watchdog groups.\n\nFrazier, who is African American, said in a tweet on Monday that the country's leaders must \"honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy.\"\n\nOne person was killed in the protests after a car slammed into a crowd and multiple people were injured in that incident and in running clashes between white supremacists and those opposing them.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned from a White House advisory council for the same reason.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier this year as executives retire, are replaced, or, as with Frazier, Musk and Iger, resign.\n\nBusiness Briefing from St. Louis Post-Dispatch\n\nMake it your business. Musk also left the manufacturing council.\n\nFormer Uber Technologies Inc CEO Travis Kalanick quit the business advisory council in February amid pressure from activists and employees who opposed the {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T15:13:00Z", "url": "http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/breaking-news/merck-ceo-resigns-from-trump-council/news-story/944965cd17e7966271772a33d3bc3a6e", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Merck & Co chief executive Kenneth Frazier has resigned from US President Donald Trump's American Manufacturing Council, saying he was taking a stand against intolerance and extremism.\n\nFrazier, who is African-American, is the only CEO so far to leave one of Trump's advisory councils because of his reaction to the violence in Virginia. Prominent Democrats and Republicans criticised Trump's response to the violence over the weekend.\n\nA gathering of hundreds of white nationalists in Virginia took a deadly turn on Saturday when a car ploughed into a group of counter-protesters and killed at least one person.\n\nTrump had said \"many sides\" were involved, drawing fire from across the political spectrum for not specifically denouncing the far right.\n\n\"America's leaders must honour our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier said in a statement announcing his resignation.\n\nTrump responded in a tweet, saying now that \"Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nMerck shares rose 0.8 per cent in morning trading on the New York Stock Exchange, in line with the wider market.\n\nOther top business leaders also spoke out in reaction to the violence in Charlottesville.\n\n\"Lincoln: 'A house divided against itself cannot stand.' Isolate those who try to separate us. No equivalence w/ those who bring us together,\" Goldman Sachs CEO Lloyd Blankfein tweeted on Monday morning.\n\nSeveral executives from top US companies have stepped down from a number of presidential advisory councils in protest over Trump policies.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk and Walt Disney CEO Robert Iger left the president's Strategic and Policy Forum, a business advisory group, in June, after Trump said he would withdraw from the Paris climate accord. Musk also left the manufacturing council.\n\nFormer Uber Technologies CEO Travis Kalanick quit the business advisory council in February amid pressure from activists and employees who opposed the administration's immigration policies.\n\nThe White House said on Sunday that Trump's remarks condemning violence at a white nationalist rally were meant to include the Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazi groups.\n\nDemocrats and Republicans criticised Trump for waiting too long to address the violence - his first major domestic crisis as president - and for failing when he did speak out to explicitly {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-15T01:21:00Z", "url": "http://www.fox35orlando.com/news/politics/273721130-story", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "WASHINGTON - TRENTON, N.J. (AP) -- President Donald Trump lashed out at the CEO of the nation's third-largest pharmaceutical company after he resigned from a federal advisory council, citing the president's failure to explicitly rebuke the white nationalists who marched in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nMerck CEO Kenneth Frazier wrote on Twitter Monday that \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which runs counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nFrazier is one of the few African Americans to head a Fortune 500 company.\n\nRELATED: 1 dead, 35 injured after vehicle plows into counter-protesters at white nationalist rally\n\nTrump is under increasing pressure to call out the white supremacist and hate groups involved. He lashed out almost immediately on Monday following the resignation, saying on Twitter that Frazier will now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nNow that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council,he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES! -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nDrugmakers have come under withering criticism for soaring prices in the U.S., including by Trump, though he has yet to act on a promise to contain them.\n\nWith the barb, Trump appeared to attack an industry executive who has tried to make drug pricing somewhat more transparent by revealing his company's overall drug price changes.\n\nRELATED: Racist website 'Daily Stormer' calls Trump's comments 'good, really, really good'\n\nIn January, Merck reported that its average net prices -- the amount the company receives after discounts and other rebates -- increased in the years since 2010 in a range between 3.4 percent and 6.2 percent per year. That's about half as large as the increase in its retail prices. Much of the furor over drug prices recently has been over increases that have been far bigger and come one after another for drugs that have been on the market for years.\n\nThe exchange lit up social media early on Monday, with many people lauding Frazier and blasting the president. Trump eventually made a statement condemning bigotry Monday afternoon at a press conference.\n\nMeanwhile, other executives stated their support for Frazier.\n\nUnilever CEO Paul Polman wrote on Twitter, \"Thanks @Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is.\"\n\nFrazier, who grew up in a poor neighborhood in Philadelphia, resigned days after one person was killed and others wounded in violent clashes between white supremacists and protesters.\n\nFrazier and his siblings were raised by their janitor father after their mother died when he was very young. He has earned a reputation as a risk taker in the drug industry, pouring money into daunting research areas, particularly trying to develop a treatment for Alzheimer's disease.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned for the same reason from the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, which Trump established to advise him on how government policy impacts economic growth and job creation.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier this year as executives retire, are replaced, or, as with Frazier and Musk, resign.\n\nWilliam Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said he couldn't \"think of a parallel example\" of any president responding as viciously as Trump to a CEO departing an advisory council.\n\n\"Usually, certain niceties are observed to smooth over a rupture,\" said Galston, who served as a domestic policy aide in the Clinton administration.\n\n\"We've learned that as president, Mr. Trump is behaving exactly as he did as a candidate,\" Galston said. \"He knows only one mode: When attacked, hit back harder.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Economics Writer Josh Boak in Washington contributed to this story.\n\n___\n\nFollow Linda A. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T14:41:00Z", "url": "http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/08/14/ceo-major-pharmaceutical-firm-quits-white-house-council-protest/", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "The chief executive of one of the world's largest pharmaceutical companies has resigned from President Donald Trump's manufacturing council in protest at his failure to condemn a white supremacist rally.\n\nKenneth Frazier, CEO of Merck, became just the latest business leader to resign in protest against the president's policies, following announcements earlier this year that the heads of Uber, Disney and Tesla that they could no longer support Mr Trump's administration.\n\nMr Frazier said he was stepping down to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\n\nMr Trump is yet to condemn the white supremacists who organised Saturday's rally in Charlotteville, in which a car ploughed into a group of protesters, killing Heather Heyer. Two police officers also died in a separate crash.\n\nInstead of disassociating himself from the neo-Nazi organisers, Mr Trump said \"many sides\" were involved, drawing fire from across the political spectrum for not specifically denouncing the far right.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" said Mr Frazier, in a tweet announcing his resignation on Monday morning.\n\npic.twitter.com/a1PNQZism5 -- Merck (@Merck)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nMr Trump responded on Twitter: \"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nNow that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council,he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES! -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nThe manufacturing council was announced on January 27 as a way of brainstorming the best solutions to America's manufacturing problems.\n\nMr Frazier, the only African American on the council, appeared at the White House last month to promote an agreement between Merck, Pfizer and Corning to create 1,000 jobs.\n\nAt the group's first meeting in January, Mr Trump shook Mr Frazier's hand after the CEO talked up efforts to bring manufacturing jobs back to the US for a cancer drug.\n\n\"That's very good,\" said Mr Trump at the time.\n\nBut business leaders have found themselves facing criticism from employees over any White House role.\n\nThe CEO of Disney, Bob Iger, left the advisory council in protest at the Paris agreement, and Travis Kalanick, former CEO of Uber, dropped out after customers and employees complained about Mr Trump's travel ban.\n\nElon Musk, who quit at the same time as Mr Iger, initially resisted pressure to leave the White House Strategy and Policy Forum, saying he planned to express his objections to Mr Trump's immigration policy, but keep his seat at the table.\n\nThe Paris decision made him change his mind, however.\n\nMr Trump is expected to speak to the press later on Monday, at which he is likely to address the Charlottesville rally. He has come under pressure from all sides to issue a strong condemnation of white supremacists - following the lead of his daughter, Ivanka, and Mike Pence, the vice president.\n\nSenior Republicans {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T13:59:00Z", "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4789270/index.html", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "President Donald Trump appeared with Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier at a White House event in July.\n\nPresident Donald Trump lambasted Merck's CEO Monday after the African-American pharmaceutical executive resigned from a White House advisory council, citing Trump's controversial response to a violent white supremacist rally.\n\nMerck chief executive Kenneth Frazier, alluding to Trump's much-criticized response to a deadly weekend white supremacist protest, said he was exiting Trump's American Manufacturing Council.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all men are created equal,\" Frazier wrote on Twitter.\n\n\"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nTrump, also on Twitter, responded about an hour later.\n\n\"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\" the US president said.\n\nThe White House came under fire after Trump refused to explicitly condemn white supremacists for their role in a violent protest Saturday in the southern state of Virginia.\n\nA woman died and 19 people were injured in the city of Charlottesville when a car plowed into a crowd of people after a rally by Ku Klux Klan members and other white nationalists turned violent. Two state police officers died in a helicopter crash near the area.\n\nIn an appearance Saturday at his golf resort in Bedminster, New Jersey, Trump faulted \"many sides\" for the violence. He made no mention of the far-right militia groups involved in the Charlottesville melee, some of whom were wearing Trump hats or T-shirts.\n\nWhite House officials have since made explicit they oppose bigotry and white supremacy. Several top officials, including Vice President Mike Pence and White House advisor Ivanka Trump, have spoken forcefully against hate groups.\n\nBut Trump, whose presidential campaign was championed by {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "storyUri": "eng-3361963", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-15T01:21:00Z", "url": "http://www.capitalgazette.com/news/business/bs-bz-kevin-plank-charlottesville-trump-20170814-story.html", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Under Armour founder Kevin Plank became the second CEO to resign from President Donald J. Trump's advisory jobs panel on Monday after the president was widely criticized\n\nPlank's statement, issued Monday night,\n\n, saying the company did not want to focus on \"politics.\"\n\nPlank said he joined the American Manufacturing Council because he believed it was important for Under Armour to \"have an active seat at the table and represent our industry.\"\n\n\"However, Under Armour engages in innovation and sports, not politics,\" Plank said in a statement posted to Twitter. \"I love our country and our company and will continue to focus my efforts on inspiring every person that they can do anything through the power of sport which promotes unity, diversity and inclusion.\"\n\nEarlier Monday, Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier said he was leaving the manufacturing initiative, citing the president's failure to explicitly denounce those groups that marched in the rally.\n\n\"I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism,\" said Frazier, calling on America's leaders -- including Trump -- to clearly reject \"expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy.\"\n\nIn January, Frazier and Plank were named to the 28-member panel established by the White House to promote job growth.\n\nAppearing later Monday, Trump labeled members of the KKK, neo-Nazis and white supremacists who participate in violence as \"criminals and thugs.\"\n\nNineteen people were injured and a woman was killed when a car plowed into counter-protesters. Another dozen or so people were injured in clashes between white nationalists and counter-protesters and two state troopers were killed when their helicopter, which was monitoring the rally, crashed.\n\n\"We are saddened by #Charlottesville,\" Plank said on Under Armour's Twitter account. \"There is no place for racism or discrimination in this world. We choose love & unity.\"\n\nBy mid-afternoon on Monday, a few hundred people had responded to Plank's message on Twitter, many of them urging him to quit the advisory group.\n\n\"Please keep us loyal to your brand by resigning from Trump's board,\" wrote one.\n\nAnother tweeter, Charles H. Bryan of Gladwin, Mich., wrote to Plank: \"You're in a position to send a real message to President Trump. You should do so.\"\n\nIn response to a question from the Baltimore Sun, Bryan added that each of the company CEOs who are part of the advisory panel should withdraw \"as a show of solidarity\" with Frazier.\n\nThe social media debate echoed one Under Armour faced in February after Plank was asked about Trump during a televised interview. Plank, who has contributed in the past both to Republican and Democratic elected officials in federal and state posts, told CNBC that having \"such a pro-business president is something that's a real asset to this country.\"\n\nA number of celebrity Under Armour endorsers -- including basketball star Stephen Curry and ballerina Misty Copeland -- released statements saying they did not agree with Plank's assessment.\n\n\"We engage in policy, not politics,\" Under Armour said at the time.\n\nTrump was quick to rebuke Frazier on Monday, lashing out on Twitter that the pharmaceuticals company CEO will now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nWith the barb, Trump appeared to attack an industry executive who has tried to make drug pricing somewhat more transparent by revealing his company's overall drug price changes.\n\nFrazier is one of the few African-Americans to head a Fortune 500 company.\n\nOthers on the White House manufacturing council include top executives from Boeing, Dell Technologies, Dow Chemical and Johnson & Johnson.\n\nLike Plank, the other CEOs faced calls on social media Monday to resign, but none did.\n\nDow CEO Andrew Liveris issued a statement condemning the violence in Charlottesville and saying the company \"will continue to work to strengthen the social and economic fabric of the communities where it operates -- including supporting policies that help create employment opportunities in manufacturing and rebuild the American workforce.\"\n\nAnother panel member, Brian Krzanich of Intel, tweeted: \"There should be no hesitation in condemning hate speech or white supremacy by name.\"\n\nIn February, Uber CEO Travis Kalanick left the advisory group and said his participation had not meant that he favored the president's policies.\n\nElon Musk, CEO of SpaceX and Tesla, resigned from the council and two other presidential advisory groups in June after Trump vowed to exit the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned for the same reason from the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, which Trump established to advise him on how government policy impacts economic growth and job creation.\n\nWilliam Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said he couldn't \"think of a parallel example\" of any president responding as viciously as Trump did to a CEO departing an advisory council.\n\n\"Usually, certain niceties are observed to smooth over a rupture,\" said Galston, who served as a domestic policy aide in the Clinton administration.\n\n\"We've learned that as president, Mr. Trump is behaving exactly as he did as a candidate,\" Galston said. \"He knows only one mode: When attacked, hit back harder.\"\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\njebarker@baltsun.com\n\ntwitter.com/sunjeffbarker", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "time": "01:21:00", "originalArticle": null, "details": {}, "timeCrawl": "01:21:00", "title": {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T16:17:00Z", "url": "http://www.opposingviews.com/i/politics/trump-blasts-merck-ceo-stepping-down", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "A pharmaceutical CEO left President Donald Trump's manufacturing council after Trump's comments regarding the protests in Charlottesville, Virginia, on Aug. 12.\n\nKenneth C. Frazier, chief executive of Merck Pharmaceuticals, stepped down from the president's American Manufacturing Council, citing Trump's slow response to the white nationalist rally, which turned deadly, according to The New York Times.\n\nFrazier, who is black, issued a statement on the Merck Twitter account announcing his resignation from the president's council.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier wrote.\n\nTrump, who is still on vacation at his golf club in Bedminster, New Jersey, responded to Frazier's resignation with a tweet of his own.\n\n\"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES,\" Trump wrote.\n\nSeveral executives and other leaders offered their support for Frazier and his decision. Frazier is one of a few black CEOs of Fortune 500 companies and was personally invited to join Trump's newly minted council shortly after the president's inauguration, reports CNN Money.\n\nTrump also drew criticism for his decision to attack Frazier, considering the amount of blowback he received for his response to the neo-Nazi rally in Charlottesville. During the protests, a white nationalist allegedly drove a car into a group of counter-protesters, killing one and injuring at least 30.\n\nFrazier is only the second African American to head a major pharmaceutical firm, according to The New York Times.\n\n\"It took Trump 54 minutes to condemn Merck CEO Ken Frazier, but after several days he still has not condemned murdering white supremacists,\" said Keith Boykin, a former aide to former President Bill Clinton.\n\nTrump issued a further statement about the rallies in Virginia, making more specified rebukes about white supremacy and singling them out, reports the Los Angeles Times.\n\n\"Racism is evil and those who cause violence in its name are criminals and thugs, including the KKK, neo-Nazis, white supremacists and other hate groups that are repugnant to everything we hold dear as Americans,\" Trump said on Aug. 14.\n\nOther executives on the business council issued statements via Twitter denouncing racism and bigotry, but did not note if they were planning to resign.\n\nOther executives have left Trump's councils in the past, most of them after the president's decision to withdraw from the Paris climate accord, a multinational agreement, according to CNN Money. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T14:15:00Z", "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/on-leadership/wp/2017/08/14/trump-fires-back-after-the-ceo-of-merck-resigned-from-his-manufacturing-council/", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "President Trump speaks during a meeting with manufacturing executives at the White House in Washington, Thursday, Feb. 23, 2017. From left are, White House Senior Adviser Jared Kushner, Trump, Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier, and Ford CEO Mark Fields. (AP Photo/Evan Vucci)\n\nThe chief executive of Merck said Monday in a tweet that he was resigning from President Trump's American Manufacturing Council, saying he was doing so \"as CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience\" and that \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy.\"\n\nIn the statement, Kenneth C. Frazier, one of the few African American CEOs in the Fortune 500, said \"I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism\" and touted the power of diversity. \"Our country's strength stems from its diversity and the contributions made by men and women of different faiths, races, sexual orientations and political beliefs.\"\n\nWithin an hour after the statement was first issued, Trump tweeted his response. \"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\npic.twitter.com/a1PNQZism5\n\n-- Merck (@Merck) August 14, 2017\n\nNow that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council,he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\n\n-- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 14, 2017\n\nFrazier's resignation followed an outcry by critics about how President Trump had responded to protests in Charlottesville, Va. over the weekend that were led by white supremacist groups and turned violent. Many questioned why Trump had not explicitly named neo-Nazi, Ku Klux Klan or white nationalist groups when he said \"we condemn in the strongest possible terms this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides,\" repeating \"on many sides\" for emphasis.\n\n[Trump condemns Charlottesville violence but doesn't single out white nationalists]\n\nA spokesman for Merck said the company had no further comment about Frazier's decision, his tweet, or the president's response. An email to spokespersons for the White House was not immediately returned.\n\nOn Saturday afternoon, following the eruption of violence in Charlottesville that morning, Trump first made a general statement about the violence, tweeting that \"We ALL must be united & condemn all that hate stands for. There is no place for this kind of violence in America. Lets come together as one!\" Later Saturday, he read a statement that included his condemnation of \"hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides.\" Critics, including Republicans in his own party, said he should directly condemn the groups by name.\n\nMr. President - we must call evil by its name. These were white supremacists and this was domestic terrorism. https://t.co/PaPNiPPAoW\n\n-- Cory Gardner (@SenCoryGardner) August 12, 2017\n\nTrump's swift response -- and his willingness to go after an American CEO but not specifically name white supremacists in Charlottesville -- was noted by a number of observers Monday on social media.\n\nAdd Merck to list of groups/individuals that Trump has denounced more forcefully - by name - than the white nationalists in Charlottesville https://t.co/dGBYywq6fg\n\n-- Mark Murray (@mmurraypolitics) August 14, 2017\n\nLess than 1 hour after Frazier's announcement. Some events still get immediate response from president https://t.co/Ebal9r8Enk\n\n-- Dave Itzkoff (@ditzkoff) August 14, 2017\n\nFrazier is not the first corporate chieftain to resign in protest from one of the president's advisory councils. In June, following the president's announcement that he planned to withdraw from the Paris climate agreement, both Tesla CEO Elon Musk and Disney CEO Robert Iger resigned from White House advisory councils.\n\nLowering drug prices was a major campaign promise for Trump, and throughout the early part of the year, Trump made threatening and vague statements about the prices of drugs being too high. In the midst of one of the drug industry's biggest conferences in January, Trump accused the pharmaceutical industry of \"getting away with murder,\" fueling speculation that he might take action on drug prices that the industry has long fought -- such as allowing the government to bid on prices in the Medicare program.\n\nBut in the intervening months, industry leaders have grown increasingly confident that any governmental actions won't harm their business models. Pharmaceutical chief executives, including Frazier, met with Trump in January and came away from the meeting with the impression that they would not face a serious effort from the White House to lower drug prices through government negotiation on Medicare drug prices.\n\nKey leaders from across government have been meeting to discuss the issue of pricing, but based on leaked documents that have been circulating, including a potential draft executive order on drug pricing, Wall Street analysts have noted that some of the actions being proposed could actually help the pharmaceutical industry.\n\nCarolyn Johnson contributed to this report.\n\nRead also:\n\n'Climate change is real': CEOs share their disappointment over Trump's Paris accord exit\n\nLike On Leadership? Hundreds of white supremacists clashed with counter demonstrators as a car rammed into the crowd and a police helicopter crashed on Saturday, killing three people and injuring 19 others in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nTrump condemned the violence but said \"many sides\" were involved, inviting criticism from across the political spectrum for not specifically denouncing the far right. \"America's leaders must honour our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier said. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "storyUri": "eng-3361963", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-15T01:39:00Z", "url": "http://www.erienewsnow.com/story/36134746/under-armour-ceo-quits-trumps-manufacturing-council", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "NEW YORK (CNNMoney) -- Under Armour CEO Kevin Plank said Monday night that he's leaving President Trump's manufacturing council, the second departure by a high-profile business leader in the space of a day.\n\nPlank didn't give a clear reason for stepping down, but his announcement comes amid fierce criticism over Trump's response to violence over the weekend at a white nationalist rally in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\n\"I am appreciative of the opportunity to have served, but have decided to step down from the council,\" Plank said in a statement. \"I love our country and our company and will continue to focus my efforts on inspiring every person that they can do anything through the power of sport which promotes unity, diversity and inclusion.\"\n\nHis move comes hours after Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier, one of the country's most prominent black corporate executives, quit the council over Trump's initial failure to condemn white supremacists.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy,\" Frazier said. \"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nThat appeared to be a reference to Trump's statement over the weekend blaming violence \"on many sides\" after neo-Nazis and white nationalists clashed with counter-protesters in Charlottesville.\n\nTM & \u00a9 2017 Cable News Network, Inc., a Time Warner Company. Nineteen people were injured.\n\nMr Frazier added: \"Our country's strength stems from its diversity and the contributions made by men and women of different faiths, races, sexual orientations and political beliefs.\"\n\nNow that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council,he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nMinutes after the high-profile CEO's announcement, Trump attacked him on Twitter. He wrote: \"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nThe White House has since issued a statement, which said the president \"condemns all forms of violence, bigotry and hatred, and of course that includes white Supremacists, KKK, neo-nazi and all extremist groups.\"\n\nMr Frazier is the third business leader to quit the US leader's panel. Disney chairman Bob Iger and Elon Musk, chief executive of Tesla, both resigned in June after Trump announced he would withdraw the US from the Paris climate agreement.", "location": null, Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nThe White House came under fire after Trump refused to explicitly condemn white supremacists for their role in a violent protest Saturday in the southern state of Virginia.\n\nA woman died and 19 people were injured in the city of Charlottesville when a car ploughed into a crowd of people after a rally by Ku Klux Klan members and other white nationalists turned violent. Two state police officers died in a helicopter crash near the area.\n\nREAD: Driver accused of murder in Charlottesville violence due in court\n\nIn an appearance on Saturday at his golf resort in Bedminster, New Jersey, Trump faulted \"many sides\" for the violence. He made no mention of the far-right militia groups involved in the Charlottesville melee, some of whom were wearing Trump hats or T-shirts.\n\nWhite House officials have since made explicit they oppose bigotry and white supremacy. Several top officials, including Vice President Mike Pence and White House advisor Ivanka Trump, have spoken forcefully against hate groups.\n\n1:2 There should be no place in society for racism, And the move drew an immediate snarky retort from Trump via Twitter.\n\nWhite supremacists and neo-Nazis attended a white nationalist rally to protest the removal of a statue of Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee, but violence erupted and counter-protesters were beaten and bloodied, and one female counter-protester and two police officers were killed when a car driven by one of the far right protesters plowed into a crowd.\n\nTrump drew rebuke from both the left and the right for stressing that \"many sides\" were responsible for the violence, and not calling out the white supremacists directly.\n\nIn announcing his resignation, Frazier tweeted: \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nTrump responded immediately on Twitter, stating \"Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nNow that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council,he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\n\n-- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nTrump had specifically named Frazier in a tweet Monday morning, saying he will now have more time to \"lower ripoff drug prices.\"\n\nTrump's criticism of Merck and Frazier is a reversal. Just last month he called Frazier a \"business genius\" and \"one of the great, great leaders of business.\"\n\nFrazier announced Monday he would resign from the council \"as a matter of personal conscience\" following the violence this weekend in Charlottesville, where one person died and many more were injured in clashes between the white supremacists and counter protesters.\n\n\"Our country's strength stems from its diversity and the contributions made by men and women of different faiths, races, sexual orientations and political beliefs,\" Frazier said.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal. explicitly rebuking white supremacists in Charlottesville over the weekend.\n\nTrump eventually made a statement Monday afternoon in which he said that \"racism is evil\" and for the first time called {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T21:59:00Z", "url": "http://at.theaustralian.com.au/link/39c0332de766b9df3cddcabb4e3ace00?domain=theaustralian.com.au", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "President Donald Trump has lashed out at the chief executive of the nation's third-largest pharmaceutical company after he resigned from a federal advisory council, citing the president's failure to explicitly rebuke the white nationalists who marched in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nMerck CEO Kenneth Frazier wrote on Twitter on Monday that \"America's leaders must honour our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which runs counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal\".\n\nFrazier is one of the few African Americans to head a Fortune 500 company.\n\nTrump is under increasing pressure to call out the white supremacist and hate groups involved. He lashed out almost immediately on Monday following the resignation, saying on Twitter that Frazier will now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nDrugmakers have come under withering criticism for soaring prices in the US, including by Trump, though he has yet to act on a promise to contain them.\n\nWith the barb, Trump appeared to attack an industry executive who has tried to make drug pricing somewhat more transparent by revealing his company's overall drug price changes.\n\nIn January, Merck reported that its average net prices - the amount the company receives after discounts and other rebates - increased in the years since 2010 in a range between 3.4 per cent and 6.2 per cent per year. That's about half as large as the increase in its retail prices.\n\nMuch of the furore over drug prices recently has been over increases that have been far bigger and come one after another for drugs that have been on the market for years.\n\nThe exchange lit up social media early on Monday, with many people lauding Frazier and blasting the president. Trump eventually made a statement condemning bigotry Monday afternoon at a press conference.\n\nMeanwhile, other executives stated their support for Frazier.\n\nUnilever CEO Paul Polman wrote on Twitter, \"Thanks (at)Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is.\"\n\nFrazier, who grew up in a poor neighbourhood in Philadelphia, resigned days after one person was killed and others wounded in violent clashes between white supremacists and protesters.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the US withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned for the same reason from the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, which Trump established to advise him on how government policy impacts economic growth and job creation.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier this year as executives retire, are replaced, or, as with Frazier and {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "storyUri": "eng-3361963", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-15T01:51:00Z", "url": "http://www.kansascity.com/news/nation-world/national/article167224627.html", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Under Armour CEO Kevin Plank stepped down from his role on the American Manufacturing Council Monday in the wake of the deadly white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nPlank was the second CEO to resign from the council on Monday, but did not directly blame President Donald Trump's response to the rally for his decision.\n\n\"I joined the American Manufacturing Council because I believed it was important for Under Armour to have an active seat at the table and represent our industry,\" Plank said in a statement. \"However, Under Armor engages in innovation and sports, not politics.\"\n\nTrump was widely criticized for his lack of forceful response to a neo-Nazi rally held in Charlottesville over the weekend in protest of the removal of a Confederate statue from a park.\n\nPlank said he was appreciative of the opportunity to have served on the council but will now \"focus my efforts on inspiring every person that they can do anything through the power of sport which promotes unity, diversity and inclusion.\"\n\nEarlier Monday, Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier also stepped down from the manufacturing council. He too refrained from mentioning Trump by name in his statement, but the pharmaceutical executive was more explicit in the reason for his decision.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier, who is African American, said in a statement. \"As CEO of Merck, and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nShortly after Frazier's announcement, Trump personally attacked the CEO for stepping down.\n\nTrump on Saturday said violence was perpetrated \"on many sides,\" a response criticized by both Democrats and Republicans as an insufficient condemnation of white supremacists and hateful ideology. On Sunday, the White House issued an unattributed statement saying that \"of course\" Trump's initial comments on the situation condemned \"white supremacists, KKK Neo-Nazi and all extremist groups.\"\n\nThat statement did nothing to quell calls for a clear and unequivocal presidential condemnation of the white supremacists in Charlottesville, some of whom support Trump. On Monday, the president told media gathered at the White House ahead of an economic event that \"racism is evil.\"\n\n\"And those who cause violence in its name are criminals and thugs, including the KKK, neo-Nazis, white supremacists, and other hate groups that are repugnant to everything we hold dear as Americans,\" Trump said.\n\nHe later criticized the media response on Twitter.", "location": {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T13:59:00Z", "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4789118/index.html", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "The only black member of President Trump's American Manufacturing Council quit on Monday over the president's response to the violence in Charlottesville, calling on American leaders to clearly reject 'expressions of hatred,bigotry and group supremacy.'\n\nKenneth Frazier, the CEO of the pharmaceutical giant Merck, bowed out of the board, saying it was a 'matter of personal conscience' that he take a 'stand against intolerance and extremism.'\n\nPresident Trump quickly hit back on Twitter, writing, 'Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council,he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!'\n\nScroll down for video\n\nMerck CEO Kenneth Frazier quit President Trump's American Manufacturing Council over President Trump's lackluster response to violence in Charlottesville caused by white supremacist groups\n\nPresident Trump quickly hit Frazier's decision on Twitter Monday, by suggesting Merck overcharged for its drugs\n\nPresident Trump (left) is photographed with Kenneth Frazier (right), the CEO of Merck in July, as the only black member of Trump's manufacturing council exited the group over the president's inability to call out white supremacists by name\n\nThe president is now facing a business backlash over his much-panned response to the violence that broke out Saturday in Charlottesville, in which one counter-protester - marching against hate groups gathered in the Virginia town - was killed.\n\nOn Saturday, Trump made a statement from his Bedminster resort in New Jersey saying, 'We condemn in the strongest possible terms this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides, on many sides.'\n\nCritics, including a handful of Congressional Republicans, suggested that Trump was falsely equating the neo-Nazis, KKK members and white supremacists protesting the removal of a statue of Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee with those marching against the hate groups.\n\nSince then, an unnamed spokesman for the White House has updated the statement to say 'of course that includes white supremacists, KKK, Neo-Nazi and all extremist groups.'\n\nBut Trump hasn't personally condemned the hate groups by name.\n\nKenneth Frazier (left), the CEO of Merck, was the only black member of President Trump's (right) American Manufacturing Council\n\nInstead, Trump spent his Sunday out of journalists' sights, not making public appearances and staying off Twitter throughout the day.\n\nAround 6 p.m. he finally retweeted several pieces of positive coverage, but made no mention of the Charlottesville violence again.\n\nOn Sunday night, Vice President Mike Pence defended Trump's response and by Monday morning Attorney General Jeff Sessions had also chimed in.\n\n'He made a very strong statement that directly contradicted the ideology of hatred, violence, bigotry, racism, white supremacy,' Session, during an appearance on the Today show, argued.\n\nBut that wasn't enough to sway Frazier, whose statement from the official Merck Twitter account quickly picked up steam.\n\n'I am resigning from the President's American Manufacturing Council,' he wrote.\n\n'Our country's strength stems from its diversity and the contributions by men and women of different faiths, races, sexual orientations and political beliefs,' Frazier said.\n\nFrazier's exit marks the fourth time a prominent CEO has walked away from one of Trump's White House boards.\n\nOn the heels of Trump exiting the Paris climate accord, Tesla CEO Elon Musk, also part of the American Manufacturing Council, threw in the towel. Disney CEO Bob Iger, who served on the president's Strategic and Policy Forum exited over Paris too.\n\nNow former Uber CEO Travis Kalanick left Trump's boards in February over the administration's {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T15:00:00Z", "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/merck-ceo-resigns-from-trump-council-over-charlottesville/articleshow/60061973.cms", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "By Michael Erman\n\n(Reuters) - Merck & Co Inc Chief Executive Kenneth Frazier resigned from U.S. President Donald Trump's American Manufacturing Council on Monday, saying he was taking a stand against intolerance and extremism.\n\nFrazier, who is African-American, is the only CEO so far to leave one of Trump's advisory councils because of his reaction to the violence in Virginia. Prominent Democrats and Republicans criticized Trump's response to the violence over the weekend.\n\nA gathering of hundreds of white nationalists in Virginia took a deadly turn on Saturday when a car plowed into a group of counter-protesters and killed at least one person.\n\nTrump had said \"many sides\" were involved, drawing fire from across the political spectrum for not specifically denouncing the far right.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier said in a statement announcing his resignation. (http://bit.ly/2fFnITM)\n\n\"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism,\" he said.\n\nTrump responded in a tweet, saying now that \"Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nMerck shares rose 0.8 percent in morning trading on the New York Stock Exchange, in line with the wider market.\n\nOther top business leaders also spoke out in reaction to the violence in Charlottesville.\n\n\"Lincoln: 'A house divided against itself cannot stand.' Isolate those who try to separate us. No equivalence w/ those who bring us together,\" Goldman Sachs CEO Lloyd Blankfein tweeted on Monday morning.\n\nSeveral executives from top U.S. companies have stepped down from a number of presidential advisory councils in protest to Trump policies.\n\nTesla Inc CEO Elon Musk and Walt Disney Co CEO Robert Iger left the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, a business advisory group, in June, after Trump said he would withdraw from the Paris climate accord. Musk also left the manufacturing council.\n\nFormer Uber Technologies Inc CEO Travis Kalanick quit the business advisory council in February amid pressure from activists and employees who opposed the administration's immigration policies.\n\nThe White House said Sunday that Trump's remarks condemning violence at a white nationalist rally were meant to include the Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazi groups.\n\nDemocrats and Republicans criticized Trump for waiting too long to address the violence - his first major domestic crisis as president - and for failing when he did speak out to explicitly condemn white-supremacist marchers who ignited the melee.\n\nTrump on Saturday initially denounced what he called \"this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides.\"\n\nOn Sunday, however, the White House added: \"The president said very strongly in his statement yesterday that he condemns all forms of violence, bigotry, and hatred, and of course that includes white supremacists, KKK, neo-Nazi, and all extremist groups. He called for national unity and bringing all Americans together.\"\n\n(Reporting by Michael Erman in New York and Natalie Grover in Bengaluru; Editing by Maju Samuel and Nick Zieminski)\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with News App. Download The Times of India news app for your device.", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "time": "15:00:00", "originalArticle": null, {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T17:49:00Z", "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4789982/index.html", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "TRENTON, N.J. (AP) - President Donald Trump lashed out at the CEO of the nation's third-largest pharmaceutical company after he resigned from a federal advisory council, citing the president's failure to immediately and explicitly rebuke the white nationalists who marched in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nBy early afternoon, the president did issue a direct condemnation of hate groups, but it did not appear to tamp down criticism that it was not done over the weekend when fringe groups clashed with protesters.\n\nMerck CEO Kenneth Frazier wrote on Twitter Monday that \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which runs counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nFILE - In this Thursday, Feb. 23, 2017, file photo, President Donald Trump, left, speaks during a meeting with manufacturing executives at the White House in Washington, including Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier, center, and Ford CEO Mark Fields. Frazier is resigning from the President's American Manufacturing Council citing \"a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\" Frazier's resignation comes shortly after a violent confrontation between white supremacists and protesters in Charlottesville, Va. Trump is being criticized for not explicitly condemning the white nationalists who marched in Charlottesville. (AP Photo/Evan Vucci, File)\n\nFrazier is one of the few African Americans to head a Fortune 500 company.\n\nTrump mocked the executive almost immediately following the resignation, saying on Twitter that Frazier will now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nDrugmakers have come under withering criticism for soaring prices in the U.S., including by Trump, though he has yet to act on a promise to contain them.\n\nWith the barb, Trump appeared to attack an industry executive who has tried to make drug pricing somewhat more transparent by revealing his company's overall drug price changes.\n\nIn January, Merck reported that its average net prices - the amount the company receives after discounts and other rebates - increased in the years since 2010 in a range between 3.4 percent and 6.2 percent. That's about half as large as the increase in its retail prices.\n\nThe exchange lit up social media on Monday, with many people lauding Frazier and blasting the president.\n\nOther corporate executives aired support for Frazier as well.\n\nUnilever CEO Paul Polman wrote on Twitter, \"Thanks @Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is.\"\n\nFrazier, who grew up in a poor neighborhood in Philadelphia, resigned days after one person was killed and others wounded in violent clashes between white supremacists and protesters.\n\nFrazier and his siblings were raised by their janitor father after their mother died when he was very young. He has earned a reputation as a risk taker in the drug industry, pouring money into daunting research areas, particularly trying to develop a treatment for Alzheimer's disease.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned for the same reason from the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, which Trump established to advise him on how government policy impacts economic growth and job creation.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier this year as executives retire, are replaced, or, as with Frazier and Musk, resign.\n\nWilliam Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said he couldn't \"think of a parallel example\" of any president responding as viciously as Trump to a CEO departing an advisory council.\n\n\"Usually, certain niceties are observed to smooth over a rupture,\" said Galston, who served as a domestic policy aide in the Clinton administration.\n\n\"We've learned that as president, Mr. Trump is behaving exactly as he did as a candidate,\" Galston said. \"He knows only one mode: When attacked, hit back harder.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Economics Writer Josh Boak in Washington contributed to this story.\n\n___\n\nFollow Linda A. Johnson at https://twitter.com/LindaJ_onPharma\n\nFILE - In this Sunday, Sept. 27, 2015, file photo, Merck Chairman and CEO Kenneth Frazier participates in a session \"The Future of Impact,\" at the Clinton Global Initiative in New York. Frazier is resigning from the President's American Manufacturing Council citing \"a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\" Frazier's resignation comes shortly after a violent confrontation between white supremacists and protesters in Charlottesville, Va. U.S. President Donald Trump is being criticized for not explicitly condemning the white nationalists who marched in Charlottesville. He may yet do that, but first he condemned one of those critics. \"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\" Trump tweeted Monday morning. The tweet came less than an hour after Frazier, the African-American CEO of Merck, announced that he was resigning from the federal panel in protest of what he saw as a tepid presidential response to the weekend unrest in Charlottesville, reports the Hill.\n\nIn his statement, Frazier said that American leaders must clearly reject \"expressions of hatred, bigotry, and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\" That was a clear shot at Trump's Saturday afternoon response that condemned the \"egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence\" but also said \"many sides\" were to blame for it. \"As CEO of Merck, and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism,\" wrote Frazier in announcing his departure from the panel. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T14:25:00Z", "url": "http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/08/14/543384974/merck-ceo-resigns-from-a-trump-business-council-citing-his-conscience", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Kenneth Frazier, the CEO of Merck, said he was stepping down as a matter of personal conscience. He's seen here with President Trump during a White House event in July.\n\nMerck CEO Kenneth Frazier is leaving President Trump's American Manufacturing Council, saying, \"I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nThe resignation came after Trump was criticized for his response to the violence at white supremacist events in Charlottesville, Va., over the weekend. The president, famous for his ability to be direct and forceful, was faulted for condemning violence \"on many sides.\"\n\nWithin an hour of Merck announcing Frazier's withdrawal, Trump retorted on Twitter, \"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned ... he will have more time to lower ripoff drug prices!\"\n\nFrazier stated, \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nHe was acting, Frazier said, as both the CEO of Merck and \"as a matter of personal conscience.\"\n\nMembers of his own party have called on Trump to condemn Saturday's killing of a woman who had been protesting white supremacists as an act of domestic terrorism. The White House later stated that Trump was including \"white supremacists, KKK Neo-Nazi and all extremist groups\" in his remarks about the violence.\n\nFrazier's departure is the latest high-profile exit from a presidential business council since Trump took office in January.\n\nWhen Trump announced the U.S. would be leaving the Paris climate accord, both Tesla CEO Elon Musk and Disney CEO Bob Iger left his business advisory council.\n\nAnd in February, Uber cofounder Travis Kalanick left the same advisory council during the fallout from Trump's executive order that banned immigrants from seven Muslim countries.\n\n\"The executive order is hurting many people in communities all across America,\" Kalanick said at the time.", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "time": "14:25:00", {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T15:43:00Z", "url": "http://www.rttnews.com/2805536/merck-ceo-quits-president-s-council-protesting-charlottesville-incident.aspx", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Kenneth Frazier, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Merck & Co. (MRK), has resigned as a member of the U.S. President's American Manufacturing Council in protest against Donald Trump's handling of white supremacist violence in Charlottesville.\n\nA 32-year old woman was killed and 19 others injured when a car rammed into a crowd protesting at a white supremacist rally in the university town Saturday.\n\nThe President did not explicitly condemn the actions of white supremacists involved in the rally, but condemned what he called an \"egregious display of hatred and bigotry\" displayed by antagonists \"on many sides,\" drawing fire from across the political spectrum.\n\nFrazier, one of the few black CEOs of a major U.S. corporation, announced his resignation from the elite presidential council on Monday.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier said in a statement.\n\n\"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism,\" he added.\n\nTrump, who had condemned drug makers over rising costs of prescription drugs, responded immediately through Twitter, saying, \"Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nFrazier is the latest among a number of corporate heads to quit a presidential advisory council to protest Trump's actions and policies. Former Uber Technologies CEO Travis Kalanick left in February over the Trump administration's immigration policies.\n\nIn June, Tesla CEO Elon Musk and Walt Disney CEO Robert Iger resigned from the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, a business advisory group, in dissent of Trump's decision to withdraw the United States from the Paris climate deal. Musk also had departed the manufacturing council.\n\nby RTT Staff Writer\n\nFor comments and feedback: editorial@rttnews.com\n\nPolitical News\n\nThe World's Top 10 Beer Makers\n\nThe 10 Highest {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "storyUri": "eng-3361963", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-15T01:50:00Z", "url": "http://www.khou.com/news/politics/national-politics/under-armour-ceo-quits-trumps-job-council-over-charlottesville-rally-response/464408340", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN GOOGLE+ PINTEREST\n\nUnder Armour CEO Kevin Plank said late Monday he's stepping down from President Trump's manufacturing job council, joining Merck in distancing his company from the administration following Trump's widely criticized response to white nationalists' rally at Charlottesville.\n\n\"We remain resolute in our potential and ability to improve American manufacturing,\" Plank said in a statement. \"However, Under Armour engages in innovation and sports, not politics.\"\n\nPlank's statement follows Merck CEO Ken Frazier's move earlier in the day to step down from the council \"as a matter of personal conscience.\"\n\nFrazier's resignation prompted angry responses from Trump on Twitter. In the morning, Trump tweeted that Frazier's response would give him \"more time to lower ripoff drug prices.\"\n\nTrump stepped up his Twitter criticism the pharmaceutical giant and Frazier later in the afternoon, hours after his delayed denunciation of specific racist hate groups involved in the weekend's tragedy.\n\nPlank said he joined the council \"to have an active seat at the table\" for discussions on how to spur manufacturing jobs.\n\n\"I am appreciative of the opportunity to have served, but have decided to step down from the council,\" he said. \"I love our country and our company and will continue to focus my efforts on inspiring every person that they can do anything through the power of sport which promotes unity, diversity and inclusion.\"\n\nI love our country & company. I am stepping down from the council to focus on inspiring & uniting through power of sport. - CEO Kevin Plank pic.twitter.com/8YvndJMjj1 -- Under Armour (@UnderArmour)\n\nAugust 15, 2017\n\n\u00a9
