"eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "The President attacked chief executive, Kenneth Frazier after he resigned from the White House's American Manufacturing Council in protest at Mr Trump's response to white supremacist violence\n\nShares in pharmaceutical giant Merck rose on Monday despite an angry tweet from Donald Trump threatening to crack down on \"rip-off drug prices\".\n\nThe shares were up just under 1 per cent shortly after Wall Street's opening bell, in a sign that the President's power to wipe billions off share prices in minutes with his threats over Twitter may be waning.\n\nA tweet from Mr Trump in March, vowing to drive down drug prices, sent shares in Merck, Pfizer and Amgen tumbling.\n\nRead more Pharmaceutical CEO resigns from Trump advisory council\n\nSimilar threats made to the automotive and defence industries have also hurt company stocks, at least in the short-term, as investors have worried about potential legislation that could hurt firms' profits.\n\nOn Monday, the President attacked Merck's chief executive, Kenneth Frazier after he resigned from the White House's American Manufacturing Council in protest at Mr Trump's response to white supremacist violence.\n\nMr Trump tweeted: \"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nMerck chief executive tendered his resignation after Mr Trump failed to unequivocally condemn white supremacist violence in Charlottesville, Virginia, on Saturday.\n\nAt least one person was killed when a car ploughed into a group of counter-protesters at a white supremacist gathering.\n\nFigures from across the political spectrum criticised Mr Trump after he merely said that \"many sides\" were involved in the incident.\n\nMr Frazier wrote in a tweet on Monday: \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nHe added: \"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T19:29:00Z", "url": "http://www.dailyrepublic.com/business/trump-attacks-exec-for-quitting-council-over-charlottesville/", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "TRENTON, N.J. -- President Donald Trump lashed out at the CEO of the nation's third-largest pharmaceutical company after he resigned from a federal advisory council, citing the president's failure to explicitly rebuke the white nationalists who marched in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nMerck CEO Kenneth Frazier wrote on Twitter Monday that \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which runs counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nFrazier is one of the few African Americans to head a Fortune 500 company.\n\nTrump is under increasing pressure to call out the white supremacist and hate groups involved. He lashed out almost immediately on Monday following the resignation, saying on Twitter that Frazier will now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nDrugmakers have come under withering criticism for soaring prices in the U.S., including by Trump, though he has yet to act on a promise to contain them.\n\nWith the barb, Trump appeared to attack an industry executive who has tried to make drug pricing somewhat more transparent by revealing his company's overall drug price changes.\n\nIn January, Merck reported that its average net prices -- the amount the company receives after discounts and other rebates -- increased in the years since 2010 in a range between 3.4 percent and 6.2 percent per year. That's about half as large as the increase in its retail prices. Much of the furor over drug prices recently has been over increases that have been far bigger and come one after another for drugs that have been on the market for years.\n\nThe exchange lit up social media early on Monday, with many people lauding Frazier and blasting the president. Trump eventually made a statement condemning bigotry Monday afternoon at a press conference.\n\nMeanwhile, other executives stated their support for Frazier.\n\nUnilever CEO Paul Polman wrote on Twitter, \"Thanks @Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is.\"\n\nFrazier, who grew up in a poor neighborhood in Philadelphia, resigned days after one person was killed and others wounded in violent clashes between white supremacists and protesters.\n\nFrazier and his siblings were raised by their janitor father after their mother died when he was very young. He has earned a reputation as a risk taker in the drug industry, pouring money into daunting research areas, particularly trying to develop a treatment for Alzheimer's disease.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned for the same reason from the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, which Trump established to advise him on how government policy impacts economic growth and job creation.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier this year as executives retire, are replaced, or, as with Frazier and Musk, resign.\n\nWilliam Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said he couldn't \"think of a parallel example\" of any president responding as viciously as Trump to a CEO departing an advisory council.\n\n\"Usually, certain niceties are observed to smooth over a rupture,\" said Galston, who served as a domestic policy aide in the Clinton administration.\n\n\"We've learned that as president, Mr. Trump is behaving exactly as he did as a candidate,\" Galston said. \"He knows only one mode: When attacked, hit back harder.\"", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "time": Trump instead laid the blame for the bigotry and murderous violence \"on many sides.\"\n\nNo other prominent Republican and Democratic leader equivocated in such a way. Virtually every Republican and Democratic leader -- other than the President -- denounced the attack for what it was: an act of terror.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values,\" said Frazier in announcing his resignation, \"by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nTrump had previously celebrated the support of the Merck CEO, one of the few African-American chief executives of a Fortune 500 company, in his manufacturing initiative. The president had sat Frazier next to him at the first gathering of his advisory council in February.\n\nAnd again, at a meeting with drug company CEOs.\n\nBut after Frazier's announcement this {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T15:22:00Z", "url": "http://www.toledoblade.com/Nation/2017/08/14/Merck-CEO-quits-Trump-council-over-Charlottesville.html", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier quit President Trump's manufacturing council on Monday.\n\nCNN Enlarge\n\nOne of America's most prominent black CEOs quit President Trump's manufacturing council on Monday over Trump's failure to condemn white supremacists.\n\nKenneth Frazier of Merck said in a statement: \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy.\"\n\nWithin minutes, Trump attacked him on Twitter, saying Frazier's resignation will give him \"more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nFrazier did not mention the violence in Charlottesville, Virginia, in his statement, but he did say that \"as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nThat appeared to be a reference to Trump's statement over the weekend blaming violence \"on many sides\" after neo-Nazis and white nationalists clashed with counter-protesters.\n\nFrazier is one of the country's most prominent black corporate executives and was the only black male CEO named to the council in January.\n\nHis exit marks another rebuke to Trump from corporate America. Trump's June 1 decision to leave the Paris climate accord led Tesla CEO Elon Musk to step down from the manufacturing panel as well as a separate business advisory council.\n\nDisney CEO Bob Iger similarly quit the business advisory council, and Goldman Sachs CEO Lloyd Blankfein used his first-ever tweet to slam Trump's Paris decision.\n\nPaul Polman, the chief executive of Unilever, which owns the Dove and Axe brands, praised Frazier for standing up \"for the moral values that made this country what it is.\"\n\nFrazier appeared at the White House just last month to promote an agreement between Merck, Pfizer and Corning to create 1,000 jobs.\n\nTrump formed the manufacturing council a week after his inauguration as part of a push to create jobs. At the time, the White House hailed the council, including Frazier, as \"some of the world's most successful and creative business leaders.\"\n\nAt the group's first meeting in January, Trump shook Frazier's hand after the CEO talked up efforts to bring manufacturing jobs back to the U.S. for a cancer drug.\n\n\"That's very good,\" Trump said at the time.\n\nWall Street seemed unfazed by Trump's attack. A fund that represents biotech stocks climbed 1% on Monday morning. Trump has in the past caused drug stocks to drop by threatening to bring prices \"way down.\"\n\nRelated Items Donald Trump, Kenneth Frazier, Charlottesville, Merck & Co Inc", "location": null, {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T19:12:00Z", "url": "http://www.afro.com/black-exec-resigns-presidents-council-guess-trump-responds/", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "TRENTON, N.J. (AP) -- President Donald Trump lashed out at the CEO of the nation's third-largest pharmaceutical company after he resigned from a federal advisory council, citing the president's failure to explicitly rebuke the White nationalists who marched in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nMerck CEO Kenneth Frazier wrote on Twitter Monday that \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which runs counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nFrazier is one of the few African Americans to head a Fortune 500 company.\n\nTrump is under increasing pressure to call out the White supremacist and hate groups involved. He lashed out almost immediately on Monday following the resignation, saying on Twitter that Frazier will now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nDrugmakers have come under withering criticism for soaring prices in the U.S., including by Trump, though he has yet to act on a promise to contain them.\n\nWith the barb, Trump appeared to attack an industry executive who has maneuvered to push prices lower, at least on some drugs.\n\nLast year, the company launched a new hepatitis C medicine at a big discount to the drugs already on the market. In January, Merck reported that since 2010 its annual average net price increase has ranged from 3.4 percent to 6.2 percent, roughly half its list price increases. Other drugmakers have hiked list prices 20 percent or more every year and launched new drugs with eye-popping price tags.\n\nMerck also is developing cheaper versions of complex injected medicines called biologics that can cost hundreds of thousands of dollars a year.\n\nThe exchange lit up social media early on Monday, with many people lauding Frazier and blasting the president.\n\nThere was also support from other executives.\n\nUnilever CEO Paul Polman on Twitter wrote, \"Thanks @Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is.\"\n\nFrazier, who grew up in a poor neighborhood in Philadelphia, resigned days after one person was killed and others wounded in violent clashes between white supremacists and protesters.\n\nFrazier and his siblings were raised by their janitor father after their mother died when he was very young. He has earned a reputation as a risk taker in the drug industry, pouring money into daunting research areas, particularly trying to develop a treatment for Alzheimer's disease.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T07:45:00Z", "url": "http://scng-dash.digitalfirstmedia.com/2017/08/14/exec-resigns-from-presidents-council-and-trump-lashes-out/", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "NEW YORK -- The CEO of the nation's third largest pharmaceutical company resigned from a manufacturing council that advises President Donald Trump days after racially tinged clashes in Charlottesville, Virginia, citing \"a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nTrump, who is under increasing pressure to explicitly condemn the white supremacist and hate groups involved, lashed out almost immediately Monday at Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier on Twitter, saying that because of the resignation, the pharmaceutical executive \"will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nDrugmakers have come under closer scrutiny because of rising drug prices, though Merck has not been one of the companies targeted by lawmakers or watchdog groups.\n\nFrazier, who is African American, said in a tweet on Monday that the country's leaders must \"honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy.\"\n\nOne person was killed in the protests after a car slammed into a crowd and multiple people were injured in that incident and in running clashes between white supremacists and those opposing them.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned from a White House advisory council for the same reason.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T14:17:00Z", "url": "http://www.newsweek.com/trump-attacks-african-american-ceo-who-quit-federal-board-protest-presidents-650528", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "President Donald Trump has criticized an African-American pharmaceuticals executive who resigned from a federal manufacturing panel in protest at Trump's failure to explicitly condemn white nationalists after Saturday's violence in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nIn a statement posted on Twitter, Kenneth C. Frazier, chairman and chief executive officer at Merck pharmaceuticals, announced Monday he was resigning from the President's American Manufacturing Council.\n\nPresident Donald Trump meets with Kenneth C. Frazier, chairman and CEO of Merck & Co., left, in the Roosevelt Room of the White House on January 31 in Washington, D.C. Getty\n\nDaily Emails and Alerts - Get the best of Newsweek delivered to your inbox\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier said in the statement. \"As CEO of Merck, and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nFrazier is one of a small handful of black executives of Fortune 500 companies in the U.S.\n\nTrump faced widespread criticism from Democrats and Republicans after his statement on the violence at a far-right protest in Charlottesville. White supremacists and other groups in the so-called alt-right had gathered to protest the removal of a statue of a Confederate general, with the gathering turning violent and resulting in the death of a counter-protester, run down by a man in a car. Trump had on Saturday failed to condemn white nationalists outright in a statement on the situation, instead referring to violence \"on many sides.\"\n\n\"We condemn in the strongest possible terms this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides -- on many sides,\" Trump said at a press conference from his New Jersey golf course, where he is taking a 17-day break.\n\nLess than an hour after Frazier's announcement Monday, Trump responded on Twitter as he departed for a day trip back to Washington from his Bedminster, New Jersey, course.\n\n\"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\" he tweeted.\n\nTrump is under building pressure to unequivocally condemn the white supremacists behind Saturday's protests, in which activist Heather Heyer was killed when a car drove into a group of counter-demonstrators. Police believe the man behind the wheel was James Alex Fields, who was earlier Saturday pictured at the protest with members of white supremacist group Vanguard America.\n\nThe White House has since sought to clarify Trump's comments, with a spokesman saying in a statement that Trump's condemnation included the Klu Klux Klan and neo-Nazi groups.\n\nTrump has yet to mention the white nationalist violence on his @RealDonaldTrump Twitter account, which he favors for making public statements and attacking opponents.\n\nCritics say the administration has repeatedly failed to criticize white supremacist violence, while being hasty to condemn attacks around the world where Islamist extremists have been involved.", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 612, "textStart": 602, {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T19:09:00Z", "url": "http://www.khaleejtimes.com/international/americas/trump-attacks-exec-for-quitting-council-over-charlottesville", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Frazier is one of the few African Americans to head a Fortune 500 company.\n\nPresident Donald Trump lashed out at the CEO of the nation's third-largest pharmaceutical company after he resigned from a federal advisory council, citing the president's failure to explicitly rebuke the white nationalists who marched in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nMerck CEO Kenneth Frazier wrote on Twitter Monday that \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which runs counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nFrazier is one of the few African Americans to head a Fortune 500 company.\n\nTrump is under increasing pressure to call out the white supremacist and hate groups involved. He lashed out almost immediately on Monday following the resignation, saying on Twitter that Frazier will now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nDrugmakers have come under withering criticism for soaring prices in the U.S., including by Trump, though he has yet to act on a promise to contain them.\n\nWith the barb, Trump appeared to attack an industry executive who has tried to make drug pricing somewhat more transparent by revealing his company's overall drug price changes.\n\nIn January, Merck reported that its average net prices - the amount the company receives after discounts and other rebates - increased in the years since 2010 in a range between 3.4 percent and 6.2 percent per year. That's about half as large as the increase in its retail prices. Much of the furor over drug prices recently has been over increases that have been far bigger and come one after another for drugs that have been on the market for years.\n\nThe exchange lit up social media early on Monday, with many people lauding Frazier and blasting the president. Trump eventually made a statement condemning bigotry Monday afternoon at a press conference.\n\nMeanwhile, other executives stated their support for Frazier.\n\nUnilever CEO Paul Polman wrote on Twitter, \"Thanks (at)Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is.\"\n\nFrazier, who grew up in a poor neighborhood in Philadelphia, resigned days after one person was killed and others wounded in violent clashes between white supremacists and protesters.\n\nFrazier and his siblings were raised by their janitor father after their mother died when he was very young. He has earned a reputation as a risk taker in the drug industry, pouring money into daunting research areas, particularly trying to develop a treatment for Alzheimer's disease.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned for the same reason from the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, which Trump established to advise him on how government policy impacts economic growth and job creation.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier this year as executives retire, are replaced, or, as with Frazier and Musk, resign.\n\nWilliam Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said he couldn't \"think of a parallel example\" of any president responding as viciously as Trump to a CEO departing an advisory council.\n\n\"Usually, certain niceties are observed to smooth over a rupture,\" said Galston, who served as a domestic policy aide in the Clinton administration.\n\n\"We've learned that as president, Mr. Trump is behaving exactly as he did as a candidate,\" Galston said. \"He knows only one mode: When attacked, hit back harder.\"", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "time": {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T16:52:00Z", "url": "https://www.i24news.tv/en/news/economy/152972-170814-trump-slams-merck-ceo-who-quit-advisory-panel-over-charlottesville-response", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Merck chief executive Kenneth Frazier, who is African American, resigned Monday from a White House advisory panel on manufacturing, calling the decision a \"matter of personal conscience\" following President Donald Trump's initial response to a violent white supremacist rally.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all men are created equal,\" Frazier wrote on Twitter.\n\n\"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nTrump, also on Twitter, responded about an hour later.\n\n\"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\" the US president said.\n\nFrazier announced the decision Monday morning as criticism mounted of Trump's failure over the weekend to explicitly denounce the neo-Nazis and Ku Klux Klan members whose rally in Charlottesville, Virginia set off violent clashes that culminated when a man drove his car into a crowd of counter-protesters, killing a young woman and injuring 19.\n\nTwo state police officers responding to the events died in a helicopter crash near the area.\n\nLater Monday, Trump made a statement calling out specific hate groups.\n\n\"Racism is evil. And those who cause violence in its name are criminals and thugs, including the KKK, neo-Nazis, white supremacists and other hate groups that are repugnant to everything we hold dear as Americans,\" he said from the White House.\n\nThe Justice Department has launched a civil rights inquiry into the incident, and the driver, a 20-year-old Ohio man who was said to have had a history of neo-Nazi beliefs, has been charged with second-degree murder.\n\nFrazier is a Harvard Law School-trained attorney whose experience includes pro bono work that won the release of a wrongly convicted death row inmate in Alabama.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to depart a Trump advisory panel. After Trump announced he would withdraw the United States from the Paris climate agreement, Disney chief executive Bob Iger and Tesla Motors head Elon Musk both left a White House advisory council, joining former Uber leader, who stepped down in February following criticism of Trump's travel ban.\n\nBut most other executives appear to be staying put.\n\n\"Heartbroken by the violence in #Charlottesville. Hate and intolerance are a betrayal of what we stand for as Americans,\" said Pepsi chief executive Indra Nooyi on Twitter, in a statement that did not address the Trump panel.\n\nOther executives, including those from General Electric and Dow, planned to stay on Trump panels, US financial news media reported Monday.", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "time": "16:52:00", {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T20:14:00Z", "url": "http://lethbridgeherald.com/business/2017/08/14/trump-attacks-exec-for-quitting-council-over-charlottesville/", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "By Linda A. Johnson, The Associated Press on August 14, 2017.\n\nTRENTON, N.J. - President Donald Trump lashed out at the CEO of the nation's third-largest pharmaceutical company after he resigned from a federal advisory council, citing the president's failure to explicitly rebuke the white nationalists who marched in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nMerck CEO Kenneth Frazier wrote on Twitter Monday that \"America's leaders must honour our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which runs counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nFrazier is one of the few African Americans to head a Fortune 500 company.\n\nTrump is under increasing pressure to call out the white supremacist and hate groups involved. He lashed out almost immediately on Monday following the resignation, saying on Twitter that Frazier will now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nDrugmakers have come under withering criticism for soaring prices in the U.S., including by Trump, though he has yet to act on a promise to contain them.\n\nWith the barb, Trump appeared to attack an industry executive who has tried to make drug pricing somewhat more transparent by revealing his company's overall drug price changes.\n\nIn January, Merck reported that its average net prices - the amount the company receives after discounts and other rebates - increased in the years since 2010 in a range between 3.4 per cent and 6.2 per cent per year. That's about half as large as the increase in its retail prices. Much of the furor over drug prices recently has been over increases that have been far bigger and come one after another for drugs that have been on the market for years.\n\nThe exchange lit up social media early on Monday, with many people lauding Frazier and blasting the president. Trump eventually made a statement condemning bigotry Monday afternoon at a press conference.\n\nMeanwhile, other executives stated their support for Frazier.\n\nUnilever CEO Paul Polman wrote on Twitter, \"Thanks @Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is.\"\n\nFrazier, who grew up in a poor neighbourhood in Philadelphia, resigned days after one person was killed and others wounded in violent clashes between white supremacists and protesters.\n\nFrazier and his siblings were raised by their janitor father after their mother died when he was very young. He has earned a reputation as a risk taker in the drug industry, pouring money into daunting research areas, particularly trying to develop a treatment for Alzheimer's disease.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned for the same reason from the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, which Trump established to advise him on how government policy impacts economic growth and job creation.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier this year as executives retire, are replaced, or, as with Frazier and Musk, resign.\n\nWilliam Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said he couldn't \"think of a parallel example\" of any president responding as viciously as Trump to a CEO departing an advisory council.\n\n\"Usually, certain niceties are observed to smooth over a rupture,\" said Galston, who served as a domestic policy aide in the Clinton administration.\n\n\"We've learned that as president, Mr. Trump is behaving exactly as he did as a candidate,\" Galston said. \"He knows only one mode: When attacked, hit back harder.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Economics Writer Josh Boak in Washington contributed to this story.", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 60, "textStart": 45, "amb": false, "date": "2017-08-14"}], "time": "20:14:00", "originalArticle": null, "details": {}, He lashed out almost immediately following the resignation Aug. 14, saying on Twitter that Frazier will now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nDrugmakers have come under withering criticism for soaring prices in the US, including by Trump, though he has yet to act on a promise to contain them.\n\nWith the barb, Trump appeared to attack an industry executive who has tried to make drug pricing somewhat more transparent by revealing his company's overall drug price changes.\n\nIn January, Merck reported that its average net prices - the amount the company receives after discounts and other rebates - increased in the years since 2010 in a range between 3.4% and 6.2% per year. That's about half as large as the increase in its retail prices.\n\nMuch of the furor over drug prices recently has been over increases that have been far bigger and come one after another for drugs that have been on the market for years.\n\nThe exchange lit up social media, with many people lauding Frazier and blasting the president.\n\nLater in the day, Trump finally named and condemned \"repugnant\" hate groups and declared that \"racism is evil\" in a far more forceful statement than he'd made earlier after deadly, race-fueled weekend clashes in Charlottesville.\n\nMeanwhile, other executives stated their support for Frazier.\n\nUnilever CEO Paul Polman wrote on Twitter, \"Thanks ?Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is.\"\n\nFrazier, who grew up in a poor neighbourhood in Philadelphia, resigned days after one person was killed and others wounded in violent clashes between white supremacists and protesters.\n\nFrazier and his siblings were raised by their janitor father after their mother died when he was very young. He has earned a reputation as a risk taker in the drug industry, pouring money into daunting research areas, particularly trying to develop a treatment for Alzheimer's disease.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned for the same reason from the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, which Trump established to advise him on how government policy impacts economic growth and job creation.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier this year as executives retire, are replaced, or, as with Frazier and Musk, resign.\n\nWilliam Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said he couldn't \"think of a parallel example\" of any president responding as viciously as Trump to a CEO departing an advisory council.\n\n\"Usually, certain niceties are observed to smooth over a rupture,\" said Galston, who served as a domestic policy aide in the Clinton administration.\n\n\"We've learned that as {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T13:34:00Z", "url": "http://gantdaily.com/2017/08/14/merck-ceo-quits-trump-council-over-charlottesville/", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier quit President Trump's manufacturing council on Monday after Trump failed to condemn white supremacists.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy,\" Frazier said in a statement posted on Twitter by the company.\n\nTrump immediately responded on Twitter with an attack on Frazier, saying his resignation will give him \"more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nThe president cited violence \"on many sides\" after neo-Nazis and white nationalists clashed with counter-protesters in Charlottesville, Virginia, over the weekend.\n\nFrazier is one of the country's most prominent black corporate executives and was the only black male CEO named to the council in January.\n\nHis exit marks another rebuke to Trump from corporate America. Trump's June 1 decision to leave the Paris climate accord led Tesla CEO Elon Musk to step down from the manufacturing panel as well as a separate business advisory council.\n\nFrazier appeared at the White House just last month to promote an agreement between Merck, Pfizer and Corning to create 1,000 jobs.\n\nTrump formed the manufacturing council a week after his inauguration as part of a push to create jobs. At the time, the White House hailed the council, including Frazier, as \"some of the world's most successful and creative business leaders.\"\n\nAt the group's first meeting in January, Trump shook Frazier's hand after the CEO talked up efforts to bring manufacturing jobs back to the U.S. for a cancer drug.\n\n\"That's very good,\" Trump said at the time.\n\n-CNNMoney's Patrick Gillespie {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T19:32:00Z", "url": "http://www.chicagobusiness.com/article/20170814/NEWS05/170819931/trump-attacks-merck-exec-for-quitting-manufacturing-council", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "(AP) -- President Donald Trump lashed out at the CEO of the nation's third-largest pharmaceutical company after he resigned from a federal advisory council, citing the president's failure to explicitly rebuke the white nationalists who marched in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nMerck CEO Kenneth Frazier wrote on Twitter Monday that \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which runs counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nFrazier is one of the few African Americans to head a Fortune 500 company.\n\nThe council's remaining members include Dennis Muilenburg, the CEO of Boeing, and Doug Oberhelman, the executive chairman and former CEO of Caterpillar. Crain's reached out to both companies to ask if the two men will continue to serve on the councils and will update this story once they respond.\n\nTrump is under increasing pressure to call out the white supremacist and hate groups involved. He lashed out almost immediately on Monday following the resignation, saying on Twitter that Frazier will now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nDrugmakers have come under withering criticism for soaring prices in the U.S., including by Trump, though he has yet to act on a promise to contain them.\n\nWith the barb, Trump appeared to attack an industry executive who has tried to make drug pricing somewhat more transparent by revealing his company's overall drug price changes.\n\nIn January, Merck reported that its average net prices -- the amount the company receives after discounts and other rebates -- increased in the years since 2010 in a range between 3.4 percent and 6.2 percent per year. That's about half as large as the increase in its retail prices. Much of the furor over drug prices recently has been over increases that have been far bigger and come one after another for drugs that have been on the market for years.\n\nThe exchange lit up social media early on Monday, with many people lauding Frazier and blasting the president. Trump eventually made a statement condemning bigotry Monday afternoon at a press conference.\n\nMeanwhile, other executives stated their support for Frazier.\n\nUnilever CEO Paul Polman wrote on Twitter, \"Thanks @Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is.\"\n\nFrazier, who grew up in a poor neighborhood in Philadelphia, resigned days after one person was killed and others wounded in violent clashes between white supremacists and protesters.\n\nFrazier and his siblings were raised by their janitor father after their mother died when he was very young. He has earned a reputation as a risk taker in the drug industry, pouring money into daunting research areas, particularly trying to develop a treatment for Alzheimer's disease.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned for the same reason from the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, which Trump established to advise him on how government policy impacts economic growth and job creation.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier this year as executives retire, are replaced, or, as with Frazier and Musk, resign.\n\nWilliam Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said he couldn't \"think of a parallel example\" of any president responding as viciously as Trump to a CEO departing an advisory council.\n\n\"Usually, certain niceties are observed to smooth over a rupture,\" said Galston, who served as a domestic policy aide in the Clinton administration.\n\n\"We've learned that as president, Mr. Trump is behaving exactly as he did as a candidate,\" Galston said. \"He knows only one mode: When attacked, hit back harder.\"", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "time": {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T17:09:00Z", "url": "http://dailycaller.com/2017/08/14/ceo-leaves-white-house-council-over-trumps-charlottesville-response/", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "A CEO that served on President Donald Trump's council on manufacturing announced his resignation early Monday morning, due to Trump's response to the violent protest in Charlottesville, Va.\n\nKen Frazier, the CEO of Merck, a large pharmaceutical company, announced he was stepping down from the White House panel in a statement on Twitter, saying he would be leaving \"as a matter of personal conscience\" and \"to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nFrazier criticized Trump for his vague language condemning the protests, as the president merely denounced \"hatred\" from all sides after the violence.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry, and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier said in the statement.\n\nNow that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council,he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\n\n-- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 14, 2017\n\nThe \"Unite the Right\" rally drew white nationalists, neo-Nazis, and members of the militia movement. Police promptly called the permitted event an unlawful assembly after violent brawls between rally-goers and counter protesters began, leaving several injured. (RELATED: Trump Condemns Hatred And Bigotry 'On Many Sides' Following Violence In Virginia)\n\nAfter the police cleared the groups out of the park, a car violently struck a crowd, which resulted in {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T20:57:00Z", "url": "http://www.canadianbusiness.com/business-news/trump-attacks-exec-for-quitting-council-over-charlottesville/", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "President Donald Trump lashed out at the CEO of the nation's third-largest pharmaceutical company after he resigned from a federal advisory council, citing the president's failure to explicitly rebuke the white nationalists who marched in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nMerck CEO Kenneth Frazier wrote on Twitter Monday that \"America's leaders must honour our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which runs counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nFrazier is one of the few African Americans to head a Fortune 500 company.\n\nTrump is under increasing pressure to call out the white supremacist and hate groups involved. He lashed out almost immediately on Monday following the resignation, saying on Twitter that Frazier will now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nDrugmakers have come under withering criticism for soaring prices in the U.S., including by Trump, though he has yet to act on a promise to contain them.\n\nWith the barb, Trump appeared to attack an industry executive who has tried to make drug pricing somewhat more transparent by revealing his company's overall drug price changes.\n\nIn January, Merck reported that its average net prices _ the amount the company receives after discounts and other rebates _ increased in the years since 2010 in a range between 3.4 per cent and 6.2 per cent per year. That's about half as large as the increase in its retail prices. Much of the furor over drug prices recently has been over increases that have been far bigger and come one after another for drugs that have been on the market for years.\n\nThe exchange lit up social media early on Monday, with many people lauding Frazier and blasting the president. Trump eventually made a statement condemning bigotry Monday afternoon at a press conference.\n\nMeanwhile, other executives stated their support for Frazier.\n\nUnilever CEO Paul Polman wrote on Twitter, \"Thanks ?Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is.\"\n\nFrazier, who grew up in a poor neighbourhood in Philadelphia, resigned days after one person was killed and others wounded in violent clashes between white supremacists and protesters.\n\nFrazier and his siblings were raised by their janitor father after their mother died when he was very young. He has earned a reputation as a risk taker in the drug industry, pouring money into daunting research areas, particularly trying to develop a treatment for Alzheimer's disease.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned for the same reason from the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, which Trump established to advise him on how government policy impacts economic growth and job creation.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier this year as executives retire, are replaced, or, as with Frazier and Musk, resign.\n\nWilliam Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said he couldn't \"think of a parallel example\" of any president responding as viciously as Trump to a CEO departing an advisory council.\n\n\"Usually, certain niceties are observed to smooth over a rupture,\" said Galston, who served as a domestic policy aide in the Clinton administration.\n\n\"We've learned that as president, Mr. Trump is behaving exactly as he did as a candidate,\" Galston said. \"He knows only one mode: When attacked, hit back harder.\"\n\nFollow us on Facebook Follow us on Twitter\n\nGet our daily briefing on innovation, leadership, technology & the economy.\n\nWeekdays at 6 AM ET. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T20:35:00Z", "url": "http://www.news24.com/World/News/merck-ceo-quits-trump-advisory-panel-over-charlottesville-response-20170814", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "New Yor - Merck chief executive Kenneth Frazier, who is African American, resigned on Monday from a White House advisory panel on manufacturing, calling the decision a \"matter of personal conscience\" following President Donald Trump's initial response to a violent white supremacist rally.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all men are created equal,\" Frazier wrote on Twitter.\n\n\"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nTrump, also on Twitter, responded about an hour later.\n\n\"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\" the US president said.\n\nFrazier announced the decision on Monday morning as criticism mounted of Trump's failure over the weekend to explicitly denounce the neo-Nazis and Ku Klux Klan members whose rally in Charlottesville, Virginia set off violent clashes that culminated when a man drove his car into a crowd of counter-protesters, killing a young woman and injuring 19.\n\nTwo state police officers responding to the events died in a helicopter crash near the area.\n\nLater on Monday, Trump made a statement calling out specific hate groups.\n\n\"Racism is evil. And those who cause violence in its name are criminals and thugs, including the KKK, neo-Nazis, white supremacists and other hate groups that are repugnant to everything we hold dear as Americans,\" he said from the White House.\n\nThe Justice Department has launched a civil rights inquiry into the incident, and the driver, a 20-year-old Ohio man who was said to have had a history of neo-Nazi beliefs, has been charged with second-degree murder.\n\nFrazier is a Harvard Law School-trained attorney whose experience includes pro bono work that won the release of a wrongly convicted death row inmate in Alabama.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to depart a Trump advisory panel. After Trump announced he would withdraw the United States from the Paris climate agreement, Disney chief executive Bob Iger and Tesla Motors head Elon Musk both left a White House advisory council, joining former Uber leader, who stepped down in February following criticism of Trump's travel ban.\n\nBut most other executives appear to be staying put.\n\n\"Heartbroken by the violence in #Charlottesville. Hate and intolerance are a betrayal of what we stand for as Americans,\" said Pepsi chief executive Indra Nooyi on Twitter, in a statement that did not address the Trump panel.\n\nOther executives, including those from General Electric and Dow, planned to stay on Trump panels, US financial news media reported on Monday.", "location": {"label": {"eng": "New York City"}, "country": {"label": "body": "A man hits the pavement during a clash between members of white nationalist protesters against a group of counter-protesters in Charlottesville, Virginia August 12, 2017. -- Reuters pic WASHINGTON, Aug 14 -- President Donald Trump lambasted Merck's CEO today after the African-American pharmaceutical executive resigned from a White House advisory council, citing Trump's controversial response to a violent white supremacist rally.\n\nMerck chief executive Kenneth Frazier, alluding to Trump's much-criticised response to a deadly weekend white supremacist protest, said he was exiting Trump's American Manufacturing Council.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all men are created equal,\" Frazier wrote on Twitter.\n\n\"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nTrump, also on Twitter, responded about an hour later.\n\n\"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\" the US president said.\n\nThe White House came under fire after Trump refused to explicitly condemn white supremacists for their role in a violent protest Saturday in the southern state of Virginia.\n\nFlowers and a photo of car ramming victim Heather Heyer lie at a makeshift memoriall in Charlottesville, Virginia, August 13, 2017. -- Reuters picA woman died and 19 people were injured in the city of Charlottesville when a car plowed into a crowd of people after a rally by Ku Klux Klan members and other white nationalists turned violent. Two state police officers died in a helicopter crash near the area.\n\nIn an appearance Saturday at his golf resort in Bedminster, New Jersey, Trump faulted \"many sides\" for the violence. He made no mention of the far-right militia groups involved in the Charlottesville melee, some of whom were wearing Trump hats or T-shirts.\n\nWhite House officials have since made explicit they oppose bigotry and white supremacy. Several top officials, including Vice President Mike Pence and White House advisor Ivanka Trump, have spoken forcefully against hate groups.\n\nBut Trump, whose presidential campaign was championed by prominent white supremacists such as David Duke, has come under fire from many in his own party for not speaking out clearly on the matter. -- AFP", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-15T00:38:00Z", "url": "http://www.fox13memphis.com/news/merck-ceo-stepping-down-from-american-manufacturing-council/591200925", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier wrote on Twitter Monday that \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which runs counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nFrazier is one of the few African Americans to head a Fortune 500 company.\n\nTrump is under increasing pressure to call out the white supremacist and hate groups involved. He lashed out almost immediately on Monday following the resignation, saying on Twitter that Frazier will now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nThe president followed up later in the day, tweeting that Merck \"is a leader in higher & higher drug prices while at the same time taking jobs out of the U.S. Bring jobs back & LOWER PRICES!\"\n\nDrugmakers have come under withering criticism for soaring prices in the U.S., including by Trump, though he has yet to act on a promise to contain them.\n\nWith the barbs, Trump appeared to attack an industry executive who has tried to make drug pricing somewhat more transparent by revealing his company's overall drug price changes.\n\nIn January, Merck reported that its average net prices - the amount the company receives after discounts and other rebates - increased in the years since 2010 in a range between 3.4 percent and 6.2 percent per year. That's about half as large as the increase in its retail prices. Much of the furor over drug prices recently has been over increases that have been far bigger and come one after another for drugs that have been on the market for years.\n\nThe exchange lit up social media early on Monday, with many people lauding Frazier and blasting the president. Trump eventually made a statement condemning bigotry Monday afternoon at a press conference.\n\nMeanwhile, other executives stated their support for Frazier.\n\nUnilever CEO Paul Polman wrote on Twitter, \"Thanks @Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is.\"\n\nFrazier, who grew up in a poor neighborhood in Philadelphia, resigned from the manufacturing advisory council days after one person was killed and others wounded in violent clashes between white supremacists and protesters.\n\nFrazier and his siblings were raised by their janitor father after their mother died when they were very young. He has earned a reputation as a risk taker in the drug industry, pouring money into daunting research areas, particularly trying to develop a treatment for Alzheimer's disease.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned for the same reason from the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, which Trump established to advise him on how government policy impacts economic growth and job creation.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier this year as executives retire, are replaced, or, as with Frazier and Musk, resign.\n\nWilliam Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said he couldn't \"think of a parallel example\" of any president responding as viciously as Trump to a CEO departing an advisory council.\n\n\"Usually, certain niceties are observed to smooth over a rupture,\" said Galston, who served as a domestic policy aide in the Clinton administration.\n\n\"We've learned that as president, Mr. Trump is behaving exactly as he did as a candidate,\" Galston said. \"He knows only one mode: When attacked, hit back harder.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Economics Writer Josh Boak in Washington contributed to this story.\n\n___\n\nFollow Linda A. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T14:35:00Z", "url": "http://www.livemint.com/Politics/IB9yKqUHg3vAaHYqL7m7uO/Donald-Trump-attacks-Merck-CEO-on-Twitter-after-resignation.html", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "New York: Merck & Co.'s CEO resigned from President Donald Trump's council of manufacturing executives Monday, saying \"America's leaders must honour our fundamental values\" by rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy.\n\nHe was almost immediately attacked by Trump on Twitter.\n\nFollowing a weekend of violence in Virginia involving white-supremacist groups that Trump has been criticized for not explicitly condemning, Merck chief executive officer Ken Frazier said \"as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nLess than an hour later, Trump tweeted in response, \"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nThe council has included top executives from Boeing Co., Dow Chemical Co. and Johnson & Johnson. Frazier's resignation -- the latest CEO to quit one of Trump's high-profile executive advisory groups -- comes after a weekend of violent clashes in Charlottesville, Virginia, that resulted in one death.\n\nFrazier is an African-American CEO -- a rarity in large American corporations -- and Merck has sometimes taken stands on social issues. In 2012, the Kenilworth, New Jersey-based company's foundation ended funding for the Boy Scouts of America over the group's exclusion of gays from its leadership ranks. He is a registered Democrat, according to Pennsylvania voter records.\n\nCEO departures\n\nOther chief executives have also stepped down from the various business-advisory groups pulled together by the Trump administration. Earlier this year, Elon Musk of Tesla Inc. and Walt Disney Co. CEO Bob Iger quit a strategy and policy panel after Trump withdrew from the Paris climate pact.\n\nFormer Uber Technologies Inc. CEO Travis Kalanick quit in February after Trump's executive order on immigration. The manufacturing group, spearheaded by Dow Chemical CEO Andrew Liveris, hasn't met in five months.\n\nTrump made US drug prices an issue during the presidential campaign and after -- at one point accusing drug companies of \"getting away with murder.\" While his rhetoric on the subject has cooled, the Food and Drug Administration has taken steps to try and bring more competition to the market for some drugs, and speed more generic drugs to the market.\n\nFrazier, in December, said his company has a \"restrained\" approach to price increases, calling aggressive price increases a foolhardy move by the industry.\n\nMerck shares were up less than 1% in trading before the markets opened in New York. One protester was killed and 19 people were injured.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier said in a statement released Monday morning on Twitter.\n\npic.twitter.com/a1PNQZism5 -- Merck (@Merck)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nThe president immediately fired back his own criticism of Frazier, saying on Twitter that the CEO should concentrate on lowering \"ripoff drug prices.\"\n\nNow that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council,he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES! -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nTrump responded to Saturday's violence by blaming bigotry on \"many sides.\" He has not explicitly condemned the white supremacists, although Attorney General Jeff Sessions said Monday the president had \"explicitly condemned\" violence and \"he totally opposes\" the values espoused by white supremacy organizations.\n\nThe manufacturing council is an advisory group of executives from across the country. Led by Dow CEO Andrew Liveris, its members include leaders of Intel, Dell, General Electric and Lockheed Martin. Tesla CEO Elon Musk stepped down in June, in protest of Trump's decision to withdraw from the Paris climate accords.\n\nFrazier said in his statement that his decision was made not only as CEO of Merck, the country's third-largest pharmaceutical company, but as a \"matter of personal conscience.\"\n\n\"I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism,\" he said.\n\nHeadquartered in Kenilworth, New Jersey, Merck employs thousands of people in Pennsylvania, most at its sprawling West Point vaccine manufacturing plant in Upper Gwynedd. Many of its employees live in Bucks and Montgomery counties.\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\nEnjoying our content? {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T21:50:00Z", "url": "http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/36131228/trump-mocks-exec-for-quitting-advisory-council-over-racism", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "TRENTON, N.J. (AP) - President Donald Trump lashed out at the CEO of the nation's third-largest pharmaceutical company after he resigned from a federal advisory council, citing the president's failure to immediately and explicitly rebuke the white nationalists who marched in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nBy early afternoon, the president did issue a direct condemnation of hate groups, but it did not appear to tamp down criticism that it was not done over the weekend when fringe groups clashed with protesters.\n\nMerck CEO Kenneth Frazier wrote on Twitter Monday that \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which runs counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nFrazier is one of the few African Americans to head a Fortune 500 company.\n\nTrump mocked the executive almost immediately following the resignation, saying on Twitter that Frazier will now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nDrugmakers have come under withering criticism for soaring prices in the U.S., including by Trump, though he has yet to act on a promise to contain them.\n\nWith the barb, Trump appeared to attack an industry executive who has tried to make drug pricing somewhat more transparent by revealing his company's overall drug price changes.\n\nIn January, Merck reported that its average net prices - the amount the company receives after discounts and other rebates - increased in the years since 2010 in a range between 3.4 percent and 6.2 percent. That's about half as large as the increase in its retail prices.\n\nThe exchange lit up social media on Monday, with many people lauding Frazier and blasting the president.\n\nOther corporate executives aired support for Frazier as well.\n\nUnilever CEO Paul Polman wrote on Twitter, \"Thanks @Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is.\"\n\nFrazier, who grew up in a poor neighborhood in Philadelphia, resigned days after one person was killed and others wounded in violent clashes between white supremacists and protesters.\n\nFrazier and his siblings were raised by their janitor father after their mother died when he was very young. He has earned a reputation as a risk taker in the drug industry, pouring money into daunting research areas, particularly trying to develop a treatment for Alzheimer's disease.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned for the same reason from the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, which Trump established to advise him on how government policy impacts economic growth and job creation.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier this year as executives retire, are replaced, or, as with Frazier and Musk, resign.\n\nWilliam Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said he couldn't \"think of a parallel example\" of any president responding as viciously as Trump to a CEO departing an advisory council.\n\n\"Usually, certain niceties are observed to smooth over a rupture,\" said Galston, who served as a domestic policy aide in the Clinton administration.\n\n\"We've learned that as president, Mr. Trump is behaving exactly as he did as a candidate,\" Galston said. \"He knows only one mode: When attacked, hit back harder.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Economics Writer Josh Boak in Washington contributed to this story.\n\n___\n\nFollow Linda A. Johnson at https://twitter.com/LindaJ_onPharma\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T20:16:00Z", "url": "http://www.yorkdispatch.com/story/money/business/2017/08/14/trump-attack-merck-ceo-quits-presidents-council-white-nationalism/104598790/", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nTRENTON, N.J. -- President Donald Trump lashed out at the CEO of the nation's third-largest pharmaceutical company after he resigned from a federal advisory council, citing the president's failure to explicitly rebuke the white nationalists who marched in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nMerck CEO Kenneth Frazier wrote on Twitter Monday that \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which runs counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nFrazier is one of the few African Americans to head a Fortune 500 company.\n\nTrump is under increasing pressure to call out the white supremacist and hate groups involved. He lashed out almost immediately on Monday following the resignation, saying on Twitter that Frazier will now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nDrugmakers have come under withering criticism for soaring prices in the U.S., including by Trump, though he has yet to act on a promise to contain them.\n\nWith the barb, Trump appeared to attack an industry executive who has tried to make drug pricing somewhat more transparent by revealing his company's overall drug price changes.\n\nIn January, Merck reported that its average net prices -- the amount the company receives after discounts and other rebates -- increased in the years since 2010 in a range between 3.4 percent and 6.2 percent per year. That's about half as large as the increase in its retail prices. Much of the furor over drug prices recently has been over increases that have been far bigger and come one after another for drugs that have been on the market for years.\n\nThe exchange lit up social media early on Monday, with many people lauding Frazier and blasting the president. Trump eventually made a statement condemning bigotry Monday afternoon at a press conference.\n\nOther execs: Meanwhile, other executives stated their support for Frazier.\n\nUnilever CEO Paul Polman wrote on Twitter, \"Thanks @Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is.\"\n\nFrazier, who grew up in a poor neighborhood in Philadelphia, resigned days after one person was killed and others wounded in violent clashes between white supremacists and protesters.\n\nFrazier and his siblings were raised by their janitor father after their mother died when he was very young. He has earned a reputation as a risk taker in the drug industry, pouring money into daunting research areas, particularly trying to develop a treatment for Alzheimer's disease.\n\nOther resignations: Frazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and from two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned for the same reason from the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, which Trump established to advise him on how government policy impacts economic growth and job creation.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier this year as executives retire, are replaced, or, as with Frazier and Musk, resign.\n\nWilliam Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said he couldn't \"think of a parallel example\" of any president responding as viciously as Trump to a CEO departing an advisory council.\n\n\"Usually, certain niceties are observed to smooth over a rupture,\" said Galston, who served as a domestic policy aide in the Clinton administration.\n\n\"We've learned that as president, Mr. Trump is behaving exactly as he did as a candidate,\" Galston said. \"He knows only one mode: When attacked, hit back harder.\"\n\nCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. Nineteen people were injured.\n\nMr Frazier added: \"Our country's strength stems from its diversity and the contributions made by men and women of different faiths, races, sexual orientations and political beliefs.\"\n\nMinutes after the high-profile CEO's announcement, Trump attacked him on Twitter. He wrote: \"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nThe White House has since issued a statement, which said the president \"condemns all forms of violence, bigotry and hatred, and of course that includes white Supremacists, KKK, neo-nazi and all extremist groups.\"\n\nMr Frazier is the third business leader to quit the US leader's panel. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T19:43:00Z", "url": "http://www.business-standard.com/article/reuters/merck-ceo-resigns-from-trump-council-over-charlottesville-117081401829_1.html", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Merck & Co Inc\n\nTrump denounced neo-Nazis and the Ku Klux Klan as criminals and thugs on Monday, bowing to mounting political pressure after initially saying many sides were to blame after a white-nationalist rally turned deadly in Virginia.\n\nFrazier, who is African-American, is the only CEO so far to leave one of Trump's advisory councils because of his reaction to the violence in Virginia. Prominent Democrats and Republicans criticized Trump's response to the violence over the weekend.\n\nThe gathering of hundreds of white nationalists took a deadly turn on Saturday when a car plowed into a group of counter-protesters and killed at least one person.\n\nTrump had said \"many sides\" were involved, drawing fire from across the political spectrum for not specifically denouncing the far right.\n\n\"America's leaders must honour our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier said in a statement announcing his resignation. (http://bit.ly/2fFnITM)\n\n\"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism,\" he said.\n\nTrump responded in a tweet, saying now that \"Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nThe son of a janitor, Frazier joined Merck as general counsel of one of the drugmaker's subsidiaries in 1992, working his way up to CEO of the company in 2011.\n\nHe made his name as the company's top lawyer, steering it through daunting litigation over Vioxx, its widely used painkiller that was withdrawn in 2004 after being linked to heart attacks.\n\nMany observers thought Merck would eventually have to shell out $10 billion or more to thousands of plaintiffs over the drug's withdrawal. But Frazier's legal strategy led to a $4.85-billion settlement in 2007, allowing Merck to refocus on its pipeline of experimental medicines.\n\nMerck shares rose 0.5 percent in afternoon trading on the New York Stock Exchange, roughly in line with the wider market.\n\nFrazier frequently made political contributions during the 2016 election, donating to both Republican and Democratic members of Congress but no donations to a presidential candidate during the year.\n\nThe political PAC maintained by Merck and funded through donations from Merck employees made over $1.1 million in candidate contributions during the 2016 campaign - but did not contribute to Trump or his Democratic rival Hillary Clinton, according to documents filed with the Federal Elections Commission.\n\nThe Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, which represents the pharmaceutical industry and lobbies on its behalf in Congress, declined to offer a statement of support for Frazier or to comment on Trump's reaction.\n\nThe industry's silence comes as Trump is finalising an executive order on drug prices that would relax industry regulation and contains measures that, some say, would protect existing drug prices or even increase them.\n\nIndividually, at least one CEO, John Maraganore of Alnylam Pharmaceuticals\n\nOther top business leaders also spoke out in response to the violence in Charlottesville.\n\n\"I support Ken Frazier's decision. I'm thankful we have business leaders such as Ken to remind America of its better angels,\" said Hewlett Packard Enterprises\n\nGoldman Sachs\n\nSeveral executives from top U.S. companies have previously stepped down from a number of presidential advisory councils in protest to Trump policies.\n\nTesla Inc\n\nFormer Uber Technologies Inc [UBER.UL] CEO Travis Kalanick quit the business advisory council in February amid pressure from activists and employees who opposed the administration's immigration policies.\n\nThe White House said Sunday that Trump's remarks condemning violence at a white nationalist rally were meant to include the Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazi groups.\n\nDemocrats and Republicans criticized Trump for waiting too long to address the violence - his first major domestic crisis as president - and for failing when he did speak out to explicitly condemn white-supremacist marchers who ignited the melee.\n\nTrump on Saturday initially denounced what he called \"this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides.\"\n\nOn Sunday, however, the White House added: \"The president said very strongly in his statement yesterday that he condemns all forms of violence, bigotry, and hatred, and of course that includes white supremacists, KKK, neo-Nazi, and all extremist groups. He called for national unity and bringing all Americans together.\"", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "time": "19:43:00", "originalArticle": null, "details": {}, "timeCrawl": "19:43:00", {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-15T01:48:00Z", "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/pharmaceutical-ceo-resigns-trump-advisory-132800646.html", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "The CEO of a major American pharmaceutical company has resigned from Donald Trump's manufacturing council in response to the Presidents' failure to address \"hatred, bigotry and group supremacy\" stemming from a white supremacist rally.\n\nKenneth Frazier, chairman and CEO of Merck & Co, announced his resignation in a statement on Twitter, saying: \"America's leaders must honour our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nThe President quickly shot back, sarcastically tweeting that the pharmaceutical company leader would now have \"more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nMr Frazier, who is black, previously served on Mr Trump's American Manufacturing Council, alongside prominent CEOs like Tesla's Elon Musk and Ford's Mark Fields.\n\nHis resignation comes days after a white supremacist rally in Virginia resulted in the deaths of three people, and the injury of dozens more. Mr Trump, addressing the situation on Sunday, decried the \"hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides\".\n\nThe comments sparked outcry from those who believed the President should explicitly denounce white supremacist and neo-Nazi groups.\n\nThe White House attempted to clear up these comments later, saying in an unattributed statement that Mr Trump's condemnation of bigotry and violence \"includes white supremacists, KKK, Neo-Nazi and all extremist groups\". Mr Trump has yet to explicitly condemn any white supremacist groups himself.\n\nMr Frazier did not mention Mr Trump specifically in his statement, in which he spoke broadly of \"American leaders\". He said his resignation was a matter of \"personal conscience,\" adding that he felt \"a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism\".\n\n\"Our country's strength stems from its diversity and the contributions made by men and women of different faiths, races, sexual orientations and political beliefs,\" he said.\n\nNow that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council,he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES! -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nMr Trump created the manufacturing council in January, as part of his pledge to create jobs and cut regulations. Restoring the American manufacturing industry was a key tenet of Mr Trump's campaign, and a theme of the White House's recent \"Made in America\" week.\n\nMr Frazier is the latest high-profile CEO to step down from one of the President's councils. Walt Disney CEO Robert Iger and Mr Musk both stepped down from the Strategic and Policy Forum in June, after Mr Trump announced he would withdraw the US from the Paris climate agreement.\n\nFormer
