{"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T13:41:00Z", "url": "https://www.bustle.com/p/who-is-ken-frazier-the-merck-executive-resigned-in-protest-of-trump-76381", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "One of the president's surrogates is making his opposition to the handling of the Charlottesville violence clear. Kenneth Frazier, CEO of of the pharmaceutical company Merck & Co., has resigned from President Trump's manufacturing council. Frazier's resignation is notable, as he is the only black member of the aforementioned council.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" he said in a statement. \"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nPresident Trump's response and his refusal to specifically condemn white supremacist groups at the rally in Charlottesville that led to the death of at least one counter-protester, Heather Heyer, has been roundly criticized by both Democrats and Republicans in Congress.\n\n\"We condemn in the strongest possible terms this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence, on many sides,\" Trump said in a statement on Saturday. \"On many sides. It's been going on for a long time in our country. Not Donald Trump, not Barack Obama. This has been going on for a long, long time.\"\n\nTrump tweeted about Frazier Monday morning. \"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\" he wrote.\n\nThe president's vague condemnations on Saturday were embraced on white supremacist websites like the Daily Stormer. \"Trump comments were good,\" wrote one member. \"He didn't attack us. He just said the nation should come together. Nothing specific against us. He said that we need to study why people are so angry, and implied that there was hate... on both sides!\"\n\nThe user went on to add, \"There was virtually no counter-signaling of us at all. He said loves us all. Also refused to answer a question about White Nationalists supporting him.\"\n\nSeveral white supremacists, such as former Ku Klux Klan Grand Wizard David Duke, said Saturday's rally was a sign of white America's determination to fulfill Donald Trump's promises to \"take [their] country back.\"\n\n\"We are going to fulfill the promises of Donald Trump,\" Duke said on Saturday. \"That's what we believed in. That's why we voted for Donald Trump, because he said he's going to take our country back.\"\n\nA spokesperson for the White House insisted on Sunday that the president's statement on Saturday included white supremacists. \"The president said very strongly in his statement yesterday that he condemns all forms of violence, bigotry and hatred. Of course that includes white supremacists, KKK Neo-Nazi and all extremist groups. He called for national unity and bringing all Americans together,\" said the spokesperson.\n\nPresident Trump has yet to condemn such groups directly himself.", "location": null, "extractedDates": {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T15:27:00Z", "url": "http://www.heart.co.uk/news/uk-world/trump-suffers-first-resignation-over-charlott/", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "An influential pharma CEO has quit an advisory role over Donald Trump's failure to condemn neo-Nazis involved in violent clashes with anti-fascist protesters in Virginia that left three people dead\n\nMerck chief executive Kenneth Frazier - one of America's most prominent black executives - quit the US President's American Manufacturing Council on Monday, saying he was taking a stand against intolerance and extremism in the wake of the violence.\n\n:: Leaders condemn 'repulsive' far-right protests\n\nMr Trump criticised Mr Frazier's decision on Twitter, but has come under fire himself for repeatedly not condemning the neo-Nazis who staged the initial rally in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nIn a tweet announcing his resignation, Mr Frazier said: \"America's leaders must honour our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nThe US President hit back, saying that now that \"Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from the President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nMr Trump has claimed \"many sides\" were involved in the violence in Charlottesville, but has been heavily criticised across the political spectrum for not specifically denouncing the far right.\n\nThe US President has been at his New Jersey golf club on a \"working vacation\", but is expected to return to Washington on Monday to sign an executive action on China's trade policies.\n\nHe will likely face questions and criticism from the media over his initial response to the violence on Saturday.\n\nOn Monday, attorney general Jeff Sessions said the death of paralegal Heather Heyer, 32, who was killed when a car ploughed into a group of counter-protesters in Charlottesville \"does meet the definition of domestic terrorism in our statute\".\n\nHe told ABC: \"You can be sure we will charge and advance the investigation towards the most serious charges that can be brought, because this is an unequivocally unacceptable and evil attack that cannot be accepted in America.\"\n\nMr Sessions said he expects to hear more from Mr Trump after a meeting on Monday.\n\nA White House statement on Sunday said: \"The president said very strongly in his statement yesterday that he condemns all forms of violence, bigotry and hatred and of course that includes white supremacists, KKK, neo-Nazi and all extremist groups.\n\n\"He called for national unity and bringing all Americans together.\"\n\nSeveral executives from top US companies have stepped down from a number of presidential advisory councils in protest over Mr Trump's policies.\n\nTesla chief executive Elon Musk and Walt Disney chief executive Robert Iger quit the Strategic and Policy Forum in June after Mr Trump announced the US would withdraw from the Paris climate accord.\n\nMr Musk has also left the manufacturing council.\n\nFormer Uber chief executive Travis Kalanick left the business advisory council in February amid {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T22:40:00Z", "url": "http://www.houstonchronicle.com/news/nation-world/nation/article/CEOs-respond-after-Trump-attacks-Merck-Chief-11818596.php", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Kenneth Frazier, chief executive of Merck, the pharmaceuticals company, Monday resigned from President Donald Trump's American Manufacturing Council after the president failed to directly condemn the white nationalist protesters at the center of violent protests in Charlottesville, Va., over the weekend.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier said in a statement. \"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against extremism.\"\n\nLess than an hour later, Trump took aim at the Merck executive.\n\nTrump replied swiftly to Frazier on Twitter, suggesting that stepping down from the council would give him \"more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nLater in the day, Trump explicitly condemned hate groups including neo-Nazis and the Ku Klux Klan, offering the kind of sharp denunciation of racism that many critics believed was lacking over the weekend.\n\nBut the president's remarks came too late for Frazier, who resigned early Monday.\n\nBy midday, Frazier was joined by a handful of other executives as a voice of dissent in the business community, which has particular sway over the president, himself a businessman.\n\nLloyd Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, posted a cryptic message on Twitter, quoting Abraham Lincoln.\n\n\"Lincoln: 'A house divided against itself cannot stand.' Isolate those who try to separate us. No equivalence w/ those who bring us together,\" Blankfein wrote.\n\nTim Cook, the chief executive of Apple, also posted a statement opposing white supremacy and racism.\n\n\"We've seen the terror of white supremacy & racist violence before. It's a moral issue - an affront to America. We must all stand against it,\" Cook wrote.\n\nAnd at least one other chief executive - albeit of a foreign company - came to Frazier's defense. Paul Polman, the chief executive of Unilever, signaled his support for the Merck boss on Twitter.\n\n\"Thanks Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is,\" Polman wrote.\n\nGeneral Electric said in a statement that it \"has no tolerance for hate, bigotry or racism,\" but added that its chairman and recently retired chief executive, Jeff Immelt, will remain on the manufacturing advisory council from which Frazier resigned Monday.\n\nKevin Plank, Under Armour's chief executive, who is also on one of the advisory councils, issued a statement denouncing racism and discrimination.\n\nHe stopped short of criticizing the president or his comments about Frazier.", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "time": "22:40:00", {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T16:16:00Z", "url": "http://www.crainsnewyork.com/article/20170814/POLITICS/170819954/merck-ceo-ken-frazier-quits-president-donald-trumps-manufacturing-council-as-a-matter-of-personal-conscience-after-charlottesville-virginia-attacks", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Merck & Co.'s CEO quit President Donald Trump's council of manufacturing executives Monday, saying \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values\" by rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy.\n\nHe was almost immediately attacked by Trump on Twitter.\n\nFollowing a weekend of violence in Virginia involving white-supremacist groups that Trump has been criticized for not explicitly condemning, Merck chief executive Ken Frazier said \"as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nLess than an hour later, Trump tweeted in response:\n\nNow that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council,he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES! -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nThe council has included top executives from Boeing Co., Dow Chemical Co. and Johnson & Johnson. The move by Frazier -- the latest CEO to quit the groups -- comes after a weekend of violent clashes in Charlottesville, Virginia, that resulted in one death.\n\nTrump, over the weekend, said \"many sides\" bore blame for the violence, though has so far not directly criticized the supremacist groups that were protesting the removal of a statue of the confederate war general Robert E. Lee. On Saturday, a man drove a Dodge Challenger into a group of counter-demonstrators, killing a woman.\n\nAttorney General Jeff Sessions said there is \"no bigger case right now that we are working on\" and said the attack with the car met the definition of domestic terrorism.\n\nFrazier is a black CEO -- a rarity in large American corporations -- and Merck has in the past taken stands on social issues. In 2012, the Kenilworth, New Jersey-based company's foundation ended funding for the Boy Scouts of America over the group's exclusion of gays from its leadership ranks. Frazier is a registered Democrat, according to Pennsylvania voter records.\n\nTrump created two CEO advisory groups early in his presidency. Blackstone Group CEO Steve Schwarzman leads one described as a strategy and policy forum, and Dow Chemical Co.'s Andrew Liveris organized a manufacturing initiative. After an initial burst of activity and press attention, the councils have fizzled with neither meeting since April.\n\nOther chief executives have also stepped down from the various business-advisory groups. Earlier this year, Elon Musk of Tesla Inc. and Walt Disney Co. CEO Bob Iger quit the strategy and policy panel after Trump withdrew from the Paris climate pact. Former Uber Technologies Inc. CEO Travis Kalanick quit in February after Trump's executive order on immigration.\n\nTrump made U.S. drug prices an issue during the presidential campaign and after -- at one point accusing drug companies of \"getting away with murder.\" While his rhetoric on the subject has cooled, the Food and Drug Administration has taken steps to try and bring more competition to the market for some drugs, and speed more generic drugs to the market.\n\nFrazier, in December, said his company has a \"restrained\" approach to price increases, calling aggressive price increases a foolhardy move by the industry. In a company report published this year, Merck said it has a \"long history of making our medicines and vaccines accessible and affordable through responsible pricing practices.\"\n\nFor 2016, the list price on its drugs rose by 9.6% on average while the net price, which more closely reflects what is paid by consumers, rose 5.5%, according to the report.\n\nMerck shares were up 0.7% to $62.84 at 9:42 a.m. in New York.\n\nToby Cosgrove, the CEO of the Cleveland Clinic, plans to remain on strategy and policy group, said to Eileen Sheil, a spokeswoman for the health system. She said the group hasn't met since April, and there are no meetings scheduled.\n\nGoldman Sachs Group Inc. CEO Lloyd Blankfein also took to Twitter Monday in response to the violence, citing former president Abraham Lincoln. \"A house divided against itself cannot stand,\" wrote Blankfein, whose inaugural tweet in June expressed disapproval over Trump's decision to ditch the Paris climate accord.", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 818, "textStart": 803, "amb": false, "date": {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T16:08:00Z", "url": "http://www.dw.com/en/merck-ceo-quits-trump-council-over-charlottesville-remarks/a-40088833", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "In a statement Monday posted on Twitter, Merck chief executive (CEO) Kenneth Frazier said he was stepping down \"as a matter of personal conscience\" after the Charlottesville violence, adding that he was feeling \"a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nThe move came after Donald Trump is under increasing pressure to explicitly condemn the racially-tinged rally of white supremacists in Charlottesville, Virginia, over the weekend.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all men are created equal,\" the CEO of America's third largest pharmaceutical company wrote on Twitter.\n\nTrump backlash\n\nAfter the news was out, the US President immediately responded, saying in a Tweet that Frazier's resignation would now give him more time to \"LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nFrazier, who is African American, is one of several high-profile business leaders who agreed to advise the US President on the American Manufacturing Council. However, there have already been a number of resignations from the panel over differences with the Trump administration.\n\nThe CEO of e-car pioneer Tesla, Elon Musk, quit in after the US withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned from a White House advisory council for the same reason.\n\nMuted response\n\nA woman died and 19 people were injured in Charlottesville when a car plowed into a crowd of people after a rally by Ku Klux Klan members and other white nationalists turned violent. Two state police officers died in a helicopter crash near the area.\n\nIn an appearance Saturday at his golf resort in Bedminster, New Jersey, Trump faulted \"many sides\" for the violence. He made no mention of the far-right militia groups involved in the rioting, some of whom were wearing Trump hats or T-shirts.\n\nWhite House officials have since made explicit they oppose bigotry and white supremacy. But Trump, whose presidential campaign was championed by prominent white supremacists such as David Duke, has come under fire not speaking out clearly on the matter.", "location": null, Kenneth Frazier, CEO of pharmaceutical company Merck, resigned from the US president's manufacturing council today.\n\nResponding to clashes surrounding an Aug. 12 white nationalist rally and a car attack that left one woman dead, Trump spoke vaguely of \"bigotry\" and and violence \"on many, many sides.\" His emphasis on law enforcement rather than racial hate prompted widespread criticism.\n\nIn a statement shared on Twitter by Merck, Frazier announced that he was stepping down from the panel as a matter of personal conscience. \"I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\npic.twitter.com/a1PNQZism5\n\n-- Merck (@Merck) August 14, 2017\n\nTrump was quick to criticize Frazier with a tweet linking him to \"ripoff drug prices:\"\n\nNow that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council,he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\n\n-- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 14, 2017\n\nThe manufacturing council consist of Trump's selection of representatives from US companies, and includes Elon Musk and Michael Dell. The council advises the president on US business competitiveness.\n\nFollowing Frazier's resignation, many on social media have called for other members of the cabinet to follow. At time of writing, Under Armor CEO Kevin Plank had tweeted condemnation of the violence in Charlottesville from a company account, but had not left the council.\n\nWe are saddened by #Charlottesville. There is no place for racism or discrimination in this world. We choose love & unity. - CEO Kevin Plank\n\n-- Under Armour (@UnderArmour) August 14, 2017\n\nMerck's CEO was the only person of color in the council, which now comprises of 27 members. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T17:46:00Z", "url": "http://www.journalnow.com/news/nation_world_ap/trump-mocks-exec-for-quitting-advisory-council-over-racism/article_a8b0ee95-752a-50de-8a73-00eba8ee92ee.html", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "TRENTON, N.J. (AP) -- President Donald Trump lashed out at the CEO of the nation's third-largest pharmaceutical company after he resigned from a federal advisory council, citing the president's failure to immediately and explicitly rebuke the white nationalists who marched in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nBy early afternoon, the president did issue a direct condemnation of hate groups, but it did not appear to tamp down criticism that it was not done over the weekend when fringe groups clashed with protesters.\n\nMerck CEO Kenneth Frazier wrote on Twitter Monday that \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which runs counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nFrazier is one of the few African Americans to head a Fortune 500 company.\n\nTrump mocked the executive almost immediately following the resignation, saying on Twitter that Frazier will now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nDrugmakers have come under withering criticism for soaring prices in the U.S., including by Trump, though he has yet to act on a promise to contain them.\n\nWith the barb, Trump appeared to attack an industry executive who has tried to make drug pricing somewhat more transparent by revealing his company's overall drug price changes.\n\nIn January, Merck reported that its average net prices -- the amount the company receives after discounts and other rebates -- increased in the years since 2010 in a range between 3.4 percent and 6.2 percent. That's about half as large as the increase in its retail prices.\n\nThe exchange lit up social media on Monday, with many people lauding Frazier and blasting the president.\n\nOther corporate executives aired support for Frazier as well.\n\nUnilever CEO Paul Polman wrote on Twitter, \"Thanks @Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is.\"\n\nFrazier, who grew up in a poor neighborhood in Philadelphia, resigned days after one person was killed and others wounded in violent clashes between white supremacists and protesters.\n\nFrazier and his siblings were raised by their janitor father after their mother died when he was very young. He has earned a reputation as a risk taker in the drug industry, pouring money into daunting research areas, particularly trying to develop a treatment for Alzheimer's disease.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned for the same reason from the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, which Trump established to advise him on how government policy impacts economic growth and job creation.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier this year as executives retire, are replaced, or, as with Frazier and Musk, resign.\n\nWilliam Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said he couldn't \"think of a parallel example\" of any president responding as viciously as Trump to a CEO departing an advisory council.\n\n\"Usually, certain niceties are observed to smooth over a rupture,\" said Galston, who served as a domestic policy aide in the Clinton administration.\n\n\"We've learned that as president, Mr. Trump is behaving exactly as he did as a candidate,\" Galston said. \"He knows only one mode: When attacked, hit back harder.\"\n\n-- -- --\n\nAP Economics Writer Josh Boak in Washington contributed to this story.\n\n-- -- --\n\nFollow Linda A. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T18:33:00Z", "url": "http://www.wsoctv.com/news/national-news/ap-top-news/trump-mocks-exec-for-quitting-advisory-council-over-racism/591434661", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "By early afternoon, the president did issue a direct condemnation of hate groups, but it did not appear to tamp down criticism that it was not done over the weekend when fringe groups clashed with protesters.\n\nMerck CEO Kenneth Frazier wrote on Twitter Monday that \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which runs counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nFrazier is one of the few African Americans to head a Fortune 500 company.\n\nTrump mocked the executive almost immediately following the resignation, saying on Twitter that Frazier will now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nDrugmakers have come under withering criticism for soaring prices in the U.S., including by Trump, though he has yet to act on a promise to contain them.\n\nWith the barb, Trump appeared to attack an industry executive who has tried to make drug pricing somewhat more transparent by revealing his company's overall drug price changes.\n\nIn January, Merck reported that its average net prices - the amount the company receives after discounts and other rebates - increased in the years since 2010 in a range between 3.4 percent and 6.2 percent. That's about half as large as the increase in its retail prices.\n\nThe exchange lit up social media on Monday, with many people lauding Frazier and blasting the president.\n\nOther corporate executives aired support for Frazier as well.\n\nUnilever CEO Paul Polman wrote on Twitter, \"Thanks @Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is.\"\n\nFrazier, who grew up in a poor neighborhood in Philadelphia, resigned days after one person was killed and others wounded in violent clashes between white supremacists and protesters.\n\nFrazier and his siblings were raised by their janitor father after their mother died when he was very young. He has earned a reputation as a risk taker in the drug industry, pouring money into daunting research areas, particularly trying to develop a treatment for Alzheimer's disease.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned for the same reason from the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, which Trump established to advise him on how government policy impacts economic growth and job creation.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier this year as executives retire, are replaced, or, as with Frazier and Musk, resign.\n\nWilliam Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said he couldn't \"think of a parallel example\" of any president responding as viciously as Trump to a CEO departing an advisory council.\n\n\"Usually, certain niceties are observed to smooth over a rupture,\" said Galston, who served as a domestic policy aide in the Clinton administration.\n\n\"We've learned that as president, Mr. Trump is behaving exactly as he did as a candidate,\" Galston said. \"He knows only one mode: When attacked, hit back harder.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Economics Writer Josh Boak in Washington contributed to this story.\n\n___\n\nFollow Linda A. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T16:08:00Z", "url": "https://www.cnbc.com/2017/08/14/cramer-to-trump-get-the-facts-straight-on-merck-ceo-ken-frazier-and-drug-pricing.html", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "President Donald Trump should have done his homework on Merck Chairman and CEO Ken Frazier before spouting off on Twitter and implying Frazier and the drugmaker are behind \"ripoff drug prices,\" CNBC's Jim Cramer said on Monday.\n\nNo matter what you think about the reason Frazier gave for leaving a key White House business advisory group, the president should get his facts right, Cramer said on \"Squawk on the Street.\" \"Mr. Frazier has not been at the forefront of raising prices for the sake of raising prices.\"\n\nOn Monday morning, Merck tweeted out a statement from Frazier, which read in part: \"I am resigning from the President's American Manufacturing Council. ... America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry, and group supremacy. ... As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nFRAZIER TWEET\n\nNot even an hour later, Trump blasted Frazier on Twitter.\n\nNow that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\n\nTrump's response to Frazier's message came after the president's weekend comments about the deadly violence that erupted at a white nationalist rally in Charlottesville, Virginia. On Saturday, Trump said: \"We condemn in the strongest possible terms this egregious display of hatred, bigotry, and violence on many sides.\"\n\nCritics took issue with Trump's statement, saying that by adding \"on many sides\" and not specifically condemning the white nationalist groups by name, he was tacitly supporting the racist and anti-Semitic messages from the groups behind the rally.\n\n\"For those that think it's absolutely right that Trump called [Frazier] out because he called Trump out, all I can say is ... do homework. Homework is key because I know companies. I know companies,\" Cramer said.\n\n\"In the industry, Mr. Frazier is not known as someone who has done ripoff pricing,\" Cramer argued. \"There are some companies that have continually ripped off the American people. But Merck has not been one. If you hate him or like him for what he said, can we at least get the facts straight on Mr. Frazier.\"\n\nOn a personal note, Cramer said he respects Frazier for not making broad claims about Merck's cancer drug Keytruda.\n\n\"Mr. Frazier has so kept down his sales by not promising about what Keytruda does because he does not want to give people false hope,\" Cramer said. \"Anyone who's lost {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T17:10:00Z", "url": "https://www.cnbc.com/2017/08/14/ex-mcdonalds-ceo-trumps-actions-despicable-in-wake-of-violence.html", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Former McDonald's CEO Ed Rensi had harsh words Monday for President Donald Trump following a violent white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Virginia, and what Rensi called the president's \"unacceptable\" response.\n\nRensi said Trump's slow reaction to condemn the march meant he \"lost a bit of a fan in me.\" He also said Trump's tweet attacking Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier was \"despicable.\"\n\nFrazier, the only African-American CEO of a major pharmaceutical company, resigned Monday morning from the president's American Manufacturing Council.\n\n\"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism,\" Frazier wrote in a tweet.\n\nTrump responded on Twitter, saying the drug executive would have more time to \"LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\" now that he was no longer a part of the advisory group.\n\nIn an interview on CNBC's \"Squawk Alley\" before Trump explicitly denounced white supremacists and the \"racist\" violence, Rensi praised Frazier's decision to leave. He said if he were on the council, he would have confronted Trump face to face and resigned, saying, \"he would have a battle every day with me.\"\n\n\"Our job as CEOs is to return great value to the shareholders and stakeholders of our companies, but that involves social conscience,\" Rensi said. \"We got to do the right thing for the right reasons.\"\n\nPaul Polman, CEO of Unilever, was one of the few current executives who had words of support for Frazier and his decision to resign by midday Monday. He thanked Frazier for his \"strong leadership.\"\n\nPaulPolman: Thanks @Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is\n\nRensi warned Trump will become \"irrelevant\" if he doesn't change his ways and embrace leading, rather than strategizing as if this were campaign stumping.\n\n\"The president of the United States works for us and we ought to challenge him,\" Rensi said.\n\nHe also said the country should come together and \"celebrate our diversity, celebrate our differences and celebrate the wonderfulness that comes out of all that.\"\n\nDrawing from a quote from the Rev. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T17:29:00Z", "url": "http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/A/APFN_US_TRUMP_MERCK_CEO_NJOL-?SITE=CAANR&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "TRENTON, N.J. (AP) -- President Donald Trump lashed out at the CEO of the nation's third-largest pharmaceutical company after he resigned from a federal advisory council, citing the president's failure to immediately and explicitly rebuke the white nationalists who marched in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nBy early afternoon, the president did issue a direct condemnation of hate groups, but it did not appear to tamp down criticism that it was not done over the weekend when fringe groups clashed with protesters.\n\nMerck CEO Kenneth Frazier wrote on Twitter Monday that \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which runs counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nFrazier is one of the few African Americans to head a Fortune 500 company.\n\nTrump mocked the executive almost immediately following the resignation, saying on Twitter that Frazier will now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nDrugmakers have come under withering criticism for soaring prices in the U.S., including by Trump, though he has yet to act on a promise to contain them.\n\nWith the barb, Trump appeared to attack an industry executive who has tried to make drug pricing somewhat more transparent by revealing his company's overall drug price changes.\n\nIn January, Merck reported that its average net prices - the amount the company receives after discounts and other rebates - increased in the years since 2010 in a range between 3.4 percent and 6.2 percent. That's about half as large as the increase in its retail prices.\n\nThe exchange lit up social media on Monday, with many people lauding Frazier and blasting the president.\n\nOther corporate executives aired support for Frazier as well.\n\nUnilever CEO Paul Polman wrote on Twitter, \"Thanks @Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is.\"\n\nFrazier, who grew up in a poor neighborhood in Philadelphia, resigned days after one person was killed and others wounded in violent clashes between white supremacists and protesters.\n\nFrazier and his siblings were raised by their janitor father after their mother died when he was very young. He has earned a reputation as a risk taker in the drug industry, pouring money into daunting research areas, particularly trying to develop a treatment for Alzheimer's disease.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned for the same reason from the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, which Trump established to advise him on how government policy impacts economic growth and job creation.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier this year as executives retire, are replaced, or, as with Frazier and Musk, resign.\n\nWilliam Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said he couldn't \"think of a parallel example\" of any president responding as viciously as Trump to a CEO departing an advisory council.\n\n\"Usually, certain niceties are observed to smooth over a rupture,\" said Galston, who served as a domestic policy aide in the Clinton administration.\n\n\"We've learned that as president, Mr. Trump is behaving exactly as he did as a candidate,\" Galston said. \"He knows only one mode: When attacked, hit back harder.\"\n\n---\n\nAP Economics Writer Josh Boak in Washington contributed to this story.", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "time": "17:29:00", "originalArticle": null, "details": {}, "timeCrawl": "17:42:00", "title": "Trump mocks exec for quitting {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T19:58:00Z", "url": "https://www.thestar.com/business/2017/08/14/merck-ceo-quits-trumps-council-due-to-presidents-refusal-to-denounce-white-supremacy-groups-in-charlottesville.html", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "U.S. president responds on Twitter, saying pharmaceutical boss will have 'more time to lower ripoff drug prices.'\n\nMerck & Co.'s CEO quit U.S. President Donald Trump's council of manufacturing executives Monday, saying \"America's leaders must honour our fundamental values\" by rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy.\n\nHe was almost immediately attacked by Trump on Twitter.\n\nFollowing a weekend of violence in Virginia involving white-supremacist groups that Trump has been criticized for not explicitly condemning, Merck chief executive officer Ken Frazier said \"as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nRead more:\n\n'Racism is evil': Trump finally condemns white supremacists amid fierce backlash over his first Charlottesville remarks\n\n15 photos that show Charlottesville's stunning descent into violence\n\nWhat we know about James Alex Fields Jr., the man charged in the Charlottesville car killing\n\nLess than an hour later, Trump tweeted in response, \"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nThe council has included top executives from Boeing, Dow Chemical and Johnson & Johnson. The move by Frazier -- the latest CEO to quit the groups -- comes after a weekend of violent clashes in Charlottesville, Va., that resulted in one death.\n\nTrump, over the weekend, said \"many sides\" bore blame for the violence, though has so far not directly criticized the supremacist groups that were protesting the removal of a statue of the confederate war general Robert E. Lee. On Saturday, a man drove a Dodge Challenger into a group of counterdemonstrators, killing a woman.\n\nAttorney General Jeff Sessions said there is \"no bigger case right now that we are working on\" and said the attack with the car met the definition of domestic terrorism.\n\nSocial Issues\n\nFrazier is a black CEO -- a rarity in large American corporations -- and Merck has in the past taken stands on social issues. In 2012, the Kenilworth, N.J.-based company's foundation ended funding for the Boy Scouts of America over the group's exclusion of gays from its leadership ranks. Frazier is a registered Democrat, according to Pennsylvania voter records.\n\nTrump created two CEO advisory groups early in his presidency. Blackstone Group CEO Steve Schwarzman leads one described as a strategy and policy forum, and Dow Chemical's Andrew Liveris organized a manufacturing initiative. After an initial burst of activity and press attention, the councils have fizzled with neither meeting since April.\n\nOther chief executives have also stepped down from the various business-advisory groups. Earlier this year, Elon Musk of Tesla and Walt Disney CEO Bob Iger quit the strategy and policy panel after Trump withdrew from the Paris climate pact. Former Uber Technologies CEO Travis Kalanick quit in February after Trump's executive order on immigration.\n\nTrump made U.S. drug prices an issue during the presidential campaign and after -- at one point accusing drug companies of \"getting away with murder.\" While his rhetoric on the subject has cooled, the Food and Drug Administration has taken steps to try and bring more competition to the market for some drugs and speed more generic drugs to the market.\n\nMerck's Prices\n\nFrazier, in December, said his company has a \"restrained\" approach to price increases, calling aggressive price increases a foolhardy move by the industry. In a company report published this year, Merck said it has a \"long history of making our medicines and vaccines accessible and affordable through responsible pricing practices.\"\n\nFor 2016, the list price on its drugs rose by 9.6 per cent on average while the net price, which more closely reflects what is paid by consumers, rose 5.5 per cent, according to the report.\n\nMerck shares were up 0.25 per cent to $62.62 at 3:05 p.m. in New York.\n\nToby Cosgrove, the CEO of the Cleveland Clinic, plans to remain on the strategy and policy group, said Eileen Sheil, a spokesperson for the health system. She said the group hasn't met since April, and there are no meetings scheduled.\n\nGoldman Sachs CEO Lloyd Blankfein also took to Twitter Monday in response to the violence, citing former president Abraham Lincoln.\n\n\"A house divided against itself cannot stand,\" wrote Blankfein, whose inaugural tweet in June expressed disapproval over Trump's decision to ditch the Paris climate accord.", {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T17:39:00Z", "url": "http://www.startribune.com/trump-mocks-exec-for-quitting-advisory-council-over-racism/440349993/", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "TRENTON, N.J. -- President Donald Trump lashed out at the CEO of the nation's third-largest pharmaceutical company after he resigned from a federal advisory council, citing the president's failure to immediately and explicitly rebuke the white nationalists who marched in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nBy early afternoon, the president did issue a direct condemnation of hate groups, but it did not appear to tamp down criticism that it was not done over the weekend when fringe groups clashed with protesters.\n\nMerck CEO Kenneth Frazier wrote on Twitter Monday that \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which runs counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nFrazier is one of the few African Americans to head a Fortune 500 company.\n\nTrump mocked the executive almost immediately following the resignation, saying on Twitter that Frazier will now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nDrugmakers have come under withering criticism for soaring prices in the U.S., including by Trump, though he has yet to act on a promise to contain them.\n\nWith the barb, Trump appeared to attack an industry executive who has tried to make drug pricing somewhat more transparent by revealing his company's overall drug price changes.\n\nIn January, Merck reported that its average net prices -- the amount the company receives after discounts and other rebates -- increased in the years since 2010 in a range between 3.4 percent and 6.2 percent. That's about half as large as the increase in its retail prices.\n\nThe exchange lit up social media on Monday, with many people lauding Frazier and blasting the president.\n\nOther corporate executives aired support for Frazier as well.\n\nUnilever CEO Paul Polman wrote on Twitter, \"Thanks @Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is.\"\n\nFrazier, who grew up in a poor neighborhood in Philadelphia, resigned days after one person was killed and others wounded in violent clashes between white supremacists and protesters.\n\nFrazier and his siblings were raised by their janitor father after their mother died when he was very young. He has earned a reputation as a risk taker in the drug industry, pouring money into daunting research areas, particularly trying to develop a treatment for Alzheimer's disease.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned for the same reason from the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, which Trump established to advise him on how government policy impacts economic growth and job creation.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier this year as executives retire, are replaced, or, as with Frazier and Musk, resign.\n\nWilliam Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said he couldn't \"think of a parallel example\" of any president responding as viciously as Trump to a CEO departing an advisory council.\n\n\"Usually, certain niceties are observed to smooth over a rupture,\" said Galston, who served as a domestic policy aide in the Clinton administration.\n\n\"We've learned that as president, Mr. Trump is behaving exactly as he did as a candidate,\" Galston said. \"He knows only one mode: When attacked, hit back harder.\"", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "time": He was the only black member of Trump's manufacturing council.\n\nThe resignation came after a weekend of violence at a white nationalist and neo-Nazi protest in Charlottesville, Virginia, in which the president did not explicitly condemn the actions of white supremacists.\n\nTrump almost immediately fired back at Frazier, turning the conversation toward drug pricing.\n\nMerck, a New {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T20:50:00Z", "url": "http://www.mysanantonio.com/business/national/article/CEOs-react-after-Trump-attacks-Merck-chief-11818266.php", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Kenneth C. Frazier, chief executive of Merck, the pharmaceuticals company, on Monday resigned from President Donald Trump's American Manufacturing Council after the president failed to directly condemn the white nationalist protesters at the center of violent protests in Charlottesville, Virginia, over the weekend.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier said in a statement. \"As CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against extremism.\"\n\nLess than an hour later, the president took aim at the Merck executive.\n\nTrump replied swiftly to Frazier on Twitter, suggesting that stepping down from the council would give him \"more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nLater in the day, Trump explicitly condemned hate groups including neo-Nazis and the KKK, offering the kind of sharp denunciation of racism that many critics believed was lacking over the weekend.\n\nBut the president's remarks came too late for Frazier, who resigned early Monday.\n\nBy midday, Frazier was joined by a handful of other executives as a voice of dissent in the business community, which has particular sway of the president, himself a businessman.\n\nLloyd Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, posted a cryptic message on Twitter, quoting Abraham Lincoln.\n\n\"Lincoln: 'A house divided against itself cannot stand.' Isolate those who try to separate us. No equivalence w/ those who bring us together,\" Blankfein wrote.\n\nTim Cook, the chief executive of Apple, also posted a statement opposing white supremacy and racism.\n\n\"We've seen the terror of white supremacy & racist violence before. It's a moral issue -- an affront to America. We must all stand against it,\" Cook wrote.\n\nAnd at least one other chief executive -- albeit of a foreign company -- came to Frazier's defense. Paul Polman, the chief executive of Unilever, signaled his support for the Merck boss on Twitter.\n\n\"Thanks @Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is,\" Polman wrote.\n\nGeneral Electric said in a statement that it \"has no tolerance for hate, bigotry or racism,\" but added that its chairman and recently-retired chief executive, Jeff Immelt, will remain on the manufacturing council from which Frazier resigned.\n\nKevin Plank, Under Armour's chief executive, who is also on one of the president's advisory councils, issued a statement denouncing racism and discrimination. He stopped short of criticizing the president or his comments about Frazier.\n\nWith the exception of Frazier, no other major business leaders were explicitly distancing themselves from the president's advisory councils, or criticizing his response to the events in Charlottesville. Both Republican and Democratic lawmakers criticized the president's response, which some viewed as muted and equivocal.\n\nTom Glocer, the former chief executive of Thomson Reuters, offered his support for Frazier on Twitter and called for other chief executives to step down from the president's advisory councils. \"Ken has stood up for true American values,\" he said.\n\nThis is not the first time the president's actions have caused a chief executive to walk away from a seat on one of his advisory councils.\n\nIn February, as Trump began to implement stringent new immigration rules, Travis Kalanick, then the chief executive of Uber Technologies, left the president's economic advisory council.\n\nAnd after Trump said he would withdraw the United States from the Paris climate accord, Elon Musk, Tesla's chief, and Robert Iger, Disney's chief, stepped down from the President's Strategic and Policy Forum.\n\nEven after Musk and Iger walked away in the wake of the president's withdrawal from the Paris agreement, most other chief executives stuck with Trump.", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "time": "20:50:00", "originalArticle": null, "details": {}, "timeCrawl": {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T18:33:00Z", "url": "http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2017/08/instead-of-denouncing-white-nationalists-trump-attacks-merck-ceo-for-leaving-advisory-panel/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+motherjones%2Fmain+%28MotherJones.com+Main+Article+Feed%29", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Ken Frazier resigned amid the president's refusal to denounce white supremacy.\n\nPresident Donald Trump railed against Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier on Twitter Monday morning, shortly after the pharmaceuticals executive announced his decision to leave a White House advisory council in protest over the president's refusal to directly denounce white nationalists in the wake of the violence in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nNow that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council,he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\n\n-- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) August 14, 2017\n\nIn a statement explaining his exit from the president's manufacturing council, Frazier, who is African American, said he felt compelled to \"take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry, and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Frazier said.\n\nTrump has attracted bipartisan condemnation for failing to name and condemn the white supremacist groups responsible for the \"Unite the Right\" rally that turned deadly in Charlottesville over the weekend. One person was killed after being struck by a vehicle that rammed into a group of counterprotesters on Saturday. The suspect, James Alex Fields Jr. -- who was spotted among white nationalist activists over the weekend -- is being arraigned Monday on charges including murder. Separately, two state troopers died in a helicopter crash on Saturday while responding to the violence.\n\nThe president has instead blamed \"many sides\" for the violence, while repeatedly disregarding multiple reporters' questions on Saturday over whether he sought to condemn white nationalist groups that have expressed solidarity with Trump's agenda.\n\nPres. Trump ignores shouted question after remarks on Charlottesville: \"Do you want the support of these white nationalist groups?\" pic.twitter.com/qogS0RCM05\n\n-- ABC News (@ABC) August 12, 2017\n\nOne group, however, has lavished praise on the president's equivocal remarks: neo-Nazis themselves. \"Really, really good. God bless him,\" the white nationalist website the Daily Stormer said on Sunday.\n\nSince the events in Charlottesville, Ivanka Trump and Vice President Mike Pence have denounced the white supremacist groups. At the time, the White House hailed the council, including Frazier, as \"some of the world's most successful and creative business leaders.\"\n\nAt the group's first meeting in January, Trump shook {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T22:09:00Z", "url": "https://atlantadailyworld.com/2017/08/14/exec-resigns-from-presidents-council-and-trump-lashes-out/", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier wrote on Twitter Monday that \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which runs counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nFrazier is one of the few African Americans to head a Fortune 500 company.\n\nDrugmakers have come under withering criticism for soaring prices in the U.S., including by Trump, though he has yet to act on a promise to contain them.\n\nWith the barb, Trump appeared to attack an industry executive who has tried to make drug pricing somewhat more transparent by revealing his company's overall drug price changes.\n\nIn January, Merck reported that its average net prices -- the amount the company receives after discounts and other rebates -- increased in the years since 2010 in a range between 3.4 percent and 6.2 percent. That's about half as large as the increase in its retail prices.\n\nThe exchange lit up social media on Monday, with many people lauding Frazier and blasting the president.\n\nOther corporate executives aired support for Frazier as well.\n\nUnilever CEO Paul Polman wrote on Twitter, \"Thanks @Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is.\"\n\nFrazier, who grew up in a poor neighborhood in Philadelphia, resigned days after one person was killed and others wounded in violent clashes between White supremacists and protesters.\n\nFrazier and his siblings were raised by their janitor father after their mother died when he was very young. He has earned a reputation as a risk taker in the drug industry, pouring money into daunting research areas, particularly trying to develop a treatment for Alzheimer's disease.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned for the same reason from the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, which Trump established to advise him on how government policy impacts economic growth and job creation.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier this year as executives retire, are replaced, or, as with Frazier and Musk, resign.\n\nWilliam Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said he couldn't \"think of a parallel example\" of any president responding as viciously as Trump to a CEO departing an advisory council.\n\n\"Usually, certain niceties are observed to smooth over a rupture,\" said Galston, who served as a domestic policy aide in the Clinton administration.\n\n\"We've learned that as president, Mr. Trump is behaving exactly as he did as a candidate,\" Galston said. \"He knows only one mode: When attacked, hit back harder.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Economics Writer Josh Boak in Washington {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T17:39:00Z", "url": "https://federalnewsradio.com/government-news/2017/08/trump-mocks-exec-for-quitting-advisory-council-over-racism/", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "TRENTON, N.J. (AP) -- President Donald Trump lashed out at the CEO of the nation's third-largest pharmaceutical company after he resigned from a federal advisory council, citing the president's failure to immediately and explicitly rebuke the white nationalists who marched in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nBy early afternoon, the president did issue a direct condemnation of hate groups, but it did not appear to tamp down criticism that it was not done over the weekend when fringe groups clashed with protesters.\n\nMerck CEO Kenneth Frazier wrote on Twitter Monday that \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which runs counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nFrazier is one of the few African Americans to head a Fortune 500 company.\n\nSponsored Content: Sign up for a free webinar as the U.S. Trade and Development Agency and Small Business Administration explore the hybrid IT environment in government.\n\nTrump mocked the executive almost immediately following the resignation, saying on Twitter that Frazier will now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nDrugmakers have come under withering criticism for soaring prices in the U.S., including by Trump, though he has yet to act on a promise to contain them.\n\nWith the barb, Trump appeared to attack an industry executive who has tried to make drug pricing somewhat more transparent by revealing his company's overall drug price changes.\n\nIn January, Merck reported that its average net prices -- the amount the company receives after discounts and other rebates -- increased in the years since 2010 in a range between 3.4 percent and 6.2 percent. That's about half as large as the increase in its retail prices.\n\nThe exchange lit up social media on Monday, with many people lauding Frazier and blasting the president.\n\nOther corporate executives aired support for Frazier as well.\n\nPostal Service may be able to raise price of stamps this fall\n\nUnilever CEO Paul Polman wrote on Twitter, \"Thanks @Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is.\"\n\nFrazier, who grew up in a poor neighborhood in Philadelphia, resigned days after one person was killed and others wounded in violent clashes between white supremacists and protesters.\n\nFrazier and his siblings were raised by their janitor father after their mother died when he was very young. He has earned a reputation as a risk taker in the drug industry, pouring money into daunting research areas, particularly trying to develop a treatment for Alzheimer's disease.\n\nFrazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned for the same reason from the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, which Trump established to advise him on how government policy impacts economic growth and job creation.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier this year as executives retire, are replaced, or, as with Frazier and Musk, resign.\n\nWilliam Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said he couldn't \"think of a parallel example\" of any president responding as viciously as Trump to a CEO departing an advisory council.\n\n\"Usually, certain niceties are observed to smooth over a rupture,\" said Galston, who served as a domestic policy aide in the Clinton administration.\n\n\"We've learned that as president, Mr. Trump is behaving exactly as he did as a candidate,\" Galston said. \"He knows only one mode: When attacked, hit back harder.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Economics Writer Josh Boak in Washington contributed to this story.\n\n___\n\nFollow Linda A. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T19:10:00Z", "url": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/donald-trump-slams-drug-firm-ceo-following-resignation-from-advisory-council-36030464.html", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/article36030463.ece/60225/AUTOCROP/h342/PANews%20BT_P-b5743587-88d6-4828-a537-4bf77ac4e4f6_I1.jpg\n\nDonald Trump has lashed out at the CEO of the USA's third-largest pharmaceutical company who resigned from a federal advisory council because of the US president's failure to immediately and explicitly rebuke white nationalists who marched in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nBy early afternoon on Monday, Mr Trump did issue a direct condemnation of hate groups, but it did not appear to tamp down criticism that it was not done over the weekend when fringe groups clashed with protesters.\n\nMerck CEO Kenneth Frazier wrote on Twitter on Monday: \"America's leaders must honour our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which runs counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nMr Frazier is one of the few African Americans to head a Fortune 500 company.\n\nMr Trump mocked the executive almost immediately following the resignation, saying on Twitter that Mr Frazier will now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nDrug makers have come under withering criticism for soaring prices in the US, including by Mr Trump, though he has yet to act on a promise to contain them.\n\nWith the barb, Mr Trump appeared to attack an industry executive who has tried to make drug pricing somewhat more transparent by revealing his company's overall drug price changes.\n\nIn January, Merck reported that its average net prices - the amount the company receives after discounts and other rebates - increased in the years since 2010 in a range between 3.4% and 6.2%. That is about half as large as the increase in its retail prices.\n\nThe exchange lit up social media on Monday, with many people lauding Mr Frazier and blasting the president.\n\nOther corporate executives aired support for Mr Frazier as well.\n\nUnilever CEO Paul Polman wrote on Twitter: \"Thanks @Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is.\"\n\nMr Frazier, who grew up in a poor neighbuorhood in Philadelphia, resigned days after one person was killed and others wounded in violent clashes between white supremacists and protesters.\n\nMr Frazier and his siblings were raised by their caretaker father after their mother died when he was very young. He has earned a reputation as a risk taker in the drug industry, pouring money into daunting research areas, particularly trying to develop a treatment for Alzheimer's disease.\n\nMr Frazier is not the first executive to resign from advisory councils serving Mr Trump.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the US withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Company chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned for the same reason from the president's Strategic and Policy Forum, which Mr Trump established to advise him on how government policy impacts economic growth and job creation.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier this year as executives retire, are replaced, or, as with Mr Frazier and Mr Musk, resign.\n\nWilliam Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said he could not \"think of a parallel example\" of any president responding as viciously as Mr Trump to a CEO departing an advisory council.\n\n\"Usually, certain niceties are observed to smooth over a rupture,\" said Mr Galston, who served as a domestic policy aide in the Clinton administration.\n\n\"We've learned that as president, Mr Trump is behaving exactly as he did as a candidate,\" Mr Galston said. \"He knows only one mode: When attacked, hit back harder.\"", {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T17:06:00Z", "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/14/business/merck-trump-ceos.html", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Kenneth C. Frazier, chief executive of Merck, the pharmaceuticals company, on Monday resigned from President Trump's American Manufacturing Council after the president failed to directly condemn the white nationalist protesters at the center of violent protests in Charlottesville, Va., over the weekend.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Mr. Frazier said in a statement. \"As C.E.O. of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against extremism.\"\n\nLess than an hour later, the president took aim at the Merck executive.\n\nMr. Trump replied swiftly to Mr. Frazier on Twitter, suggesting that stepping down from the council would give him \"more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nBy midday Monday, Mr. Frazier was joined by a handful of other executives as a voice of dissent in the business community, which has particular sway of the president, himself a businessman.\n\nLloyd Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, posted a cryptic message on Twitter, quoting Abraham Lincoln.\n\nTim Cook, the chief executive of Apple, also posted a statement opposing white supremacy and racism.\n\nAnd at least one other chief executive -- albeit of a foreign company -- came to Mr. Frazier's defense. Paul Polman, the chief executive of Unilever, signaled his support for the Merck boss on Twitter.\n\nBut with the exception of Mr. Frazier, no other major business leaders were explicitly distancing themselves from the president's advisory councils, or criticizing his response to the events in Charlottesville. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T15:58:00Z", "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/merck-boss-quits-trump-council-over-charlottesville-1.3186394", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Merck's chief executive Ken Frazier on Monday resigned from a White House advisory body in protest over Donald Trump's failure to denounce white nationalists for provoking clashes over the weekend in which one protester died\n\nMerck's chief executive Ken Frazier on Monday resigned from a White House advisory body in protest over Donald Trump's failure to denounce white nationalists for provoking clashes over the weekend in which one protester died.\n\nIn a statement from the US drugmaker posted on Twitter, Mr Frazier said he was stepping down from the president's American Manufacturing Council \"as a matter of personal conscience\" adding: \"I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism\".\n\nAlthough the statement did not mention the president by name, Mr Frazier, who is African American, left no doubt it was aimed at Mr Trump. \"America's leaders must honour our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\n\nAn hour after Merck posted the statement on its Twitter feed, Mr Trump replied: \"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nMr Frazier's stand comes amid mounting criticism of Mr Trump's handling of the clashes in Virginia over the weekend between far-right demonstrators and counter-protesters.\n\nWhite House aides were forced to defend the president after he blamed \"many sides\" for the clashes in Charlottesville on Saturday but failed to condemn and name the Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazi groups whose members were at the centre of the violence.\n\nMr Frazier's decision drew out several other business leaders. Goldman Sachs chief executive Lloyd Blankfein weighed in on Twitter, appearing to criticise the White House. Citing former US president Abraham Lincoln, who led the country during the Civil War, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs tweeted: \"Lincoln: 'A house divided against itself cannot stand.' Isolate those who try to separate us. No equivalence w/ those who bring us together.\"\n\nPaul Polman, the chief executive of Unilever, welcomed Mr Frazier's decision. The 61-year-old Dutch national, who has spent much of his career in the US and has an American wife, tweeted: \"Thanks @Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is.\"\n\nMr Frazier is not the first big business leader to resign from the White House advisory bodies set up by Mr Trump. In June, Tesla founder Elon Musk and Disney's chief executive Bob Iger quit over the president's decision to take the US out of the Paris climate accord.\n\nEarlier this year, the president hit out at the pharmaceutical industry over the high prices of drugs, accusing the sector of \"getting away with murder\". Mr Trump is expected to sign an executive order targeting drug pricing at some point this year, although the industry has been anticipating it would be more benign than feared.", "location": null, {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T19:48:00Z", "url": "https://newpittsburghcourieronline.com/2017/08/14/exec-resigns-from-presidents-council-and-trump-lashes-out/", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Trump, who is under increasing pressure to explicitly condemn the White supremacist and hate groups involved, lashed out almost immediately Monday at Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier on Twitter, saying that because of the resignation, the pharmaceutical executive \"will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nBy early afternoon, the president did issue a direct condemnation of hate groups, but it did not appear to tamp down criticism that it was not done over the weekend when fringe groups clashed with protesters.\n\nFrazier is one of the few African Americans to head a Fortune 500 company.\n\nDrugmakers have come under withering criticism for soaring prices in the U.S., including by Trump, though he has yet to act on a promise to contain them.\n\nWith the barb, Trump appeared to attack an industry executive who has tried to make drug pricing somewhat more transparent by revealing his company's overall drug price changes.\n\nIn January, Merck reported that its average net prices -- the amount the company receives after discounts and other rebates -- increased in the years since 2010 in a range between 3.4 percent and 6.2 percent. That's about half as large as the increase in its retail prices.\n\nThe exchange lit up social media on Monday, with many people lauding Frazier and blasting the president.\n\nOther corporate executives aired support for Frazier as well.\n\nUnilever CEO Paul Polman wrote on Twitter, \"Thanks @Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is.\"\n\nFrazier, who grew up in a poor neighborhood in Philadelphia, resigned days after one person was killed and others wounded in violent clashes between White supremacists and protesters.\n\nFrazier and his siblings were raised by their janitor father after their mother died when he was very young. He has earned a reputation as a risk taker in the drug industry, pouring money into daunting research areas, particularly trying to develop a treatment for Alzheimer's disease.\n\nTesla CEO Elon Musk resigned from the manufacturing council in June, and two other advisory groups to the president, after the U.S. withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned for the same reason from the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, which Trump established to advise him on how government policy impacts economic growth and job creation.\n\nThe manufacturing jobs council had 28 members initially, but it has shrunk since it was formed earlier this year as executives retire, are replaced, or, as with Frazier and Musk, resign.\n\nWilliam Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said he couldn't \"think of a parallel example\" of any president responding as viciously as Trump to a CEO departing an advisory council.\n\n\"Usually, certain niceties are observed to smooth over a rupture,\" said Galston, who served as a domestic policy aide in the Clinton administration.\n\n\"We've learned that as president, Mr. Trump is behaving exactly as he did as a candidate,\" Galston said. \"He knows only one mode: When attacked, hit back harder.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Economics Writer Josh Boak in Washington {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T18:08:00Z", "url": "http://perezhilton.com/2017-08-14-donald-trump-charlottesville-white-nationalist-ken-frazier-resign-american-manufacturing-council", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Donald Trump didn't have a whole lot to say about the deadly white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Virginia over the weekend.\n\nUnsurprisingly, the president's initial non-response -- a vague tweet condemning \"hate\" instead of denouncing white nationalism -- caused a whole lot of backlash, which POTUS continued to stay silent for. That is, until Big Pharma mogul Ken Frazier publicly resigned from the American Manufacturing Council -- and you better believe that got Trump talking!\n\nRelated: Too Little, Too Late, Ivanka Trump\n\nOn Monday, the Merck CEO released a statement announcing his resignation to take \"a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nBut before the president got to denouncing the neo-Nazis and the KKK rallying in the name of white supremacy, he jumped at the opportunity to lash out at Frazier, who is black, with a boardroom-style dig, writing:\n\nNow that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council,he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\n\n-- Donald J. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T19:23:00Z", "url": "https://www.reuters.com/video/2017/08/14/merck-ceo-pulls-out-of-trump-panel?videoId=372319148&videoChannel=5", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Merck's chief executive, Kenneth Frazier, resigned from American Manufacturing Council led by Donald Trump in a strong rebuke to the U.S. president over his response to a violent white nationalist rally in Virginia. Fred Katayama reports.\n\nMerck's chief executive, Kenneth Frazier, quit president Donald Trump's American Manufacturing Council Monday. He took that action over Trump's response to a white nationalist rally in Charlottesville, Virginia, over the weekend. Frazier wrote in a post on Merck's Twitter account: \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\" During the rally, a Nazi sympathizer drove a car into a crowd, killing one person and injuring 19 others. Overall, more than 30 people were injured in separate incidents. Two state police officers died in a helicopter crash after helping quell the unrest. Frazier's departure added to the many voices from both parties, Democrats and Republicans, saying that Trump waited too long to address the violence. They also blasted him for not condemning white-supremacist marchers widely seen as responsible for brutality. Trump responded to Frazier's resignation tweet on the same medium an hour later. He said: \"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\" Under pressure to take a stronger stand against right-wing extremists, the White House issued a statement on Sunday. It said Trump condemns \"all forms of violence, bigotry and hatred, and, of course, that includes white supremacists, Ku Klux Klan, neo-Nazi, and all extremist groups.\"", "location": null,
