{"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T17:19:00Z", "url": "https://finance.yahoo.com/news/trump-just-put-mercks-ceo-150716040.html", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "(Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier, speaking in 2015.AP)\n\nPresident Donald Trump called out Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier after he resigned from the president's manufacturing council, saying that Frazier will have more time to lower drug prices.Merck, a major pharmaceutical company, hasn't been among the drugmakers called out for hiking the price of prescription drugs and has taken steps to be more transparent about how it sets prices.\n\nMerck's CEO Kenneth Frazier left the president's manufacturing council, after the Trump administration failed to explicitly denounce white nationalism after violence erupted over the weekend in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nAlmost immediately, President Donald Trump fired back, turning the conversation toward drug pricing. Trump has been vocal about the rising price of prescription drugs, though he has been largely quiet on the topic in the past few months apart from a reported draft drug pricing executive order.\n\nTrump said in a tweet that now Frazier has resigned, \"he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nMerck, which known for its cancer immunotherapy drug Keytruda and its vaccines business, has not been among the pharmaceutical companies that have been called out for hiking the prices of prescription drugs. That's unlike the makers of the emergency allergy medication EpiPen, companies that make a life-saving diabetes medication, and, perhaps the most infamous, the company that raised the price of a decades-old drug to treat a parasitic infection by 5,000%.\n\nHere's Merck's track record with drug pricingIn January, Merck published a report that outlined the company's average list price increases for its products. Merck was one of only a handful of big pharmaceutical companies to disclose, alongside the list price, the net prices -- or the amount Merck actually receives after factoring in rebates and other discounts that drugmakers payout. In 2016, Merck raised prices by an average of 9.6%. But after factoring in rebates, that was just 5.5% (a rate that's still higher than the rate of inflation). \"We've taken a close look at our pricing practices - and we believe we have a good track record,\" Adam Schechter, president of global human health at Merck wrote in an accompanying post in January. \"Since 2010, Merck's average net price increase across our portfolio each year has been in the low to mid-single digits: specifically, 3.4 percent to 6.2 percent.\"Frazier has also been quick to distance himself from companies and individuals like former pharmaceutical CEO Martin Shkreli that jack up the price of prescription drugs.\"He is not us,\" Frazier said at a 2015 industry conference.Which isn't to say Merck isn't a profitable corporation. In the second quarter of 2017, Keytruda, Merck's blockbuster cancer immunotherapy drug that first hit the market in 2014, generated $881 million in sales. A treatment course of cancer immunotherapy can cost more than $100,000, depending on how long patients stay on the drug.Some drug companies have committed to only single-digit list price increases, or other caps on the list price. Merck hasn't been among the companies that have made such promises.\n\nNOW WATCH: Fidelity sector expert: Reports of a stock bubble are exaggerated\n\nMore From Business Insider\n\nHere's what was in {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T21:56:00Z", "url": "http://www.baltimoresun.com/business/under-armour-blog/bs-bz-kevin-plank-charlottesville-trump-20170814-story.html", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Under Armour CEO Kevin Plank said the company was \"saddened\" by the violence at a white nationalist rally in Charlottesville, Va., but remained mum about President Donald J. Trump's advisory jobs panel after another CEO resigned in protest.\n\nEarlier Monday, Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier said he was leaving the Manufacturing Jobs Initiative committee, citing the president's failure to explicitly denounce those groups that marched in the rally.\n\n\"I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism,\" said Frazier, calling on America's leaders -- including Trump -- to clearly reject \"expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy.\"\n\nIn January, Frazier and Plank were named to the 28-member panel established by the White House to promote job growth.\n\nIn resigning, Frazier was responding to Trump's slowness in clearly denouncing groups who rallied over the weekend in Charlottesville.\n\nAppearing later Monday, Trump labeled members of the KKK, neo-Nazis and white supremacists who participate in violence as \"criminals and thugs.\"\n\nNineteen people were injured and a woman was killed when a car plowed into counter-protesters. Another dozen or so people were injured in clashes between white nationalists and counter-protesters and two state troopers were killed when their helicopter, which was monitoring the rally, crashed.\n\n\"We are saddened by #Charlottesville,\" Plank said on Under Armour's Twitter account. \"There is no place for racism or discrimination in this world. We choose love & unity.\"\n\nSpokespersons for Plank and Under Armour did not return calls or messages on whether the CEO would remain on the panel.\n\nBy mid-afternoon on Monday, a few hundred people had responded to Plank's message on Twitter, many of them urging him to quit the advisory group.\n\n\"Please keep us loyal to your brand by resigning from Trump's board,\" wrote one.\n\n\"Our family's long loyalty to UA ends today,\" wrote another.\n\nThe social media debate echoed one Under Armour faced in February after Plank was asked about Trump during a televised interview. Plank, who has contributed in the past both to Republican and Democratic elected officials in federal and state posts, told CNBC that having \"such a pro-business president is something that's a real asset to this country.\"\n\nA number of celebrity Under Armour endorsers -- including basketball star Stephen Curry and ballerina Misty Copeland -- released statements saying they did not agree with Plank's assessment.\n\n\"We engage in policy, not politics,\" Under Armour said at the time.\n\nTrump was quick to rebuke Frazier on Monday, lashing out on Twitter that the pharmaceuticals company CEO will now \"have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nWith the barb, Trump appeared to attack an industry executive who has tried to make drug pricing somewhat more transparent by revealing his company's overall drug price changes.\n\nFrazier is one of the few African Americans to head a Fortune 500 company.\n\nOthers on the White House manufacturing council include top executives from Boeing, Dell Technologies, Dow Chemical and Johnson & Johnson.\n\nLike Plank, the other CEOs faced calls on social media Monday to resign, but none did.\n\nDow CEO Andrew Liveris issued a statement condemning the violence in Charlottesville and saying the company \"will continue to work to strengthen the social and economic fabric of the communities where it operates -- including supporting policies that help create employment opportunities in manufacturing and rebuild the American workforce.\"\n\nAnother panel member, Brian Krzanich of Intel, tweeted: \"There should be no hesitation in condemning hate speech or white supremacy by name.\"\n\nIn February, Uber CEO Travis Kalanick left the advisory group and said his participation had not meant that he favored the president's policies.\n\nElon Musk, CEO of SpaceX and Tesla, resigned from the council and two other presidential advisory groups in June after Trump vowed to exit the Paris climate agreement. Walt Disney Co. Chairman and CEO Bob Iger resigned for the same reason from the President's Strategic and Policy Forum, which Trump established to advise him on how government policy impacts economic growth and job creation.\n\nWilliam Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said he couldn't \"think of a parallel example\" of any president responding as viciously as Trump did to a CEO departing an advisory council.\n\n\"Usually, certain niceties are observed to smooth over a rupture,\" said Galston, who served as a domestic policy aide in the Clinton administration.\n\n\"We've learned that as president, Mr. Trump is behaving exactly as he did as a candidate,\" Galston said. \"He knows only one mode: When attacked, hit back harder.\"\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\njebarker@baltsun.com\n\ntwitter.com/sunjeffbarker", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "time": "21:56:00", "originalArticle": null, "details": {}, "timeCrawl": "21:56:00", "title": {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T20:04:00Z", "url": "https://www.good.is/articles/frazier-quits-trump-council-charlottesville", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "In the wake of the horrible act of white supremacist terrorism that struck Charlottesville, Virginia, on Saturday, President Trump blew the single easiest thing a president could do: condemn Nazis. Instead, Trump gave a vague response saying there were \"many sides\" to blame, while the only two sides on display were neo-Nazis and those who stood against their hatred and violence. After his speech, when reporters asked about the white supremacists who supported his candidacy, Trump sauntered away from the podium, ignoring their questions.\n\nTrump has a history of specifically calling out those who oppose him on Twitter, but for two days he remained completely silent on the KKK, \"alt-right,\" neo-Nazis, and white supremacists who gathered in Charlottesville. Although the White House did release a statement that said \"of course\" Trump's condemnation included \"white supremacists, KKK Neo-Nazi and all extremist groups,\" the statement was attributed to an unnamed spokesperson.\n\nTrump's inaction prompted Merck CEO Ken Frazier to step down from the president's council on manufacturing. He released a statement through Merck's Twitter page saying his decision is \"a matter of personal conscience\" and \"to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\" Frazier is the second African-American to lead a major pharmaceutical company and has a history of working for social justice as an attorney.\n\nWhile Trump had yet to condemn white supremacists, he wasted no time going after Frazier on Twitter.\n\nTrump's decision to criticize an African-American man standing up against intolerance before attacking the perpetrators of racist violence shows a someone with a broken -- if not completely nonexistent -- moral compass. On Monday, Trump finally condemned white supremacists, saying, \"Racism is evil -- and those who cause violence in its name are criminals and thugs, including KKK, Neo-Nazis, white supremacists, and other hate groups are repugnant to everything we hold dear as Americans.\" But coming from a man who rose to political power perpetrating the \"birther\" conspiracy, calling Mexicans \"rapists,\" and scapegoating Muslims, his worlds couldn't ring more hollow.\n\nFrazier isn't the only big-business executive to quit one of Trump's advisory councils. Tesla and SpaceX CEO Elon Musk quit three of President Trump's business advisory councils after he pulled out of the Paris climate agreement in June. \"Climate change is real. Leaving Paris is not good for America or the world,\" Musk said. Disney CEO Bob Iger followed suit and left an advisory council for the same reason, calling it \"a matter of principle.\" Trump refrained from attacking them on Twitter.", "location": null, {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T16:18:00Z", "url": "https://www.inverse.com/article/35477-merck-ceo-resigns-kenneth-frazier-trump-charlottesville", "sim": 0.5098039507865906, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "One advisor finally got the message behind Trump's refusal to explicitly condemn white nationalists.\n\nThe president's attempt to avoid alienating racists backfired Saturday, but reactions have proved that Trump's sidestep hasn't gone unnoticed.\n\nDonald Trump's statement citing violence \"on many sides\" of the Unite the Right protests in Charlottesville this weekend proved to be too much for Kenneth Frazier, CEO of Merck & Co., a pharmaceutical company. Frazier resigned from Donald Trump's American Manufacturing Council on Monday.\n\nOne woman, Heather Heyer, was killed when a terrorist slammed his car into a group of counter-protestors. Nineteen others sustained injuries in the crash. Additionally, two state troopers perished in a helicopter crash now considered to be a part of the events in Charlottesville, because Lt. H. Jay Cullen and Trooper Berke M. M. Bates were monitoring the violence from above.\n\nNotably, the governor of Virginia, Terry McAuliffe, blamed white supremacists and Nazis for every death and injury over the weekend, saying, \"Go home. You are not wanted in this great commonwealth. You pretend that you are patriots, but you are anything but patriots,\" during a press conference.\n\nTrump's lack of specific criticism towards or disavowing of literal Nazis provoked bipartisan outrage. Politicians like Bernie Sanders, Hillary Clinton, Marco Rubio and even fucking Jeff Sessions all denounced the violence perpetrated by white nationalists in Charlottesville as acts of domestic terrorism.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy,\" Frazier said in a statement explaining his resignation.\n\nPredictably, Trump lashed out against Frazier after Frazier announced his departure via Twitter.\n\nThis is not the first time that Trump's conduct has repulsed those who serve on his advisory councils, and is unlikely the last time either.\n\nSix members of the Presidential Advisory Council on HIV/AIDS also resigned in June, after it became clear that \"the policies promoted by this administration, including the substantial Medicaid budget cuts, are grossly antagonistic to the health of people with HIV,\" according to Dr. Ada Adimora, a doctor who actually stayed on the council.\n\nElon Musk and Disney CEO Robert Iger both quit White House business advisory councils in June following Trump's decision to withdraw from the Paris Agreement.\n\nThe president clarified his initial comments in a six-minute statement on Monday, condemning violence in \"the strongest possible terms\" and calling racism \"evil,\" but maintained his refusal to call the acts terrorism, Vision courtesy: Channel 7's Sunrise\n\nUp Next Trump criticised over Charlottesville response Trump criticised over Charlottesville ... Trump criticised over Charlottesville response\n\nAs US authorities begin to investigate the deadly violence stemming from a white nationalist rally in Virginia, many are attacking the Presidents' comments for being too tame.\n\nMore videos Rally organiser mobbed by protesters\n\n'Unite the Right' march organiser, Jason Kessler, ran for his life after an angry crowd stormed a news conference in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nSeveral of the president's top advisers, including his new chief of staff, John Kelly, pressed Mr Trump to issue a more forceful rebuke after his comment Saturday that the violence in Charlottesville was initiated by \"many sides,\" prompting nearly universal criticism.\n\nThat pressure reached a boiling point early Monday after the president attacked the head of Merck pharmaceuticals, who is black, for quitting an advisory board over his failure to call out white nationalists.\n\nRelated Articles Trump fires back after CEO resigns over Virginia violence After violence in Charlottesville, vigils for peace and healing\n\nMerck's chief executive, Kenneth C. Frazier, resigned from the president's American Manufacturing Council on Monday, saying he objected to the president's statement Saturday blaming violence that left one woman dead on \"many sides.\"\n\n\"America's leaders must honour our fundamental views by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal,\" Mr Frazier said in a tweet announcing he was stepping down from the panel.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nMr Frazier is one of just a handful of black chief executives of a Fortune 500 company.\n\nYou will now receive updates from Breaking News Alert Breaking News Alert\n\nGet the latest news and updates emailed straight to your inbox.\n\nBy submitting your email you are agreeing to Fairfax Media's terms and conditions and privacy policy .\n\nLess than an hour later, Mr Trump responded on social media as he departed his golf resort in Bedminster, New Jersey, for a day trip back to Washington.\n\n\"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\" the president wrote.\n\nMr Trump's shot at one of the country's best-known black executives prompted an immediate outpouring of support for Frazier from major figures in business, media and politics.\n\n\"Thanks @Merck Ken Frazier for strong leadership to stand up for the moral values that made this country what it is,\" Paul Polman, the chief executive of Unilever, wrote on Twitter.\n\nIt's not unusual for Mr Trump to attack, via Twitter, any public figure who ridicules, criticises or even mildly questions his actions. But his decision to take on Mr Frazier, a self-made multimillionaire who rose from a modest childhood in Philadelphia to attend Harvard Law School, was extraordinary given the wide-ranging criticism he has faced from both parties for not forcefully denouncing the neo-Nazis and Klan sympathisers who rampaged in Charlottesville.\n\nMr Frazier appeared next to Mr Trump at the White House last month to announce an agreement among drugmakers that would create 1,000 jobs.\n\nHe is only the second African-American executive to lead a major pharmaceutical firm and rose in prominence as Merck's general counsel when he successfully defended the company against class-action lawsuits stemming from complications involving the anti-inflammatory drug Vioxx.\n\n\"It took Trump 54 minutes to condemn Merck CEO Ken Frazier, but after several days he still has not condemned murdering white supremacists,\" Keith Boykin, a former aide to President Bill Clinton who comments on politics and race for CNN, wrote in a tweet.\n\nMr Frazier's exit from the business council marks a mini-exodus of business leaders, resulting from the president's stances on social issues and the environment. His recent decision to leave the Paris climate accord prompted Elon Musk of Tesla to resign, as did the chief executive of Disney, Bob Iger, and Lloyd Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs.\n\nCar attack suspect refused bail\n\nA Virginia judge on Monday declined to set bail for James Alex Fields jnr, the 20-year-old Ohio man accused of second-degree murder and other charges after authorities said he ploughed his car into a crowd of counter-protesters near the scene of the white supremacist rally.\n\nThat means Fields, whom news reports have described as fascinated by Nazism, will remain jailed at least until he has an attorney.\n\nJames Alex Fields jnr, second from left, holds a black shield at the rally in Charlottesville. Photo: AP\n\nThe local public defenders' office informed the court it could not represent him because of a potential conflict of interest - someone in the office has a relative who was hurt during Saturday's violence in Charlottesville.\n\nA local attorney will be appointed to represent Fields and could request bail before the next scheduled hearing, August 25.\n\nFields, clad in a black-and-white striped uniform, appeared via video link for the hearing. He briefly responded to questions from Judge Robert Downer, replying \"No, sir,\" when asked if he had any ties to the Charlottesville community.\n\nSaturday's car rampage killed 32-year-old Heather Heyer, who was among the crowd of counter-protesters responding to the rally by white nationalists and others who oppose a plan to remove from a Charlottesville park of a statue of Confederate General Robert E. Lee. Fields was taken into custody soon afterward.\n\nNew York Times, McClatchy", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textEnd": 7227, "textStart": 7218, "amb": false, "date": {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T14:05:00Z", "url": "http://www.barrons.com/articles/merck-trump-tweetsand-no-one-cares-1502726509", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier has drawn the ire of President Trump over his resignation from an advisory council.\n\nThe ongoing controversy over drug prices hurtled back into the news today, entering through the doorway that is President Donald J. Trump's Twitter account.\n\nIllustration: Getty Images\n\nKenneth Frazier, the chairman and chief executive of U.S. pharmaceutical giant Merck & Co. (MRK), stepped down from a manufacturing council that advises President Trump following a weekend of violence at a white nationalist and neo-Nazi protest in Charlottesville, Virginia. His concern: The president did not explicitly condemn the actions of white supremacists.\n\nFrazier, who is African American and has been photographed sitting next to Trump at White House meetings, said in a tweet on Monday that U.S. leaders must \"honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy.\"\n\nPresident Trump lashed back on Twitter within the hour, saying that because of his resignation, Fraizer \"will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES.\"\n\nThe pharmaceutical industry has come under scrutiny for its pricing practices. Merck, however, has not been set upon by lawmakers. And if the company's rising stock price is any indication, Trump's tweet has been written off by investors: At a recent $62.91, shares of Merck rose nearly 1%, almost in line with the S&P 500's 1.05% gain. The iShares U.S. Pharmaceuticals ETF (IHE) inched 0.6% higher to $149.07 a share and the iShares Nasdaq Biotech ETF (IBB) rose 1.1% today to $309.88 a share.\n\nThis is certainly not the first time that President Trump has let loose about drug prices. Yet as a hot button topics go, it no longer seems to deliver the same punch it did earlier this year. It is especially ineffective against Merck because the company voluntarily released information about drug-pricing practices earlier this year. In fact, today's debate has instead focused on Trump's attack on Frazier.\n\nFrazier is not the first CEO to exit such a position. Both Tesla (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk and Walt Disney Co. (DIS) CEO Robert Iger walked away from advisory panels in June after President Trump pulled out of the Paris climate agreement.\n\nGranted, 2017 has been a benign year for Merck's stock. Up almost 7% since Dec. 31, the shares have lagged the broader market, as it recovers from a recent cyberattack. Still, Merck's immunotherapy drug Keytruda has been a big success for the company. Add to that, an experimental cholesterol-lowering drug and other pipeline prospects, and there are strong catalysts capable of lifting Merck's share price higher over the next year.\n\nJust ask Credit Suisse analyst Vamil Divan and his team. The analysts regard Merck as their top pick among big-cap drug makers.\n\nMRK remains our Top Pick with ESMO, KN-189 data upcoming. We continue to see MRK as a top pick in US Pharma as Keytruda gains traction both in 1st line non-small cell lung cancer (both in monotherapy and in combination with chemotherapy) and various other indications. ESMO will be a relatively quieter meeting for MRK this year from a data perspective but we expect continued discussion around the potential uses of Keytruda while awaiting the topline data from the confirmatory KEYNOTE-189 study in the Sept/Oct timeframe, which we expect to be positive. The need to recover from the recent cyber-attack will likely take away some of the potential near-term earnings upside but, on a fundamental level, we see MRK as the best positioned company in our Reuters\n\nTo the CEOs who joined President Trump's manufacturing council in the hope of advising the president about what's good for America's private sector I have one thing to say.\n\nStop playing yourselves. Now is the time.\n\nIn the past 24 hours, Trump has proven that he not only doesn't care about the values of the American workplace, but also that he doesn't respect your opinion about what those values should be.\n\nI'm sure you're all aware of the heinous events that transpired in Charlottesville, Virginia this weekend when white supremacists and fascists of various strains descended on the city to put their violence and bigotry on display for the world to see. An American died there, and all Trump had for her were a few pithy words about how there was blame to go around on all sides.\n\nAnd then on Monday when Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier, one of the few black CEO's on the council, resigned over Trump's absurd response to what transpired, Trump did what he is known to do. He went on a Twitter rampage.\n\n\"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES,\" he tweeted.\n\nLet's put aside the fact that Merck is one of the most transparent drug companies around.\n\nAnd we'll even put aside that Frazier is black, and the fact that none of the white CEO's on the manufacturing council have followed him out the door speaks volumes.\n\nWhat's more important to focus on for our purposes is that a number of CEO's said they joined this manufacturing council to help the president make better decisions about American business. That obviously isn't happening.\n\nBusiness leaders will tell you that discrimination creates a hostile work environment, so any business minded politician should care about that. They should care that people qualified and ready to work feel safe when they do so. This has become a value, a norm in American business.\n\nThat is why you see some of the people who participated in the Charlottesville protests getting fired from their jobs. In America, we have decided that no one has a right to make anyone else feel uncomfortable in their place of business because of their race or religion, and that business owners have a right to make sure of that.\n\nThis shouldn't have to be articulated to the President of the United States.\n\nBut if you think you can articulate it, you're playing yourself. Trump isn't really taking the advice of the CEO's who he's surrounded himself with in these photo ops.\n\nWe've already seen some examples of this. Tesla CEO Elon Musk left the council after he said the US would back out of the Paris climate accord. Former Uber CEO Travis Kalanick left after the controversial immigration \"ban.\"\n\nBoth men tried to argue that they joined because thought they could advise the President.\n\nHis decisions made it obvious that that was not the case. Their advice never mattered. They couldn't change Trump's mind about a policy once it was set. Think about it: His closest advisors barely can move him, let alone people outside the White House. Remember how he steamrolled them (and business leaders) with his decision to leave the Paris Climate Accord.\n\nSo CEOs: save the \"But I'm helping him\" excuses for someone else.\n\nNow maybe you, a millionaire CEO, are afraid of a tweet from Trump. That is the impression at least one cowardly CEO gave the New York Times' Andrew Ross Sorkin:\n\nWhen I asked one chief executive Monday morning why he had remained publicly silent, he told me: \"Just look at what he did to Ken. I'm not sticking my head up.\" Which, of course, is the reason he said I could not quote him by name.\n\nWow.\n\nOne of the scariest things about American capitalism is that CEOs can sometimes rule like kings (watch a board try to unseat JPMorgan's Jamie Dimon and see what happens) while presidents get elected every four years. Think about that for a second.\n\nOr maybe you're on the council because you think you can play Trump's game. Frazier, perhaps, thought it would be better to have a seat at the table as Trump talked drug pricing and health care.\n\nMaybe you think that, like Boeing, you can petition the President to move against your foreign rivals (in Boeing's case, Bombardier) for the benefit of your company.\n\nIt's a cynical trick, but at least it makes sense.\n\nIt's not worth it. Trump's trade policy has been nothing but disarray so far, just like the rest of his policies. If you play this game maybe you'll get a nice tariff or some tough talk against your competitors, but none of that lasts forever.\n\nYou know what does? Photos of you sitting around a table with a President who doesn't care what you say. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T22:55:00Z", "url": "https://www.cnbc.com/2017/08/14/jamie-dimon-says-racist-behavior-has-no-place-in-america-in-note-on-charlottesville.html", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon called the attack in Charlottesville, Virginia, over the weekend a disturbing display of bigotry and violence.\n\nOne person was killed and 19 others injured when a white supremacist allegedly rammed a car into counterprotesters on Saturday.\n\nIn a message to U.S. employees, Dimon said such violence is unacceptable in America.\n\n\"The racist behavior on display by these perpetrators of hate should be condemned and has no place in a country that draws strength from our diversity and humanity,\" wrote Dimon, who is also chairman of Business Roundtable.\n\nIn a separate statement co-authored by Dimon, Business Roundtable said that its CEOs \"will never accept such intolerance and hate\" as demonstrated in Charlottesville over the weekend.\n\n\"Racism has no place in our businesses, our communities or our country,\" the group said in a statement.\n\nIn the first 48 hours, President Donald Trump faced bipartisan criticism for failing to explicitly condemn white supremacists in the wake of the attack in Charlottesville. On Saturday, Trump condemned hatred and violence \"on many sides,\" but he did not specifically denounce white supremacist groups.\n\nOn Monday morning, Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier resigned from the president's American Manufacturing Council in protest to Trump's initial response to the violence. Trump immediately lashed out at the drug executive on Twitter.\n\nThe president tweeted that Frazier's resignation will give him more time to work on lowering drug prices.\n\n@realDonaldTrump: Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council,he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\n\nA few other business leaders chimed in on the matter, but the executive community was largely silent about the president's initial reaction to the events in Charlottesville. Goldman Sachs' Lloyd Blankfein was one of the few who came close to criticizing the president.\n\nLater, Trump condemned white supremacists and \"racist\" violence, two days after he faced backlash for what was seen as a tepid response to the attack.\n\n\"Racism is evil, and those who cause violence in its name are criminals and thugs, including the KKK, neo-Nazis, white supremacists and other hate groups that are repugnant to everything we hold dear as Americans,\" Trump said at the White House on Monday.\n\n-- CNBC's Dawn Giel, Jacob Pramuk and Sarah Whitten contributed to this report.", America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-15T00:34:00Z", "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/woman-pushed-way-speeding-car-200200873.html", "sim": 0.4901960790157318, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "A young man was catapulted into the air as he was hit by an oncoming car during Saturday's violence in Charlottesville, Va., but not before pushing his fianc\u00e9 out of harm's way.\n\nRead: Friend Raises Incredible $200,000 in Memory of Woman Killed in Charlottesville Attack\n\nMarcus Martin's fiance, Marissa Blair, is also a friend of Heather Heyer, the 32-year-old paralegal who was killed when the Dodge Challenger plowed into the crowd.\n\n\"You see bodies flying and then the car comes and I just feel somebody push me out of the way,\" she told Inside Edition. \"Heather was right there. Heather was right in front of me when it happened. So it was unbelievable, it was unreal. Words can't even describe that moment.\"\n\nHer fianc\u00e9 escaped with a broken leg. The driver accused of hitting them, James Alex Fields Jr., was arrested Saturday and appeared in court Monday.\n\nHe was charged with murder, hit and run, and three counts of malicious wounding. He did not enter a plea.\n\nThere is more fallout over the Charlottesville violence as one of the president's top business advisers, Kenneth Frazier, CEO of the medical company Merck, resigned over the president's tepid rebuke of white supremacist groups.\n\n\"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy,\" Frazier said Monday. \"I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nHe was reacting to Trump's statement Saturday, for which he was criticized for not mentioning the Ku Klux Klan, Nazis or white supremacy by name.\n\nPresident Trump also slammed Frazier on Twitter, saying, \"He will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES.\"\n\nNow that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council,he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES! -- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nThe president made a much tougher denunciation on the violence Monday, saying, \"Racism has no place in America.\"\n\n\"Racism is evil, and those who cause violence in its name are criminals and thugs, including KKK, neo-Nazis, white supremacists and other hate groups that are repugnant to everything we hold dear as Americans,\" Trump said. \"Those who spread violence in the name of bigotry strike at the very core of America.\"\n\nMeanwhile, some of the white supremacists that have been pictured marching are being shamed on social media.\n\nA Twitter account named @YesYoureARacist is asking, \"If you recognize any of the Nazis marching in Charlottesville, send me their names and I'll make them famous.\"\n\nRead: One Dead, Several Injured After Car Plows Into Pedestrians at White Nationalist Rally: 'I Am Heartbroken'\n\nOne of the neo-Nazis identified has been fired from his job with the hot dog chain Top Dog.\n\nTIKI Brand Products, the company who makes the tiki torches wielded by white supremacist groups is distancing itself from the movement.\n\n\"We do not support the use of our products in this way. Our products are designed to enhance backyard gatherings,\" the company said in a statement.\n\nJohn Oliver, the host of Last Week Tonight on HBO, also joined in the chorus of criticism.\n\n\"In a country where previous presidents actually defeated Nazis we have a president who can't even condemn them,\" he said.\n\nWatch: Trump's 'Fire and Fury' Remark About North Korea Was Improvised: Sixty-one percent of Lundbeck's sales came from North America in the first half of 2017.\n\nEarlier Monday, Trump lashed out at Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier for stepping down from the American Manufacturing Council over the president's equivocal response to a white nationalist protest that turned deadly in Charlottesville, Virginia, on Saturday.\n\n\"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T21:58:00Z", "url": "https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/2017/08/14/merck-ceo-ken-fraziers-left-trump-council-right-move-bad-choice/565235001/", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nThe decision by Merck CEO Ken Frazier to quit an advisory panel in the wake of President Trump's initial response to violence in Charlottesville, was hailed by many Monday as a stance that should be emulated by other corporate leaders. But companies may worry about what weighing in on an emotionally charged issue will mean for the bottom line.\n\nYet some say that when a corporate leader takes a position that appears to be grounded in principle, it can actually burnish a company's image.\n\n\"There are always concerns that business leaders have about the consequences of taking a moral stand,'' says Katherine Phillips, who teaches leadership at Columbia Business School. \"But oftentimes I think those leaders recognize that the moral stand they take could be good for business.\"\n\nFrazier's decision came In the wake of a white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Va. on Saturday that left three people dead, and dozens more injured.\n\nPresident Trump gave an initial statement that did not specifically denounce the KKK, neo-Nazis and other racist groups who engaged in the violence. Lawmakers from both sides of the political aisle, and others condemned what they viewed as a tepid and inadequate response.\n\nFrazier has been by Trump's side in the past several months, during a round table talk with pharmaceutical company executives, as well as an event where Merck and Pfizer said they would work with Corning to produce more jobs and create sturdier glass vials.\n\nBut on Monday, Frazier said that he would be leaving Trump's manufacturing business council, tweeting that \"as CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\n\"I think it could encourage other business leaders to speak out and to recognize that their reputations are influenced by who they're affiliated with,'' Phillips says.\n\nBut wading into the roiling waters of race relations and other hot button topics can backfire. In 2015, for instance, the first phase of an initiative by Starbucks, in which baristas were given the choice of penning the words \"Race Together'' on customers cups, was largely met with scorn and derision by critics who said the idea was simplistic.\n\nMore: Merck's CEO quits Trump's council over Charlottesville, the president claps back\n\nMore: Trump bestows moral equivalency\n\nMore: President Trump condemns white supremacists after Charlottesville violence\n\nBut not speaking out could also hurt a company's reputation, particularly if the issue is one that it has professed to take an interest in, such as LGBT rights, diversity or criminal justice reform, says Rashad Robinson, executive director of the civil rights group Color of Change.\n\n\"There are other CEOs that are still part of this Trump business council,\" says Robinson who called Frazier's stance \"powerful.''\n\n\"These companies need to tell us what side of history do they want to be on,'' he continued. \"It's not just Charlottesville. (There are) attacks on a whole set of issues many of these companies say publicly they care about. Attacks on diversity and fairness . . . The hypocrisy is clear, and hopefully this statement from Merck will be a step in the right direction.\"\n\nMany took to Twitter to praise Frazier's decision.\n\n\"Mr. Frazier has a conscience,'' tweeted Jim Cramer, host of Mad Money on CNBC. \"That's America.''\n\n566564001 View Live Authoring TypeEmbedCredit / BylineNot setCreated By:cjonesSourceNot setClassificationNot setInitial Publish08/14/17 4:58:44 PMEmbargo DateNot embargoedTotal ViewsCurrently unavailableTotal Social RefersCurrently unavailableembed: Twitter\n\nListen--free speech is a two-way street and i get that.. I favor the First Amendment. Mr. Frazier has a conscience. That's America. -- Jim Cramer (@jimcramer)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nLayout Priority\n\nCNBC reporter Meg Tirrell tweeted a statement from Roy Vagelos, current chairman of Regeneron, and Merck's former chairman and CEO.\n\n566569001 View Live Authoring TypeEmbedCredit / BylineNot setCreated By:cjonesSourceNot setClassificationNot setInitial Publish08/14/17 4:59:41 PMEmbargo DateNot embargoedTotal ViewsCurrently unavailableTotal Social RefersCurrently unavailableembed: Twitter\n\nRoy Vagelos, $REGN chairman, former $MRK CEO & drug industry legend, on Ken Frazier's decision to leave president's manufacturing council: pic.twitter.com/kcNeDArB8O -- Meg Tirrell (@megtirrell)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nLayout Priority\n\n\"I have known Ken for 25 years since I first recruited him to Merck,'' the statement said. \"I applaud his decision to step down from the council this morning.''\n\nLloyd Blankfein, CEO of Goldman Sachs also tweeted a message that quoted Abraham Lincoln and encouraged unity. \"Isolate those who try to separate us,'' he said. \"No equivalence w/ those who bring us together.''\n\n566554001 View Live Authoring TypeEmbedCredit / BylineNot setCreated By:cjonesSourceNot setClassificationNot setInitial Publish08/14/17 4:57:30 PMEmbargo DateNot embargoedTotal ViewsCurrently unavailableTotal Social RefersCurrently unavailableembed: Twitter\n\nLincoln: \"A house divided against itself cannot stand.\" Isolate those who try to separate us. No equivalence w/ those who bring us together. -- Lloyd Blankfein (@lloydblankfein)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nLayout Priority\n\nStill, some companies may believe that they can have a greater impact on policy by remaining in advisory positions to or dialogue with the president rather than stepping away. Dell said in a statement Monday that it would continue engaging with theTrump administration .\n\nBut some civil rights advocates say that so far, outside advisers do not appear to have had much of a mitigating effect on Trump's policies or pronouncements.\n\n\"Right after the election we heard a lot of CEOs and even people in the Democratic party talk about . .. 'if we just get inside the room and share our opinions, then somehow Donald Trump will back away from some of these actions,' '' Robinson says, saying that has not been the case. \" People who do want change have to recognize that those who tell us that simply being at the table is going to make things better have to prove that to be true.''\n\nFrazier was the only African American member of the manufacturing advisory council, and Phillips said that some observers might unfortunately assign less significance to his stance because he is black.\n\n\"I think in some ways, when African American people stand up . . . . for what they're expected to stand up for, it can have less influence,'' she says. \"I hope that a white leader also does the same because I do think it may speak even louder than what Mr. Frazier does.''\n\nBut Cornell Brooks, former president of the NAACP and a long-time civil rights lawyer says that Frazier's stature and reputation give his decision great weight, regardless of race.\n\n\"He is a very well-respected CEO, a well respected attorney and a pioneering African American corporate leader,'' Brooks says. He \"leads one of America's largest and most prominent companies. I think most people will regard his act as one of personal conviction.''\n\nListen--free speech is a two-way street and i get that.. I favor the First Amendment. Mr. Frazier has a conscience. That's America. -- Jim Cramer (@jimcramer)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nRoy Vagelos, $REGN chairman, former $MRK CEO & drug industry legend, on Ken Frazier's decision to leave president's manufacturing council: pic.twitter.com/kcNeDArB8O -- Meg Tirrell (@megtirrell)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nLincoln: \"A house divided against itself cannot stand.\" Isolate those who try to separate us. No equivalence w/ those who bring us together. -- Lloyd Blankfein (@lloydblankfein)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORERead or Share this story: https://usat.ly/2wYtOlz", {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T13:12:00Z", "url": "http://www.newsweek.com/fox-news-blames-media-charlottesville-terrorism-kkk-donald-trump-media-650520", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Fox News has been searching for something -- anything -- that would allow it to deflect the violent Unite the Right rallies in Charlottesville, Virginia, that erupted Saturday afternoon. By Monday morning, it appeared the network had found the group to point its collective finger at for the continued racism, violence and polarization in America: not the Nazis, the KKK, white supremacists or the \"alt-right,\" but the mainstream media.\n\nAs graphic images of white men carrying tiki torches and attacking counterprotesters flooded timelines across the nation, hosts of the right-wing morning talk show Fox & Friends blamed the left and the media for wanting to \"run with their narrative\" about the latest developments.\n\nRelated: Fox News Was Attacking Obama For Using Mustard At This Point In His Presidency\n\nDaily Emails and Alerts - Get the best of Newsweek delivered to your inbox\n\nFox News hosts Abby Huntsman and Pete Hegseth slammed news outlets for their coverage of President Donald Trump's statement on the rally, in which he failed to directly condemn white supremacists and the alt-right movement, instead stating that hate had come \"from all sides.\"\n\n\"It seems like an open door now for them to run with their narrative, when the president didn't come out and call it for what it was,\" Huntsman said Monday morning. \"In their minds, and a lot of them, they say this can, we can associate the president with these groups, and that fits a lot of the narrative on the left, a lot of the media, and that is very problematic for, for, society.\"\n\n\"Of course, because so much of the left sees this world not through America first but through racial identity politics first,\" Hegseth said.\n\nTrump's favorite news outlet was one of the only networks to praise his response to Charlottesville. Others criticized the president's statement as falling short of an outright rejection of white supremacy.\n\nRebuke of Trump's statement didn't come solely from the media, however. Ken Frazier, CEO of the pharmaceutical company Merck & Co., resigned from the president's manufacturing council Monday. \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy,\" Frazier wrote in a statement announcing his departure. His resignation seemed to anger the president, who tweeted in response: \"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nSeveral former presidents spoke out about the events over the weekend, including Bill Clinton, who stated, \"Even as we protect free speech and assembly, we must condemn the hatred, violence and white supremacy on display in Charlottesville.\"\n\nBarack Obama quoted Nelson Mandela on Twitter, writing, \"No one is born hating another person because of the color of his skin or his background or his religion,\" along with a photo of him greeting multiracial children during his tenure in the White House.\n\nVice President Mike Pence also directly condemned white supremacy in a statement, saying, \"We have no tolerance for hate and violence from white supremacists, neo-Nazis or the KKK. These dangerous fringe groups have no place in American public life and in the American debate, and we condemn them in the strongest possible terms.\"\n\nBut according to Fox News, it was the media, not Trump or the racists in Charlottesville, who should be judged after one woman was killed and at least 19 others were injured at the weekend rally.\n\n\"Look for the press to keep pressing him no During his time at that firm, Frazier worked to get the conviction of James Willie \"Bo\" Cochran overturned in Alabama.\n\nCochran was released from prison in 1997 after spending two decades on death row. He died last year.\n\nFrazier, who is black, wrote in a 2004 essay for the American Bar Association that while he was working on Cochran's case, it \"became obvious that one of the major factors contributing to Bo's conviction centered around the fact that each of his jury trials was distorted when viewed through the lens of race.\"\n\nRelated: Trump lashes out at Merck CEO\n\nFrazier left Drinker Biddle & Reath in 1992 to join Merck. A Harvard Law School graduate, he started as a lawyer for Merck and was named the pharmaceutical titan's general counsel in 2006. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T14:37:00Z", "url": "http://investorplace.com/2017/08/trump-lashes-out-at-merck-co-inc-mrk-but-does-it-matter/", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "In the immediate wake of the events in Charlottesville, Wall Street had a strong opening Aug. 14. It was a classic bounce-back from a week where reports from North Korea pushed the Dow Jones Industrial Average down from its 22,200 high to the Friday close of 21,858. The early rise of 140 Dow points retraced about half those losses.\n\nThen, Merck & Co., Inc. (NYSE:MRK) CEO Kenneth Frazier resigned from a federal manufacturing council over the weekend's events, and President Donald Trump reacted with a tweet that left analysts in shock, because it attacked both Frazier and the pharmaceutical industry over high prices.\n\nIn response, prices were not shaken. But will the economy be stirred?\n\nFrazier is a Democrat and his company's political action committee contributed close to equally to both parties last cycle.\n\nHis decision to serve the Trump administration was comparable to former General Electric Company (NYSE:GE) CEO Jeff Immelt's service to the Obama administration. Immelt is a lifelong Republican who came under severe criticism from conservatives over that decision. Frazier, who is African-American, was seated next to Trump in pictures of the council.\n\nNone of this should matter. MRK stock should be a buy, having delivered $3.5 billion in net income on $19.4 billion in revenue for the first six months, along with $3.8 billion in operating cash flow. Merck has done this while keeping its price increases to the mid-single digits when discounts are included in the calculation.\n\nThere are \"bad actors\" among drug companies, in terms of pricing, but Merck is not one of them. The attack by the president was personal.\n\nFrazier is not alone. Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk and Walt Disney Co. (NYSE:DIS) CEO Bob Iger previously left Trump boards, troubled by the direction of policy.\n\nA president's power is proportional to their popularity and performance. If Trump's popularity means his power is declining, that could be bullish for stocks.\n\nBut stupid policy also yields stupid results.\n\nInvestors are desperate for something to invest in, the price of Bitcoin having tripled this year, up another 5% early on Aug. 14. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T21:59:00Z", "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/plum-line/wp/2017/08/14/happy-hour-roundup-1174/", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "* Jena McGregor reports on how President Trump reacts to people who really make him mad:\n\nThe chief executive of Merck said Monday in a tweet that he was resigning from President Trump's manufacturing council, saying he was doing so \"as CEO of Merck and as a matter of personal conscience\" and that \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy, which run counter to the American ideal that all people are created equal.\"\n\nIn the statement, Kenneth C. Frazier, one of the few African American CEOs in the Fortune 500, said, \"I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism\" and touted the power of diversity. \"Our country's strength stems from its diversity and the contributions made by men and women of different faiths, races, sexual orientations and political beliefs.\"\n\nWithin an hour after the statement was first issued, Trump tweeted his initial response. \"Now that Ken Frazier of Merck Pharma has resigned from President's Manufacturing Council, he will have more time to LOWER RIPOFF DRUG PRICES!\"\n\nJust to be clear, Trump will do nothing to lower drug prices.\n\n* Jana Winter reports that the government saw something like Charlottesville coming:\n\nThe FBI and the Department of Homeland Security in May warned that white supremacist groups had already carried out more attacks than any other domestic extremist group over the past 16 years and were likely to carry out more attacks over the next year, according to an intelligence bulletin obtained by Foreign Policy.\n\nEven as President Donald Trump continues to resist calling out white supremacists for violence, federal law enforcement has made clear that it sees these types of domestic extremists as a severe threat. The report, dated May 10, says the FBI and DHS believe that members of the white supremacist movement \"likely will continue to pose a threat of lethal violence over the next year.\"\n\nWe should also note that less than two weeks after Trump took office, his administration moved to revamp a program called Countering Extremist Violence so that it would no longer address white supremacists and would focus solely on Muslims.\n\n* An Oklahoma man has been arrested by the FBI on charges that he tried to detonate what he thought was a 1,000 pound bomb, driven by admiration for Timothy McVeigh and anti-government \"Three Percenter\" ideology.\n\n* Here's a transcript of the remarks President Trump made today in which he made clear that he does in fact oppose the KKK and neo-Nazis.\n\n* Greg Jarrett reports that President Trump says \"I am seriously considering pardoning Sheriff [Joe] Arpaio,\" who was convicted of blatantly ignoring judicial orders to stop randomly harassing Hispanic people.\n\n* Jonathan Cohn argues that despite Trump's tantrums, the core Republican dilemma on health care remains unresolved.\n\n* Francis Wilkinson argues that too many Bernie Sanders supporters are still in sway to the idea that everything is rigged against them, and explains what that means for the Democratic Party going forward.\n\n* Jennifer Rubin has some ideas on what Republicans can do if they really want to distance themselves from white supremacists and atone for Trump.\n\n* Mark Muro reports that industrial robots are significantly more common in red states than blue states, During his time at that firm, Frazier worked to get the conviction of James Willie \"Bo\" Cochran overturned in Alabama.\n\nCochran was released from prison in 1997 after spending two decades on death row. He died last year.\n\nFrazier, who is black, wrote in a 2004 essay for the American Bar Association that while he was working on Cochran's case, it \"became obvious that one of the major factors contributing to Bo's conviction centered around the fact that each of his jury trials was distorted when viewed through the lens of race.\"\n\nFrazier left Drinker Biddle & Reath in 1992 to join Merck. A Harvard Law School graduate, he started as a lawyer for Merck and was named the pharmaceutical titan's general counsel in 2006. He was promoted to president in 2010 and became CEO and chairman a year later.\n\nFrazier is registered as a Democrat in Pennsylvania. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T21:10:00Z", "url": "http://www.industryweek.com/corporate-responsibility/merck-ceo-resignation-won-t-impact-council-says-industry-group", "sim": 0.4509803950786591, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Frazier was joined by a handful of other executives as a voice of dissent in the business community, including CEOs of Apple and Unilever. However, no other executive distanced themselves from the manufacturing council. For instance, General Electric said in a statement that it \"has no tolerance for hate, bigotry or racism,\" but added that its chairman and recently-retired chief executive, Jeff Immelt, will remain on the manufacturing council.\n\nThe resignation of Merck & Co. CEO Ken Frazier from President Donald Trump's council of manufacturing executives won't have much impact as long as the council has the President's ears, according to Harry Moser, president and founder of Reshoring Initiative, an industry advocacy group.\n\n\"The deaths in Charlottesville are a disaster and it's a long-term issue, so one guy stepping down from President Trump's manufacturing council is not a horrible thing for the council,\" Moser said. \"\"If the other executives in the council contribute, and are listened to by President Trump, then 3 months from now no one will remember this case.\n\nFrazier resigned from the council on August 14, saying \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values\" by rejecting expressions of hatred, bigotry and group supremacy. Referring to the weekend's violence in Virginia involving white supremacist groups that Trump has been criticized for not taking a forceful enough stand against, Frazier said \"as a matter of personal conscience, I feel a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\nBy midday, Frazier was joined by a handful of other executives as a voice of dissent in the business community, including CEOs of Apple and Unilever. However, no other executive distanced themselves from the manufacturing council. For instance, General Electric said in a statement that it \"has no tolerance for hate, bigotry or racism,\" but added that its chairman and recently-retired chief executive, Jeff Immelt, will remain on the manufacturing council.\n\n\"President Trump clearly is disruptive, so some people get offended - whether right or wrong - but he's trying to get important things done,\" Moser added.\n\nAccording to the Reshoring Initiative, for the first time in decades, more manufacturing jobs are returning to the United States than are going offshore. They are willing to say what President Trump wouldn't say for two days while vacationing at his private golf club.\n\nUtah Republican Sen. Orrin Hatch, for example: \"We should call evil by its name. My brother didn't give his life fighting Hitler for Nazi ideas to go unchallenged here at home.\"\n\nThat's the sort of leadership sorely lacking at the top.\n\nIt took until Monday for the president to finally -- finally! -- call racism evil, to name the hate groups at Charlottesville, Va., and to denounce them as \"repugnant to everything we hold dear as Americans.\" His delay makes his sincerity questionable.\n\nThe nation needed to hear a clear condemnation of the neo-Nazi and Ku Klux Klan sympathizers who waved swastikas and Confederate flags and incited deadly violence over the weekend. Mr. Trump instead gave them a wink and a nod. He cravenly spoke of hatred \"on many sides, on many sides\" -- as if the torch-bearing, epithet-spewing white nationalists in Charlottesville were no more deplorable than the people protesting them.\n\nThose six words were an unmistakable dog whistle to supporters like the Daily Stormer, which wagged its tail: \"Trump comments were good. He didn't attack us,\" said the neo-Nazi website.\n\nMr. Trump's eventual clarification came only after enormous pressure from brave people like Kenneth C. Frazier, chairman and CEO of Merck, who quit the President's American Manufacturing Council, saying: \"America's leaders must honor our fundamental values by clearly rejecting expressions of hatred, {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T15:41:00Z", "url": "http://news.sky.com/story/charlottesville-resignation-chief-executive-encapsulates-american-dream-10988659", "sim": 0.4235294163227081, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "Kenneth Frazier, the Merck chief executive who has resigned from President Trump's Manufacturing Council, has an inspiring story that encapsulates the American Dream.\n\nHis background also explains why Mr Frazier, one of only four black CEOs in the Fortune 500 list of America's largest corporations, has taken the stand he has over the Charlottesville violence and Mr Trump's response to it.\n\nMr Frazier's grandfather was a South Carolina sharecropper, working in the system set up following the American Civil War under which landowners allowed tenant farmers to use their land in exchange for a portion of the crop.\n\nAlthough most sharecroppers were white, one-third of them were black, many of them former slaves or the descendants of slaves.\n\n:: Trump suffers first resignation over Charlottesville race riots\n\nIt was an exploitative arrangement that has been described as \"slavery by another name\" and that, for example, often prevented sharecroppers from selling their produce to customers other than their landlord.\n\nMr Frazier grew up in north Philadelphia, one of the poorest areas in the city.\n\nHis mother died when he was just 12 and he and his two siblings were raised by their father, Otis, a self-taught janitor who, twice a month, made his children walk a mile-and-a-half to their nearest library to borrow and return books.\n\nThis upbringing instilled in the young Kenneth a love of learning and a work ethic that saw him graduate from Pennsylvania State University with the highest possible grade and, three years later, from Harvard Law School.\n\nHe subsequently joined a Philadelphia law firm where, working on a pro-bono basis, he secured the release of James Willie \"Bo\" Cochran, a black man from Alabama who had been wrongly convicted of murder and spent 21 years on death row.\n\nMr Frazier joined Merck as an in-house lawyer in 1992 and successfully led its defence against lawsuits brought against the company for the sale of Vioxx, a painkiller that was found to increase the likelihood of heart attacks and strokes.\n\nHe became chief executive in 2011 and is regarded by Wall Street as having done a good job.\n\nMerck has won acclaim for its strong approach to inclusion and diversity and has 35% more non-white people in senior management roles than the average American company.\n\nAmong the causes it has championed under Mr Frazier is Merck for Mothers, a 10-year, $500m drive to reduce maternal mortality.\n\nMr Frazier and his wife, Andrea, were also among the founders of Cornerstone Christian Academy, which seeks to provide a high-quality education for 250 of Philadelphia's poorest children.\n\nIn an interview with Black Enterprise three years ago, he explained: \"My life story...[shows] that being born poor doesn't mean that you'll always end up there.\n\n\"Your story isn't written. You get to write that story. You get to determine your future.\"", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "time": "15:41:00", "originalArticle": null, "details": {}, "timeCrawl": "22:18:00", "title": "Quitting boss {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T23:48:00Z", "url": "http://www.foxbusiness.com/politics/2017/08/14/boeing-ceo-muilenburg-staying-on-trumps-business-council.html", "sim": 0.4196078479290009, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "President, Chairman and CEO of The Boeing Company Dennis Muilenburg speaks at the \"What's Next?\" conference in Chicago, Illinois, U.S., October 4, 2016. REUTERS/Jim Young - RTSQQVH (Reuters)\n\nBoeing's Chief Executive Officer Dennis Muilenburg will not be stepping down from President Donald Trump's American Manufacturing Council, FOX Business has learned.\n\n\"He [Muilenburg] remains on the president's manufacturing council,\" John Dern, a spokesperson for Boeing, said in a statement to FOX Business.\n\nWhen asked if the airplane manufacturer had a comment about the violent protests that took place in Charlottesville, Va., Dern referred FOX Business to a statement by the Business Roundtable, which Muilenburg is a member of.\n\n\"The CEOs of Business Roundtable will never accept such intolerance and hate. We will continue to build our companies around the principles of respect, trust and equal opportunity to all our employees,\" the statement said.\n\nEarlier Monday, Merck (MRK) CEO Kenneth Frazier, one of the most prominent African-American business executives, resigned from Trump's business council, in apparent protest of the president's response to violent clashes in Virginia, saying he was doing so \"as a matter of personal conscience\" and that he felt \"a responsibility to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.\"\n\npic.twitter.com/a1PNQZism5 -- Merck (@Merck)\n\nAugust 14, 2017\n\nThe vicious attacks that took place on Saturday by members of white nationalist, Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazi groups, left three dead, including a young woman who was killed when a Dodge Challenger plowed into a crowd of counter-protesters.\n\nMuilenburg is one of a handful of other CEOs who have not resigned from Trump's advisory groups after the president failed to mention white nationalist groups specifically in his remarks following the incidents in Charlottesville.\n\nSteve Schwarzman, CEO of private equity group Blackstone and leader of Trump's Strategic and Policy Forum, condemned the events in Charlottesville but said he would remain on the forum.\n\n\"As the president said today, I believe we need to find a path to heal the wounds left by this tragedy and address its underlying causes. Encouraging tolerance and understanding must be a core national imperative and I will work to further that goal,\" Schwarzman said in a statement.\n\nJeff Immelt, current chairman of General Electric, will stay on the Manufacturing Council, even though his company said in a statement they have \"no tolerance for hate, bigotry or racism.\"\n\nTwo days after the incidents in Charlottesville, Trump issued another statement, this time singling out the groups by name.\n\n\"Racism is evil, and those who cause violence in its name are criminals and thugs, including the K.K.K., neo-Nazis, white supremacists,\" Trump said.\n\nWhile Muilenburg may be staying on board, Trump and the Boeing CEO also have a muddied history of their own. In December, then President-elect Trump, publicly attacked Boeing in a tweet for what he called \"out of control\" costs.\n\n\"Boeing is building a brand new 747 Air Force One for future presidents, but costs are out of control, more than $4 billion. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T14:18:00Z", "url": "http://www.weny.com/story/36130257/merck-ceo-helped-get-black-inmate-off-death-row", "sim": 0.4117647111415863, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "NEW YORK (CNNMoney) -- Kenneth Frazier, the CEO of drug giant Merck that left President Trump's manufacturing council following Trump's refusal to condemn white supremacists, was previously a lawyer who helped free a black death row inmate falsely accused of murder.\n\nPrior to joining Merck, Frazier was a partner at the Philadelphia-based law firm Drinker Biddle & Reath. During his time at that firm, Frazier worked to get the conviction of James Willie \"Bo\" Cochran overturned in Alabama.\n\nCochran was released from prison in 1997 after spending two decades on death row. He died last year.\n\nFrazier, who is black, wrote in a 2004 essay for the American Bar Association that while he was working on Cochran's case, it \"became obvious that one of the major factors contributing to Bo's conviction centered around the fact that each of his jury trials was distorted when viewed through the lens of race.\"\n\nFrazier left Drinker Biddle & Reath in 1992 to join Merck. A Harvard Law School graduate, he started as a lawyer for Merck and was named the pharmaceutical titan's general counsel in 2006. He was promoted to president in 2010 and became CEO and chairman a year later.\n\nFrazier is registered as a Democrat in Pennsylvania. But according to data from the Center for Responsive Politics, he donated to Congressional candidates for both parties last year, including Democratic senators Bob Casey, Ron Wyden and Patty Murray as well as Republican House members Patrick Meehan and Kevin Brady.\n\nTM & \u00a9 2017 Cable News Network, Inc., a Time Warner Company. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T18:05:00Z", "url": "http://www.timesunion.com/7day-business/article/GE-condemns-bigotry-while-Immelt-will-stay-on-11817845.php", "sim": 0.407843142747879, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "ALBANY -- General Electric Co. Chairman Jeffrey Immelt will not follow Merck & Co. CEO Kenneth Frazier's exit from President Donald Trump's American Manufacturing Council.\n\nFrazier resigned Monday, and said in a statement that Trump didn't come out strongly enough against the white nationalist rallies in Charlottesville, Va., that led to the death of a anti-racism protester.\n\nGE is one of the Capital Region's largest employers with more than 6,000 workers, most of them in Schenectady County.\n\n\"GE has no tolerance for hate, bigotry or racism, and we strongly condemn the violent extremism in Charlottesville over the weekend,\" GE spokeswoman Jennifer Friedman said. \"GE is a proudly inclusive company with employees who represent all religions, nationalities, sexual orientations and races.\"\n\nGE has a long history of supporting diversity in the workplace, and Immelt has been critical of Trump, even as he has served on Trump's council, on the president's views on immigration and inclusiveness.\n\nHowever, Friedman said that Immelt, who stepped down as CEO of GE on Aug. 1 but remains chairman of the company, would stay on the council since the goal is to increase U.S. competitiveness in manufacturing, a strong desire of GE and Immelt.\n\n\"With more than 100,000 employees in the United States, it is important for GE to participate in the discussion on how to drive growth and productivity in the U.S., therefore, Jeff Immelt will remain on the Presidential Committee on American Manufacturing while he is the chairman of GE,\" Friedman said.\n\nImmelt was replaced as CEO by John Flannery. Immelt is scheduled to step down as chairman at the end of this year when Flannery will take the post.\n\nFrazier, the Merck CEO, issued a statement on Twitter explaining that America's leaders must take a stand against hate and racism. He implied Trump did not go far enough to condemn the rallies that led to the death of Heather Heyer, who was killed when a motorist plowed into a group protesting the white nationalist rally.\n\nTrump's initial comments did not mention the KKK or white nationalists, only the violence from both sides of the issues. {"dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "storyUri": "eng-3360602", "lang": "eng", "dateTime": "2017-08-14T20:58:00Z", "url": "http://www.businessinsider.com/trump-manufacturing-council-whos-still-in-2017-8", "sim": 0.4039215743541718, "eventUri": "eng-3360602", "isDuplicate": false, "body": "President Donald Trump speaks during a meeting with manufacturing executives at the White House in Washington. AP\n\nPresident Donald Trump's manufacturing council of business leaders lost a member Monday amid fallout from Trump's handling of the weekend's white-nationalist protests in Charlottesville, Virginia.\n\nMerck CEO Kenneth Frazier, the only black business leader in the group, resigned from it after Trump failed to explicitly denounce white nationalism in connection to the violence surrounding the protests.\n\nBy the time Trump eventually denounced white nationalists and neo-Nazis in a televised address later Monday, Frazier remained the only one to have stepped down from the council because of the weekend's events.\n\nThe council, which was formed in January, originally had 24 CEOs involved but now has 21. Business Insider contacted the representatives of the remaining members of the council to ask for a statement on Frazier's departure and their own plans for future participation. These were the responses:\n\nSteve Schwarzman, the CEO of private equity giant Blackstone and leader of Trump's Strategic and Policy Forum, also condemned the events in Charlottesville and said he would remain as head of the Forum.\n\n\"Bigotry, hatred, and extremism are an affront to core American values and have no place in this country,\" Schwarzman's statement said. \"I am deeply saddened and troubled by the tragic events in Charlottesville. My heartfelt condolences go out to the victims and their families. As the president said today, I believe we need to find a path to heal the wounds left by this tragedy and address its underlying causes. Encouraging tolerance and understanding must be a core national imperative and I will work to further that goal.\n\nThe Strategic and Policy Forum is another group of business executives that includes an array of executive from companies including JPMorgan, PepsiCo, and Walmart.\n\n*Editor's Note: The manufacturing group did hold a meeting in February along with a handful of other business executives, but it is not clear whether Trumka was in attendance.", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "time": "20:58:00", "originalArticle": null, "details": {}, "timeCrawl": "20:58:00",
